It's based on a "STEPHEN KING" Novel. "The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.

The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods. Great movie in 90s'...

Roger Ebert's review about this film:

It is a strange comment to make about a film set inside a prison, but "The Shawshank Redemption" creates a warm hold on our feelings because it makes us a member of a family. Many movies offer us vicarious experiences and quick, superficial emotions. "Shawshank" slows down and looks. It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

Interesting that although the hero of the film is the convicted former banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the action is never seen from his point of view. The film's opening scene shows him being given two life sentences for the murder of his wife and her lover, and then we move, permanently, to a point of view representing the prison population and particularly the lifer Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). It is his voice remembering the first time he saw Andy ("looked like a stiff breeze would blow him over"), and predicting, wrongly, that he wouldn't make it in prison.

Wow! The general reaction to this movie. Frank Darabont brought Steven King's Short story to a whole new light. The cast as well as the general look of this film that makes is the classic that it is. Andy Dufrain (Tim Robbins) is accused and convicted of murdering his fiancé and her lover. Andy, the big city banker that was out of place immediately strikes a cord in Red (Morgan Freeman). The two form a relationship after a bet that didn't cash out for Red. The tale of Andy and his terrible beginnings at the Shawshank Prison is unsettling. Tim Robbin's look and performance is superb! His soft,smart demeanor is painted well. His relationship with Red is the meat of the film. Andy's defiant yet peaceful persona slowly mends in with the rest of the prisoners. The story couldn't have been told better. Morgan Freeman is the actor we know now because of this role. His dedication to his friend is undying. The thought of relationships like that make this movie so watchable. The fact that you can watch this over and over and not be distracted is it's own note. Most who collect movies have this title as a part of their collection. The story will be timeless because of the movie and cement Stephen King as not only a great Novelist but, amazing screenwriter. Everyone should watch this movie. The different feelings it invokes as well as the mystery that comes with the story are worth the Hour plus you spend. The problem is that the blueprints for movies like this aren't able to be written. That's why classics like this are far and few. Cinephiles would agree that the "Shawshank Redemption" is placed well at #1 on IMDb'S List.

I don't know what to say about this movie. Its brilliant masterpiece you just need to watch and feel it

A white collar audience identifies with Andy, and fantasizes that if *they* ended up in prison, they too would be able to rise to the top among all the low-lifes and defeat the system, hatching a brilliant plot not only to escape, but escape rich *and* settle scores.

It's entertaining and satisfying, but at the same time, the prison and prisoners are too sanitized, and the guards too 1d and stereotypically evil.

And the coincidental thunderstorm, keeping a suit clean, pressed, and odor-free in a plastic bag tied with a rope in a sewer for all that time, and the complete absence of suspicion from a dozen banks, is a little too implausible.

For a long time now I had seen this movie move up the IMDb ladder and make its way to becoming #1, I was a bit irritated being that it took the spot of "The Godfather" however, this was before I had ever laid my eyes on even a trailer for this film, so I researched through the credits and found out that it was based on a novel by one of my favorite writers "Stephen King", I know what your thinking, how could he be one of my favorite writers if I didn't even have a clue about this Masterpiece. July 24, 2010 was my movie day, I promised myself I was going to stay up 24 Hours watching some of my favorite Films, I started of at around 12:45 with the controversial, sadistic, genius, masterpiece that is "A Clockwork Orange", then after my brain was through with Ultra-Violence I proceeded watching the best sequel ever made in the History of cinema "The Godfather Part II", then after I felt like a Corleone I started watching the Coen Brothers Masterpiece "No Country For Old Men", then after feeling lost I started watching "Pulp Fiction" and after that the time was around 4:30 P.M. and I broke my promise to myself and took what I thought was going to be a 2 Hour Nap which turned into a 6 Hour Intermission, I woke up around 10:00 deciding which movie I was going to watch and I wanted it to be a Classic I had never seen, I was thinking "12 Angry Men" but for some reason I wanted to see what the all this fuss was about when it came to Shawkshank Redemption" so I rented it and started watching around 11:45 P.M., Let me just say after this movie left an Impact in my Life and Mind, I now actually know why it is #1 on this site and it is for good reason, this movie made me laugh hysterically at times like in "Animal House", it made me think like "Fight Club" does at times, it made me frightened like "The Shining" at times and I have no other movie to reference my Sobbing emotions with because no other film has made me Cry, and that should tell you that after a day of Great Films this one had the biggest Impact on me.
You must see this movie. Great plot, awesome acting. I can't believe it didn't win an Oscar. It should have beaten Gump that year.

Years ago I decided to start collecting Stephen King paperback editions (and reading them, too) to prop up my excellent English. I'd found out that in the horror genre, everything that had something to do, had the label 'Stephen King' or 'John Carpenter' on it. Luckily both (as in 'Cat's Eye). But as I introduced myself with Mr. King's works I found out that the Enchantment in it isn't in the gore (which he describes splendidly, meaning that I can smell the rottening human flesh despite the fact that my nose exists only for cosmetical reasons) but the professional skill to tell a story. King gets paid by the page, so nowadays he's apt to write stories up to three bricks thick before his eyes wear out. Luckily, his best stories to be filmed are the ones that don't need 'overwriting',nor 'overfilming' as in mini-TV-series as 'The Stand', 'Golden Years', and so on. The best way for Stephen King to make an original story for a movie seems to be to: 1) keep it compact and 2) stay out of intestines, awkward smells and anything that comes out of your body when you're dead). We saw 'Stand by me me' already and 'Dolores Claiborne' afterwards, but this is the upmost number one. When King tells a little story in size of a novelette with no hurry at all, there should be nothing to add. But: then comes the movie with its more than perfect casting plus the original serenity maintained! I conclude my speech with saying that no other movie ever has collected full 10 points, horror or not.

I read Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption as part of Stephen King's Different Seasons, and loved the story.. to see just how much one person can go through, and not only remain sane, but keep his morals about him, even in the purgatory of a corrupt prison. The book was incredible. But the movie took it one step further, with incredibly well chosen actors and a beautiful sense of the book that is hard to set to a movie, as well as lines that I still remember at the drop of a hat. Incredible, and one of my favorite movies of all time.

After seeing this movie for the first time I was stunned. Living in Maine i was very interested in the whole story. The prison featured in the movie is very similar to our own Thomaston State prison. This is not just a good movie, but a great story as well. It keeps you wanting to see Andy set free throughout the whole thing.

That's my feeling when I finished reading the novel recently. Frank Darabont obviously made a lot of major modifications. The ending scene is one of them. Forrest Gump is good. Pulp Fiction is good too. But this movie is even better. And I'm glad that I saw it in the theater, not on the videotape.

This film is one that I consider under-appreciated. It captures the essence of human nature, in every one of its 142 minutes. Fear, humanity, love, anger and courage are just a few emotions and traits shown on film in this masterpiece. In the IMDB top250 films, it comes third behind Lord of The Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring and The Godfather. While good films in their own league, they don't compare to the magnificence of The Shawshank Redemption.

'Shawshank' is set in America in the 1950s-70s. It tells the story of Andy Dufresne, who is sent to Shawshank Prison for a double murder, that of his wife and her lover. The film shows us the relationships he develops with fellow prisoners, especially of that with Red, real name Ellis Boyd Redding. Tim Robbins' gentle, yet powerful portrayal of Andy touches the heart of the viewer and makes him likeable. Morgan Freeman should have won the Oscar for which he was nominated for portraying Red, the man who 'can get things'. He is a charming character that makes you want to see this film at least once more, and many of his lines stick in the memory. For instance, when Andy tells Red he wants him to get Rite Hayworth for him, Red tells him he'll try his best. Andy is still unsure, until 'I don't have her down my pants right now, Andy, but I'll get her for you!' If you have never seen 'The Shawshank Redemption', go down to the nearest video shop and rent it. No, don't rent it, BUY it. It'll be the best few quid you ever spend on entertainment. Stacy_G_
This movie is the best from all the movies ever!!!!

one of the films that you must watch in lifetime. A film about long-term imprisonment that takes its time to convey what the slow crawl of a lifer's existence might feel like. Thoroughly gripping, and pretty refreshing. Ten years ago The Shawshank Redemption was a low-key prison film that didn't recoup its costs. Slowly it has become one of the most popular movies of all time - and, for some, it has even been life- changing. It is a strange comment to make about a film set inside a prison, but "The Shawshank Redemption" creates a warm hold on our feelings because it makes us a member of a family. Many movies offer us vicarious experiences and quick, superficial emotions. "Shawshank" slows down and looks. It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

I have a rather small film collection, but "The Shawshank Redemption" is one of the movies that is a part of it. This film is done beautifully, from the soundtrack to the acting. I'm no film critic, so I'll leave the in-depth reviews to those who are more capable, but I will say that if you haven't seen this film, make the trip to the video store.

I give it a 10.
It's just sweet, classic and one of the best movies ever... that's all I can say About out this...

This movie is fantastic in it's build up and execution of what finally happens. With Andy and red going through so much, for both of them on their own to get redemption. In that it also points out an excellent point for the crappy us prison system, which only institutionalizes criminals. And makes you see the flaw of their failure to rehabilitate people. In this movie the acting is expressive and realistic from most people, but natural as something based off Steven king, the antagonist and alot of other bad characters come off as 2d and dry in terms of emotion, over the course of the film you get to see the warden in more depth, but the rest you don't besides maybe a quick glimpse into their life through dialog, which is an extremely strong point of this film. I feel all the conversation are written very well, and even reds narration is written very well if not a bit cliche. The story is very slow, and paints a beautifully sad picture of all of it throughout the course. And the story on its own is a really powerful one, which is a great combination with actually having been well done. The sets are great, of course as it almost exclusively takes place in one location. But even outside they're convincing. The way this movie presents back stories I can't feel if it's good or bad, but I like it and it's very unique. The music in this movie is extremely simple, but does it effectively. And the rest of the sound design is done fine too. The acting of red, Andy, Tommy, haywood, the warden, and brooks are all very fantastic performances. They all feel like real humans. And I feel like this could be a study of humans, it shows everything in so much detail while not being super long it's impressive. The ending is just iconic, and is one of the best endings for a movie. The long narration of what happens after while showing is so well done. This movie feels very grounded into reality which makes the satisfaction by the end all the more satisfying.

The camerawork in this movie isn't the best, but feels effective and never feels like it isn't conveying the mood or theme.

Overall though; even though I don't feel like it's the best movie ever, it's a fantastically written, with very efficient music and timing. And is a must see to anyone who likes good movies. Overall a 8.7/10 from me.

Not even the best within the prison genre itself. After all the positive comments I heard, I was waiting for some fantastic ending or deep philosophic message to come through. Neither did. The ending turns out to be as clichéd and predictable as most other movies in the genre. For those who like prison movies, just go and watch some A&E's investigative reports on American penal system. They are way more realistic and gut wrenching than this film and they are free.

On the other hand, let us not be too cynical either. It's obvious that a lot of good work have been put into this film. Morgan Freeman's work alone is worth the money of the movie. The other highlight is Mozart's music over the intercom, which completely captivate the inmates. The scene is deeply philosophical and the music therapeutic. But still, it is somewhat unbelievable, as how many prison inmates really dig Mozart? If they did, they probably wouldn't have ended up behind bars in the first place. But hey this is Hollywood.

It's not a must see movie unless you have never seen a prison film before. But it is an entertaining one to kill some time for a Friday night when you have run out of things to do. So for my money, it is worth 7/10.

The Shawshank Redemption was story about how perseverance, hope and innocence will change a man's destiny. Tim Robbins was eloquent and portrayed a character with acting prowess of razor sharp perfection. Wrongly accused of murdering his wife, he ends up in Shawshank Maximum Security Prison, for life. Here here he befriends Red, played by Morgan Freeman ( a role he definitely deserved the Best Supporting Actor Oscar ), your typical Jack of all traits in the prison. Their story was one of trust, hope and friendship which was ultimately the forte of this movie. Robbins acting was methodical, straight-foward and deservingly captures our sympathy. A great supporting cast also gives added strength to an already perfect movie. The background music score haunts me even until today as it successfully depicts the sad, helpless and claustrophobic mood of a maximum security prison. Rich, crisp and vibrant cinematography together with Director Frank Darabont's vivid imagination and direction style brought to life one of the greatest motion picture ever told! 10/10

" The Shawshank Redemption" is a witching and emotionally charged film that leaves a profound impact on its observers. Set within the confines of Shawshank State Penitentiary, the story weaves together themes of stopgap, fellowship, and the power of the mortal spirit.

The film follows the trip of Andy Dufresne, played brilliantly by Tim Robbins, a putatively ordinary banker who's wrongfully condemned of a crime he didn't commit. As Andy adjusts to life behind bars, he forms an doubtful fellowship with Red, portrayed by Morgan Freeman, a fellow capture known for his capability to smuggle contraband into the captivity. Their bond serves as the heart and soul of the film, showcasing the transformative power of connection and fellowship in the most doubtful of places.

What sets" The Shawshank Redemption" piecemeal is its capability to touch the deepest recesses of the mortal soul. It delves into the depths of despair, exposing the harsh realities of captivity life, while contemporaneously painting a pictorial portrayal of the adaptability of the mortal spirit. Through Andy's unvarying determination and insuperable spirit, the film teaches us the significance of holding onto stopgap, indeed in the darkest of circumstances.

The performances in this film are nothing short of remarkable. Tim Robbins delivers a nuanced depiction of Andy, landing both his vulnerability and unwavering resoluteness. Morgan Freeman, in one of his most iconic places, brings a quiet strength and wisdom to the character of Red. The chemistry between the two actors is palpable, elevating the film to new heights.

Director Frank Darabont consummately brings Stephen King's original story to life, immersing the followership in the gritty and rough world of Shawshank. The pacing of the film is consummately executed, seamlessly blending moments of heart- wrenching drama with subtle humor and genuine humanity.

" The Shawshank Redemption" is a rare gem that transcends its captivity setting, touching upon universal themes that reverberate with cult from all walks of life. It's a film that leaves an unforgettable mark on the bystander, reminding us of the power of stopgap, the value of fellowship, and the triumph of the mortal spirit in the face of adversity.

In summary," The Shawshank Redemption" is an extraordinary cinematic experience that deserves all the praise it has garnered over the times. It's a dateless masterpiece that reminds us of the adaptability of the mortal spirit and the transformative power of stopgap. A must- watch for all suckers of cinema.

First things first... This is my favorite movie of all time. Therefore, I was disturbed to see a few reviews claiming that this movie isn't all that great. Having only a few college credits remaining until I obtain a degree in Critical Film Analysis, I have studied this film numerous times and can tell you just why it is so great. First off, I read from another review that it was horrible because it was a first-time director. That just happens to be one reason why the film is so great to begin with. The director is passionate about the project since it is his first, and Darabont's passion is displayed magnificently in this film. The same goes for Kevin Costner (Dances With Wolves) and Sam Mendes (American Beauty). Both were first time directors and as a matter of fact both won Oscars for their Best Picture winning "first timers."

The other unlogical argument against this film that I read was about how "plain" it was. Heaven forbid that there is no computer enhanced bullets flying by a body being covered by dozens upon dozens of cameras (The Matrix) or some cheesy George Lucas characters that have no bearing on a story. The Shawshank Redemption is far from a plain movie though. The camera work IS amazing, just look at the scene where Andy is about to be pushed off of the roof that the inmates are tarring. That was pulled off WITHOUT a computer at all. Another argument that I heard: The story is too plain. Well I'm sorry that there is no Hans Solo pressing the *fill in the blank* button that will lift the *fill in the blank* to stop the *fill in the blank* from attacking the planet of *fill in the blank* that is inhabited by the *fill in the blank* race. The Shawshank Redemption is as real as it gets. Why introduce twenty million characters just for the shear joy of it? Darabont shows more emotion with Red and Andy than any other director that I have seen (possibly Sam Mendes may be better by a short bit). Without getting too much further into the film I'll just stop by saying that if you haven't seen The Shawshank Redemption there is a reason why it is #2 on the IMDB top 250 list. A good movie is enjoyable to watch, but a great movie will get you lost within the film and open a entire new world that you might never experience. You will lose yourself in the Shawshank Redemption. **I also recommend another Stephen King/Frank Darabont film: The Green Mile.

This is as close to a perfect film as I believe I have ever seen. Everything about it just WORKS. Stephen King famously sells his stories to filmmakers for one dollar, well this has got to be the best dollar he has ever spent. Shawshank arrived with no fanfare, no big premiere, it just opened. When I first read the Stephen King story, I thought it would be one of the best King stories to be made into a film I could imagine, and Frank Darabont did not let me down.

Casting Morgan Freeman was probably the biggest coup for this film, he is the absolute soul of dignity in everything he appears in, Tim Robbins, relatively unknown at the time of filming, is a revelation. It is, in fact, almost impossible to imagine any other actors in a single role in this film it is so perfectly cast. Then there is the music, so wonderfully incidental and appropriate. I could go on and on about specifics, photography, lighting, but it is probably best to say that anyone with a heart and a keen eye for good film-making should not miss this film. Every time I watch it I have a lump in my throat for nearly the entire running time, maybe because I have such a soft spot for it, but also because, when you know the story and it unfolds for you, every time you watch it different emotions come to the fore. There have been criticisms that Shawshank is nothing more than the most manipulative form of emotional heart-string tugging, but those criticisms are wrong, whenever Darabont was at risk of overdoing it with the manipulation, he pulled back. There is a moment near the end when it would have been perfectly appropriate for Freeman's character to burst into tears (the character does in the story), but he does not. It is an immensely effective moment, the expression on his face is so convincing that you cannot help but be reduced to tears yourself. Whether it was the actors decision or the directors is as irrelevant as the many detractors of this beautifully realised masterpiece.

Shawshank Redemption is a compelling, moving, and beautiful story which is darkly funny at times. This movie's #2 spot on IMDB is debatable, since it is essentially a formulaic Hollywood story with Hollywood characters... i.e. evil institution (guards) and noble rebels ("some" prisoners) within a microcosm (prison). Andy Dufresne is so incredibly friggin' smart (for a banker) that is almost super-hero like. Though this is definitely a worthy film, in terms of sheer greatness, Shawshank missed Cool Hand Luke by *this much*... If you want a really top-of-the-line awesome prison movie, Cool Hand Luke is the one to see.

And I truly mean that. When I first saw this film, I was blown away.With superb acting, superb story, perfect emotion and tone, and an incredible twist ending that still amazes me, this film is completely and utterly perfect. The film speaks of hope, and the film's two main characters debate throughout the movie about it. One character believes that, in prison, hope is dangerous, and that it should not be used because it will simply make life tougher. Another character believes that hope is needed, because it helps you to keep pushing for a better tomorrow when one does not appear to be in sight.

While very engaging and immensely entertaining, this film would not be held to such high regards if not for the twist ending, which is one of the greatest movie endings of all time, in my opinion. If the ending is merely average, this film would simply be considered good, possibly great, but not the masterpiece that it is today. And, watching it repeatedly makes the film even better, because experiencing the events that occur within the story makes the ending even greater.

I can't speak for everybody, but this is a film that I can watch over and over again, and love it more each time I watch it. And, while I simply talked about the ending this entire review, that is not all that makes this film incredible. However, I will not waste any more of your time talking about how wonderful this film is. And please do not waste any of your own time. Find a way to see this movie as ASAP. It will be time well spent, and you will certainly see it multiple more times.

One of my favorite movies of all time. Powerful,thought-provoking and finally irresistibly uplifting. Thanks to quietly dignified performances and Darabont's own inventive direction, The Shawshank Redemption remains a first class example of how to approach potentially weighty issues with conviction, style, lightness and wit. Shawshank is one of those rare movies that defines the whole reason I love films. It tells a fantastic story, masterfully written, acted, and directed. You can't help but become emotionally invested in the characters and story, and because of that, the film leaves you emotionally drained by the film's end, but still with a sense of hope.

Has to undoubtedly be one of the best movies of all time. Casting, acting, plot, cinematography, musical score. Everyone should see this movie to know what a good movie is. The plot twist at the very end was in itself a work of art. 10/10.

Based on Stephen King's novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption, Frank Darabont's "The Shawshank Redemption" tells the story of Andy Dusfresne (Tim Robbins), a gentle banker wrongly convicted for the double murders of his wife and her lover. The story goes on to send a powerful message of friendship and hope through even the darkest times imaginable.

"Andy Dusfresne – who crawled through a river of s*t, and came out clean on the other side", remarks Red, narrator and man-who-knows-how- to-get-things, effortlessly played by the iconic father of narration Morgan Freeman. When we meet Red, he's 20 years into a life sentence with a jaded view of the world and initially thinks little of Dusfresne. However as the months turn into years we watch them form a beautiful friendship and observe two people who truly care for each other, a rarity in many modern movies and arguably life today.

This is testament to the wonderful acting from Robbins and Freeman, and indeed across the board. The supporting cast is excellent, from the corrupt Warden Norton (Bob Gunton) and his viciously sadistic Captain Hadley (Clancy Brown), to the kind, institutionalized librarian Brooks (James Whitmore), every character in Shawshank is well rounded and brilliantly acted. And as if all that wasn't enough, the soundtrack, composed by Thomas Newman, is hauntingly beautiful and perfectly complements the film throughout its 2.5 hours.

The Shawshank Redemption is an emotional roller-coaster in that it truly offers everything, from devastating and disturbing lows to heart-warming highs, and even elements of comedy where appropriate. This movie has such depth and whilst not being preachy in any way, it has many lessons to offer through Andy's character. Andy, for me, embodies the perfect human, caught up in a hurricane of bad luck; he only once complains about his fate, the rest of the time he seems to find goodness in most situations and spends his sentence improving the lives of those around him.

This is epitomized by Red's story who, despite our protagonist being Andy, is our eyes and ears, our story teller and ultimately the one redeemed. Red, the self-proclaimed "only guilty man in Shawshank" is all but institutionalized after 30 years in those walls, but it's Andy who gradually shows him the power of hope, of integrity and of not forgetting who you are. He enables him to free himself after being freed from Shawshank.

It comes down to a simple choice really. Get busy living, or get busy dying.

A wonderfully made movie. The best thing about movie is it never looses its pace. Neither it gets fast nor it gets slow... Rightly placed at #2 on IMDb.Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman makes a great pair in the movie. Villain, Bob Gluton, the Jailer performs his role very well. "Hope is good thing, probably one of the best thing, and no good thing ever dies" is the central theme of the movie according to me.

Calm, Placid banker Andrew Dufresene lives his life with hope without loosing his temper. and that's the movie is all about. Frank Darabont did an amazing job adapting from Stephen King's short story, and he deserves as much praise for it as possible. Nobody, not even my favourite writers such as the Coen brothers of Quentin Tarantino (partly for the fact that the first only writes comedies and the latter only fares in blood spatter) could have achieved this amazing script, which completely uplifts and spellbinds the viewer.
The Shawshank Redemption is one of the greatest movies of the 90's era, it's a must see in my book. Movie Goers of every generation will love to see Andy sail off into the sunset.
This movie is one of the best and I think it deserves to be ranked first on the site.

This is not just a film. This is not just a work of art that transcends the black and white of human outlook to caste, justice and freedom and paints the human soul in all its true colors. This is not just life set in motion that takes us through it all - jealousy, hopelessness, irony, tragedy, monotony, inspiration, perseverance, success, and the unending miracle that is life itself. This is all of these and more.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is as much about the story it tells as about the way it tells it. We have to really immerse ourselves to understand and share the protagonist's exuberance of redemption that is the principal focal point of the entire film. And the slow and steady unfolding of events in an apparent idyllic manner makes it very easy for us viewers to get engrossed into this wonderfully threaded, emotionally rich story.

All the actors in the film were in perfect tune with one another. Never for once did any of them give an impression that this is a work of fiction and not a true incident captured on camera in real time. Tim Robbins is easily the finest of the cast, portraying the initially deranged, subsequently fearful and tentative, and ultimately the emancipated Andy Dufresne with total compulsion. Morgan Freeman is equally captivating as the wise and ever-supportive "Red" Redding, with his wry indifference to the sufferings of life, which finally gives way plain and raw happiness at his own emancipation.

This is a film that makes us appreciate the beauty and subtlety of life, soothes our soul, gives us hope and inspires us to keep trying till we reach our own "redemption" - our own freedom from the failures that bind us to the success that we always crave. This is film of life, for life, and a film to live by.

This movie is the most overrated movie of all time. The beginning of the movie is disgusting. Then it passes slowly , slowly , slowly ! .. There are no events !!! only a bunch of people in prison talking to each other.. that's it !! The movie was boring and long.. I mean very boring .. If it was not rated as 9.3 I would just stop watching the movie. But because of the high rating and all the fuss about it I just continued watching it. The ending was absolutely hilarious ! Common !!! a very funny twist that was predictable. But the way they presented that twist to us was hilarious ! Believe me , don't watch this movie, it is literally overrated. If there was zero rating, then this movie deserves it !

This film is number one on the IMDb top 250. This is not the greatest film of all time but this is a film so impossible to hate. It is, as one reviewer wrote, the best film for the worst parts of your life. No film is even comparable to Shawshank when going strictly off of inspirational powers, Rocky is the only other answer that is stupid but its still wrong. I am mocked by my friends for my taste for the dark (taxi driver, once upon a time in America, in the bedroom and the war zone just to name a few favorites) but this film is the only film I have ever seen (again, maybe Rocky) that has ever made me proud to be human. This is truly the role that has defined Morgan Freeman's career (has he really played a different character since?) and the subtleties of Andy Dufresne are endless. He is a stoic character but one of the most likable, most believable and most beloved in film. It is a film built on the little things for much of its two and a half hours, and there are so many beautiful little scenes. We learn to love these characters, when the are dragged through the mud so are we, and when they triumph we are every bit as elated. The world is a nasty and ugly place that will beat you down if you let it, so don't let it. Andy never lost hope. 'Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies.' That is what makes the human race so exceptional, for better or worse, we have a hard time giving up. Slaves rarely killed themselves, Holocaust Jews rarely killed themselves, in the darkest of times we somehow find a reason to believe they will end. To give up on faith and hope is to give up on your humanity. Get busy livn' or get busy dying'. That's' goddamn right.

Direction,writing,cinematography everything about this movie is extraordinary....and what can we say about the actors...both tim robbin and morgan freeman delivered the best performances of their career...

There is a good reason why this movie is the highest rated film on IMDb. While watching this, I felt for the characters' pain and suffering, their happiness and cheers. The music and storytelling are amazing. Props to the director for turning this Stephen King story into a masterpiece.

Whis is quite simply one of the finest motion pictures ever made. The most surprising thing is that it comes from one of the most unlikely of sources, Stephen King. I have never been a fan of his horror work and doubt I ever will be but his serious side has proved to be quite excellent. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins were robbed by the Academy when this movie came out. They both deserved to win awards for these performances. Morgan Freeman that comes as no shock as he can elevate most anything from trash to gold so when you give him a good role it becomes practically transcendent.

Tim Robins was more of a surprise to me. I have seen him in a few movies but he never really left much of an impression on me. In this film though he provided one of the 90's best performances. The rest of the cast also filled out quite well. James Whitemore was heartbreaking in his role as the elderly librarian. This movie deserves its spot on at #2 on the IMDb top list and I would actually argue that it should bump The Godfather out as I think that movie is highly over-rated but then that's just me.

If you haven't seen this movie than I suggest that you go out and rent it now. Better yet just buy it as I doubt you will be disappointed. Cheers!

Great great movie! I wasnt expecting to be so good despite the reviews. It is so obvious prison break copied many ideas from this movie. But Forrest Gump for me is probably the best movie, no wonder it won oscar for best picture in 1994. Im quite sure this movie could had won one oscar for best picture if it was released in another year.

This beautiful movie speaks about hope, about doing your best even when luck turns against you, about humanity, with his lights and shadows, it's about friendship, about cowardice, about the miseries and corruption of the evil... In essence, it's a movie about virtue and vices, staged on a prison. It's this kind of movies that despite being long, they keep interest and seem short. A piece of art.

The chief, Frank Darabont, paints the jail in dreary grays and shadows so that when key occasions do happen, they appear to have a unique kind of energy.

Andy, as played by Robbins, remains quiet about his viewpoints. Red, as Freeman plays him, is hence a significant component in the story: His nearby perception of this man, as the years progressed, gives the manner in which we screen changes and track the proportion of his impact on everyone around him. And all the time there is something different occurring, covered up and secret, which is uncovered exclusively toward the end.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is definitely not a discouraging story, in spite of the fact that I might have made it sound that way. There is a great deal of life and humor in it, and warmth in the kinship that develops between Andy and Red. There is even fervor and tension, albeit not when we anticipate it. Yet, for the most part, the film is a moral story about clutching a feeling of individual worth, notwithstanding everything. In the event that the film is maybe a little delayed in its center entries, perhaps that is important for the thought, as well, to provide us with a feeling of the heavy entry of time, before the greatness of the last recovery.
Remember Red, hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies.
A timeless script and acting. The masterpiece that thrives the cinema into a new era.

Exciting story, cool story, my family loves it all. We watched it several times. Really this is a highlight, the excitement in the movie passes us. Differential that marked the film, and brought a unique characteristic. Its direction, its actors, its actresses, really marks generations, and will pass through generation to generation.

I was a teenager when I rented that movie after a friend insisted in me watching that "you're gonna love it, I guarantee that" he said to me.

I have always seen Stephen King's job contemptuosly, I think his books are cheap, so I took it home just because he insisted.

Oh my God... it is a masterpiece. I won't say anything new, everybody has already said everything about how amazing this movie is. I own it on VHS in Spanish and English and I have it on DVD now. I think I bought pretty much a dozen of copies to give to my friends.

This movie absolutely changed a part of me in a very good way.

BTW, it just so happens that Stephen King's books result in very good movies... go figure!
So this was quite a film, quite an experience I'll say; this movie told me to do my absolute best and I guess that's all there is to it. (I don't really know why other people like it but I like it)

If you want to make a great film, follow the example of Frank Darabont. Every element is beautiful here. No More Any Words! Make sure of this yourself, and you will see all the amazing work done by the entire crew!

9.4 out of 10
One of the best jail/prison movies ever created. This movie changed my life.
Got me right in the feels. Was speechless after watching, so breathtaking in every way
Its a must watch move in a life time... my friend recommend me this movie and when i saw... i m speechless. Must watch..! every one have to see this once in your life time

Absolutely incredible. It truly is sad that this movie did not win best picture because it is one of the finest ever made. Morgan Freeman at his best and Tim Robbins is perfect. This movie sucks you in and never lets you go. A movie you can watch over and over.
Ur Mind Goona Sucks You Can't Believe What happened to You

I first saw it in 2016 and since then this movie has become an important part of my life. It teaches multiple theories of how to be a strong figure doesn't matter how worst our life has become. I highly recommend you this movie.this movie will always stay closer to my heart..
Too overrated. The only thing going on is: he tried to escape prison. And then what?

The first time I saw Shawshank, I loved it and didn't want it to end. I remember that desire being surprisingly powerful, despite understanding that I had enjoyed it as much as I did while watching it. Its power surprised me because I didn't understand fully how or why I felt the way I did. On subsequent viewings, I prepared myself for the ending, for THAT feeling, which I began to examine.

I would describe it as something on par with the end of a relationship, if not perfectly in scale, then certainly in context. A good relationship. One that ends too early, but does so because it must, because that is just how it is sometimes. I am always struck with a deep yearning to see more, to know and feel more, but also a comfort. That even though I didn't get everything I wanted, what I got is a damn sight good enough, and I should be grateful for that. But it aches, too. And then you realize that it's over, and you're going to wake up tomorrow, and start living your life again. But now you'll live having gone through this, with this perspective, this story in your memory.

It's small, not actually the same experience, but it's close. The same shape and color. No other film, no story, gives me this feeling. And just like in relationships, sometimes I end up watching nothing but disappointing titles, I have a moment when I ask myself why I do it. That maybe I'm wasting my time. And then I remember. And then I hope.

The Shawshank Redemption is without a doubt the greatest film that had ever been made I have viewed it multiple times over the years and it never gets old. It is the story of a man imprisoned for a crime he did not commit, and then he must try with all he can to escape from there. It is a story we've seen or heard a thousand times. It is nothing new. And that is the beauty of it. We think we're here to see the same old story yet again, however, it will shock and surprise you as it unfolds. It is a story of brotherhood behind bars, of an unlikely friendship that last a lifetime, and, of redemption.

The best movie I've ever seen. I've seen her more than twenty times and it's always perfect. On the 10th year anniversary DVD edition Frank Darabont claims that the movie has helped people through divorces and losing love ones and so on, just see the movie and you'll understand why.

The scene were Andy Dufresne finally gets out of Shawshank and he's standing in the rain and raising his hands is one of the better scenes in the movie history. I've got that poster up on my wall. It's amazing how you feel brightened when you see that particular scene.

Try seeing the movie a couple of times, and then reading the book which is written by Steven King, and then seeing the movie again. It pushes the movie up to another level and you'll like it more thereafter.

Such a gripping story -- innocent people do get locked up, 'ya know -- and it's so very sad... I loved the end of the movie. Very realistic, I'm afraid -- I pray it makes criminals think twice before thinking that prison is tolerable - and I wish our criminal justice system would wake up and make some corrections. People need rehabilitation, not torture.

This was a good prison movie, although I have never really seen that many, besides Cool Hand Luke. I guess I like this movie better than Cool Hand Luke, because this is made around the time I was in high school.

Anyways, I rented this movie last weekend when I went home. I saw it earlier on TNT, but like always it was edited. I like the story about a man sentenced to 2 life sentences and the friends he makes in prison, especially Morgan Freeman who is a wonderful actor! It starts in the year 1947, until Robbins busts out of prison. Coincidentally, Freeman gets out just after Robbins breaks out. Not that this really matters, but wouldn't all of these guys look much older after twenty years? I mean I look older than I did when I was in early high school, and that was only 5 years ago! These guys didn't show any external signs of aging from the beginning of the movie until the end, which was a period of 20 years. Also, wouldn't the guard, you know the real S.O.B. Hadley have been forced to retire? He looked to be in his 30's when Robbins arrived at Shawshank in 1947, but you think that when the show arrived into the 1950's he would have been forced to retire. But, I enjoyed all of the characters.

I don't know if I would say this was the best #1 movie of all time. You have to consider Jaws, Psycho, Star Wars, Raiders Of The Lost Ark, etc. But this movie could be considered a classic, but it's hard to say which movie is more of a classic than another one was. I would definitely rate this movie as a classic.

But, if you want a good prison movie to watch, I would recommend this if it isn't checked out. If this classic prison movie is checked out, then I would get Cool Hand Luke.

I'm afraid that I must join the chorus of those that question the placement of this movie at the top of the rankings. Although I enjoy the movie a great deal, it is mainly because of the superb job done by the actors, especially the leads. Without that, I don't think the movie would have amounted to much, because the plot is relatively thin; wide swaths could have been cut from the film and no one would have noticed. Take the library Andy built. It did not advance the basic plot at all, as with other scenes. You could argue that it was precisely these small events that made the film good, and I would agree. But that's my point:there wasn't really anything tying the movie together other than our sympathy for the characters. While well developed characters are a central part of any good movie, there should still be something driving the action other than our sympathy for them; i.e. some sort of chain of events that drives the action independently of the characters. To everyone who thinks this is the best movie ever, I invite you to watch a couple films from the top 5 of the AFI list. You can argue about the AFI's placement all day, but all of the top 5 are better rounded films than Shawshank. If you still feel Shawshank is better than the rest, more power to you.

...movie and like another of my favorites, "Fried Green Tomatoes," one that I could see over and over again and still find something new to appreciate. This is a jewel of a movie and one that I'm sorry didn't receive the recognition it so richly deserved. James Whitmore should at least have been nominated for Best Supporting Actor; that he didn't is a disgrace. Morgan Freeman gives his usual awesome performance. Rent this movie! Then a few months later, rent it again. This movie is so poignant and says so much about friendship and hope that I defy anyone not to be moved by it.
Truly deserves the top rated movie. Definitely Must watch

I'm kind of lost for words for this movie. I saw it last night on my DVD-player and what I saw was brilliance. The story is about a banker Andy (Tim Robbins) who get prisoned for murdering his wife and her secret lover. In prison he says he's innocent, which makes the other inmates break out in laughter. No one is innocent in prison they say. `They've all been f***ed by lawyers.' What follows is a fight for justice. A inmate (George Freeman) who calls himself Red (the other inmates call him that because he's `irish') finds something special in Andy. They connect soon and becomes good friends. What strikes me about the main characters is that hope and belief is something that they always have. Even though they go through some very tough times in prison, they always have that good confidence in themselves. Go see this movie, if you love the concept of feeling free. There's no let downs or grief ending this movie. You have to see it for yourself.

Tim forehead robbins does a classic job as a hot shot banker who was wrongfully accused. in this crusade robbins and "Red" morg freeman become good buds and with william sadlers upraving comedic factor the movie simply goes down as one of the greatest philms of all time. frank darabonts finest film and bub gunton plays a great role as the warden.

The Shawshank Redemption is a movie that many people can relate to, especially if you had to overcome an unexpected experience that left you institutionalized and scarred. People are not institutionalized only in prisons and hospitals, but in schools, colleges, broken families, society, and other organizations. Trying to liberate ourselves from our conservative past or beliefs is not an easy process.

The Shawshank Redemption is one movie that can help start that process. It's a movie that can be watched repeatedly and after each time, even the most savvy critic may be enlightened by the depth and development of the characters, the smooth yet scintillating story line, the reoccuring symbolic themes, the uninhibited realism, the scenes and music ranging from the cold gothic prison architecture to the oak tree from a Robert Frost poem, and many uninvited personal insights we hold dearly and secretly to ourselves. Watching the movie over and over again is similar to a religious baptism where your past sins and crimes are washed away by the never-ending hope that you'll be free to achieve your highest dreams. I'm not going to reiterate the plot, dialogue, and other highlights of the film. The movie speaks for itself.

The plethora of movies in this time makes it difficult to dig and find the very few movies that exuberate the same effect as the Shawshank Redemption. The purpose of these reviews (also under Leonardo (24601-6) and Leonardo) is to express my tastes and to invite anyone with similar opinions to recommend movies on the same caliber.

It is my all-time personal favorite movie--the only one I would give a 10/10.

This is by far and away the best movie I have ever seen. If you haven't seen it, do so. (If you don't know the movies outcome, definately see it!).

Everything about this movie is outstanding. What most people notice first about great movies is the fine acting. Not only is this film's acting superb, but the script, the costumes, the scenery, the directing...everything...just outstanding. Rent it for the first time...rent it again...I recently sat through TNT's double presentation, and it still had me totally absorbed, even the second time around.

As stated in the tagline, this is a film of hope. The difficult question is however, is whom does it refer to? The two lead characters (Andy Dufresne and 'Red' Redding, played superbly by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman respectively) are both inmates at Shawshank penitentiary, one innocent and the other guilty. This however, does not mar your opinion of either character - you are able to sympathise with both of them, as you are with many of the prisoners. You root for these criminals every inch of the way, despite their wayward past and current situations. This is perhaps the ultimate feelgood movie, with the greatest twist since Kevin Spacey walked away in The Usual Suspects. Unlike other films of this genre however, there is no need for constant assurance that this will make you feel good - bar one or two moments in the middle, there is no hint that anything positive will happen to either hero, right up until that moment.

The greatest factor in this movie must be the characterisation. Prison guards turn from monsters, to friends to cowards; prisoners range from the horrific, to cruel, to pitiful and finally to likable. Above all, unlike too many recent films, each and every character is human and believable.

Is there an answer to that question? Which character has the lead - the narrating Red or the centrepiece Andy? Who has the hope? The answer to that lies in the interpretation of a film that can mean anything.

In one word: Magnificent! This movie is a masterpiece! It soaks you up and it leaves you behind feeling hopeful for ways which at first didn't seem to be there.. a really fantastic movie you definitely should see! Morgan Freeman, once again, showing how much of a big actor he is! *thumbsup to the cast & crew*

There are some very special movies out there. There are those which are highly thought-provoking and leave you questioning things. There are those which are a mindless blast and great fun to boot. And then there are those which are simply sublime. They might keep it simple, but they execute in such a way that they drag you in deep and have you caring about the characters. The Shawshank Redemption is one such film. This is a absolutely outstanding story which is as simple as it is eloquent.

It's about a man wrongly imprisoned for the murder of his wife and sentenced to life at Shawshank. There he slowly finds friends and the drama of their lives is the focus of the story. He promises many times that he *will* break out within 20 years, and no one, of course, believes him. It's this hope which drives the whole movie. Men in prison have nothing but hope. Take that away and they have nothing. And that's what Andy (The main character) wants to avoid.

The ending to this is simply breathtaking in its simplicity, but incredibly heartwarming and will have you punching the air in delight.

Nominated for 4 oscars, this won none of them. Utter travesty.

A magnificent story.

Some movies really need more than 2 hours to develop their story. I think "The Shawshank Redemption" would have been more successful if it was not so long. The story is truly excellent...moving, intense, and joyous at the same time. I think it could have been improved by editing out a few scenes which were redundant to the purpose of the mood they were establishing.

Every so often, I feel cinematic achievement reaches a new zenith...a point where I feel (albeit erroneously) that the bar of accomplishment can rise no more. Yet, as said, I am eventually mistaken, mainly due to remarkable stories of profound creative intensity. These are the creations that highlight vital essences of life and society.

The Shawshank Redemption is truly an element of such a category.

The Stephen King novella, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption, is a relatively brief tale, a section of a larger book called 4 Seasons. Still, it is brilliantly adapted as a feature-length motion picture, with no flaws or injustices therein.

If you are wondering why it is such a good movie, then you only need to think about one word: freedom. Think about what it means, and how easy may be to take for granted in today's liberated world. Set in the hardened American past, The Shawshank Redemption teaches us a valuable lesson about the fickle nature of sovereignty, and the inevitable boundaries that restrict us along the path of life. Still, despite the misery of indeterminate and forceful detainment, a love of life is found.

As such, this film presents a quest like no other. The characters seek to transcend their enslavement in a vile microcosm of dubious honesty and ill will, cherishing the subtle scents of freedom that waft through the senses on a very limited basis. After seeing this film, you'll never look at a bottle of beer or an opera record the same way: when you have nothing else, such frivolities are your only ties to freedom. Still, the intelligent social analysis does not end at this basic level. Rather, it continues by showing the affects of being reintroduced to reality, and the ensuing overdose of true liberty...

Nevertheless, as clear-cut as the overall theme may seem, a mark of cunning snakes through it...fervent...unexpected...

The result will knock you out of your seat. See for yourself. 10/10

I suppose I can't call it the single best film ever, but I really like it. I must admit I don't understand the people who call it too sappy. I'm usually pretty observant about sap, but I find this film truly touching. Well-written, well-filmed, well-acted, it is very moving from beginning to end. Some necessary changes were made from the original novella, such as making it one warden instead of several, changing over time.

The warden, in my opinion, is one of the rare well-made bad guys. You don't like him at all, but he still has human motivations, not super-evil, over-the-top unbelievable qualities. Of course, Red and Andy are both well-crafted characters.

It's a fine, understated film. I think it's one of the best films of the past several years. Good music, too.

One more thing: I saw somewhere the complaint that no one seems to age, though the movie spans several years. While the aging process isn't given the full focus of the film, it's clearly there. I don't think that's a valid complaint. My two cents are now used up.

I've read a lot of the comments here. I've never voted for this movie once, but now I'm going to give it what it deserves. And I am going to try to describe why a lot of Shawshank fans are voting this the best movie ever.

The reasons that this movie is great are: it has incredible acting, incredible story-telling, incredible pace, incredible writing and dialogue, incredible imagery, and an incredible twist and ending.

The Godfather also has these qualities.

But the reason Shawshank is better is because it literally is potentially life-changing. People watch Shawshank and someone truly may believe in HOPE. They may truly believe their lives will get better. They may truly believe others' lives can be made better. Its message is not only told, but it is FELT and oft times ABSORBED. For men, for women, for old, for young, for everyone. It is a masterpiece. What other movie affects people in this way? You don't get that with The Godfather. GF is a great film, but you just come out of it saying, "Wow, that was one of the best films I've ever seen." With Shawshank, you say more than that. You feel more than that.

You will never see another like it. And the mere perfection of this movie, by a novice director, will frustrate experienced and future directors forever.

I actually watched last year's 'The Green Mile' before I got round to seeing this. And in many respects I'm glad. This film is better constructed, has a far more powerful script, and, most tellingly, a far more belivable story (the Green Mile dabbles in the supernatural and improbable). What makes this movie so good is that it really deals with the psyche and emotions of humanity, and isn't scared to go into detail with these emotions, even if it means that the plot is sidetracked for a few minutes. The male bonding throughout the film is touching, and (although sentimental) completely believable. The twist, although not quite as surprising as the 'Usual Suspects', adds a little bit extra to a plot that before was pretty much at the mercy of Morgan Freeman's narrative, which, while well delivered, all gets a bit similar after a while. I think the biggest achievement here is, apart from the bread and butter stuff like 'solid acting', 'sensitive direction', and 'breathtaking photography', is just how well the movie shows its time scale. The story is based over 20 years, charting the 'prison career' of an innocent man, and apart from the greying of Freeman's hair, it also features a lot of nostalgic conversations. Two tragedies among the group of friends that we watch also give a sense of perspective. At the centre though, are Freeman's brief meetings with the prison board, asking for a release every ten years. As he delivers the most moving part of the film- his third speech to this board, I guarantee you will be weeping buckets. The first movie I ever watched that meant so well as to be 'beyond criticism' was 'Schindler's List'. This is the second.

This is without a doubt one of my 5 favorite movies. Even now, a month after I first saw it I still think about it and repeat its maxim "Hope is a good thing." What can I say but that this is the beautiful made movie I have ever seen. This movie is the most uplifting movie I have ever seen and also one of the smartest in its ending. I had before seen the posters for the movie and thought that this was going to be another dumb movie but then TNT did me a favor and aired it on its "New Classics" program. Plus, IMBD and several articles exposed me to the newly found popularity of the movie and I was hooked. As I watched the movie, I knew that this would be one my new personal classics. Its moral, that hope is a good thing and its saying "get busy living or get busy dying, stil intrigue me. The movie is amazing in its beauty. No one could have played Andy better than Robbins and Morgan Freeman was superb in his portrayel of a great character. What can I say but that by the end of the movie you feel good inside. You feel hope, just what the character feels. The movie makes you feel what the character feels and that is one of its best qualities.

See the movie and be changed. It is definitely one of the best.

One of the best movies that i have ever seen.It truly transcends time and is an epic in all proportions.People just don't make movies like this anymore and this is one of my favorite movies of all time. The movie is About Andy Dufrane,a banker who has been wrongfully acquitted of killing his wife in cold blood and send to shaw shank prison.the movie shows the various hardships faced by Andy and how he does not give up hope and carries on with patience and finally becomes free. the climax is absolutely spellbinding and will leave you aghast.it is a truly great movie and i was aghast at finding out that this movie was a failure in the box office.BUT NOW ALMOST EVERYONE RECOGNIZES THIS MOVIE FOR WHAT IT TRULY IS - A MASTERPIECE OF STORYTELLING.

The movie has a beautiful evolution starting from how it all began to how it all ended. It shows the struggle of prisoners and how people can grow and change if there is a will. I would recommend this excellent movie to everyone.

It's fun to watch this movie a second time and pick up some things you never noticed the first time. So many things simply went unnoticed (Andy writing into the wall, his little geology tool, the "sex symbols throughout the decades" posters) and suddenly wind together to grab our attention and make this a wonderful movie. The film was fascinating in the fact that it showed us how "lifers" could only witness the change of culture in the outside world by observing the prisoners that come and go over the years, and this being the only glimpse on how the world is changing, they become institutionalized, and actually fear their freedom. I actually found myself feeling sorry for murderers, and I debated with myself on whether or not they should be released if they truly become rehabilitated. The determination and hope transpired by Andy brought our hopes up: Most movies bring our hopes up only to bring them down, but when we see him running through the pond and standing in the rain with his arms raised and the great music accompanying the scene, our hopes our fulfilled. This is one of only about three or four films that had great smarts and left me completely satisfied. 10/10.

The Shawshank Redemption is the type of film which has divided its audience into two categories: those who loved it, and those who don't care for it. There is rarely anything between. Flawless acting, passionate direction, and a memorable score have made the film a powerful cinematic experience, and at times, it can be thought provoking. It never lacks in pace, there is always a steady rhythm to the film. The Shawshank Redemption is a modern masterpiece.

Rating: 10

The Shawshank Redemption is the greatest film ever made. It is one of those few films where I wouldn't touch a frame, given the chance. It is absolutely flawless, as well as the most inspiring film ever made.

Steven King's novel is great, but what really gave life to this film is Frank Darabont's incredible direction. It becomes more hypnotic every time I see it. There is a point to every shot and angle, as well as everything that is said and done in the story. Everything is necessary to entertain or to inspire.

Citizen Kane may also be perfection, but it can't inspire the viewer and help them to connect with the characters. Citizen Kane is a great film, a top ten film, but it's nowhere close to this.

I recommend several viewings to anyone who has never seen The Shawshank Redemption. You will walk away a better person every time.

We feel it, it feels terrible, eternal even. All this is joined by Thomas Newman's fantastic score (my favorite of his) and one of the most memorable main themes ever made.

And best of all, it's one of the most fulfilling and hopeful films you can watch. It has truly become my favorite film. This movie is one of the best dramas that I have ever seen. The movie follows the life of a hot shot banker who is convicted for the murder of his wife and her lover. He proclaims throughout the movie that he is innocent however. As the movie progresses we see things inside this prison that we hope never really happens. There are incidents of brutality, graft, and even murder. The guards of the prison use the main character, Andy Dufresne, talent as a banker to do their tax returns and the warden uses him to make a fortune. Andy said it best when he said, "The funny thing is - on the outside, I was an honest man, straight as an arrow. I had to come to prison to be a crook." Everything was different inside the prison. This movie shows that no matter what the conditions are they can never completely break someone's spirit which is shown by this movie's happy ending.

Wow, this film touches a very deep and unmarked part of my soul that I never knew existed.

I feel my soul just flipping inside out and puckering throughout the struggles of the multitude of characters.

If art is supposed to reach out and touch you, then this by far is the pinnacle of the motion pictures.

Andy Dufresne is sentenced to two consecutive life terms in prison for the murders of his wife and her lover and is sentenced to a tough prison. However, only Andy knows he didn't commit the crimes. While there, he forms a friendship with Red , experiences brutality of prison life, adapts, helps the warden, etc., all in 19 years.

I enjoy this movie and have seen it multiple times. My only issue with the movie is that the character, Red (Morgan Freeman) is not accurate for the time period of the movie. I seriously doubt that Red because of his race would be such a leader of all inmates in the 1940's. And, the "go to" inmate for buying items? I doubt it. Some strong willed white inmate would have corned that market. He might have been a leader of the African Americans in the prison, but not the whites. Now before that starts some race debate about the topic, I only am pointing out how the times were in the 1940's, 50's, etc.

My issue with that topic is that I think we should accurately portray society as it was no matter how ugly it was, not as we wish it had been.

This is a film that is heavy on character and dialogue and delivers on both. The performances by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman are outstanding, as are each of the supporting actors. This film was adapted from a short story, 'Rita Hayworth and The Shawshank Redemption,' written by Stephen King. Perhaps it is because it's adapted from a short story as to why this works so well as there are only minor changes and nothing essential is left out, leaving the film makers with the ability to strengthen and stretch out the main focus, which is the bond created by the two main characters. In my personal opinion I would say this film is one of the most successful book to script adaptations in film history. The direction is brilliant in the way it is almost not noticeable as it relies on the actors and their interactions with each other to keep the audience interested. Cinematography is worth a mention also as each shot is captured beautifully. In summary, Shawshank is a must see and a well deserved film classic.
See it over and over again! Another one I watch every time it's on.
Frank Darabont did an execellent adaption, beutiful story showing the real live.

I was one of the many movie-goers who saw The Shawshank Redemption without being aware it was a Stephen King story, and so had the pleasure of seeing the movie without prior expectations.

The Shawshank Redemption is, without doubt, the finest conversion from book to film of a Stephen King story. Perhaps because 'Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption' (which can be found in the Different Seasons book) is short, and thus has less for the film makers to put on the screen.

Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins deliver faultless performances as a hardened criminal (Freeman) and a man pleading innocence (Robbins), and the supporting cast of criminals and guards does a brilliant job of creating a world full of repentent criminals, cruel wardens, and (without spoiling anything) 'less than friendly' cons.

What makes The Shawshank Redemption such a memorable movie is that it manages to create characters that the viewer loves, in a scenario and location where you'd never expect to find them. These characters, despite their faults, have you hoping for the best but fearing for the worst for the entirety of the movie. Fans of King will no doubt be familiar with the way he can create such characters, but the feat is rarely carried over onto the screen.

I like a movie that can stimulate emotion in me, and The Shawshank Redemption did that. There are things to laugh at, scenes to flinch away from (although nothing like American History X), and most importantly for the film, things that make you want to cry in a mixture of disbelief and shock.

A brilliant movie, and worthy of the Oscar nomination it got and probably should have won.

See if you liked: American History X, The Green Mile, Life is Beautiful. Strengths: Brilliant cast, excellent story-telling, King's usual attention to realism. Weaknesses: None. My Rating: 9.5 out of 10

It is very hard to think of something bad about this film.The direction is incredible, bringing about highly memorable performances, and a beautifully shot film.

Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman are sensational, carrying this film on their shoulders as if it were the easiest job in the world - a tribute to them as this film must have been an incredibly demanding shoot - it is a long and emotional film.

The development of their friendship is wonderful to watch, as is Andy's gradual assimilation into the prison society - however sad it may well be.

Frank Darabont it seems was the ideal man to take the helm of this movie. Many films in this sort of genre can feel like they are missing something, as if there were sections left on the editing room floor - not this film, everything fits perfectly in to place. This leads to a very long film, (which could perhaps be its only criticism - be warned it is long - though the longer the better for me) but one which sucks you right into the prison world, and keeps you right there until the utterly stunning last shot of the film!

Viewers should be warned that some scenes are of a disturbing nature, dealing with issues that may offend some people. However, this should not put you off seeing this film. It deals with the realities of prison, and in no way glorifies the goings on.

What we must realise however, is that this film is not necessarily about the brutality of prison and the way prison society operates, it is about human connection and interaction, and the indomitable nature of the human spirit. By the last scene we should feel uplifted at what has been achieved - not only by the characters in the story however, but by the film makers!

This film is deservedly number 3 on the top 250 list! Congratulations to all involved in making it! A must see for anyone! Sensational 10/10

I've been meaning to see this movie for several years now, having heard all the hype and comments rating this as one of the best films of all time. It certainly wasn't disappointing- despite the relatively slow pace compared to most brainless blockbusters of today and tendency towards sentimentality that crept up from time to time. It certainly wasn't one of the greatest of all films, in my opinion, either; simply an intriguing story, with something to teach us, perhaps, very well told and very well acted. It's probably a movie I'd watch again, though not straight away, as it is quite slow paced, and, just towards the end, I felt it was getting a little too drawn out. But it's very good to look at, there are some great performances, a nice musical score from Thomas Newman, and a great plot, with a wonderful twist at the end. So, overall this is a very good movie and one I would recommend.

8/10

A true transcendence of common ground between prisoner and inmate can be found within this movie. What makes a good person, does it really depend on which side of the bars you live that makes you a good person or bad person. This movie answers that inevitable question.

The Shawshank Redemption is a timeless classic that has consistently been ranked as one of the greatest movies of all time. The originality of the plot, well developed characters and engrossing story keeps you glued to your seat. Watching it for the first time, the initial slow pace of the movie may baffle you but it quickly transforms into a thrilling story that makes you wonder about how life can suddenly change. It was a new experience to learn about the North American prison system and the life within the walls of a correctional facility. While watching it for a second time I was engrossed by the subtle hints at every stage of the movie that built up to a spectacular ending. This is a story of injustice, friendship, bonding, struggle, patience, sorrow, happiness and ingenuity – a true emotional roller coaster that covers you with a generous splattering of brutal truth. It teaches us to never give up on life and the importance of a meticulous long term plan for success. The movie is set in a different time but even a new generation of film viewers can certainly relate to the universal concepts that have been so beautifully featured in this film.

Honestly, I have never heard of a movie that was so captivating and powerful to watch. The Shawshank Redemption stars Tim Robbins as a baker who is accused in murdering his wife but denies it. Morgan Freeman plays a man who has been in the Shawshank prison for many years and has given up on hope and is fighting to get out of prison by the parole hearings in the movie. Lastly, you have Bob Gunton from Ace Ventura When Nature Calls playing a warren that you would think to trust but is actually the opposite. I wont go further into describing the movie because it is very difficult to explain the whole premise and the characters. What I can say is that the plot is brilliantly paced and full of twists and turns and will keep you on the edge of your seat. I really appreciated the tone of this film having a grim, dark bleak side of Shawshank prison and the light uplifting colors outside of the prison. But, enough of the cinematography how was the acting? Without a doubt, the acting in this film was absolutely wonderful! Morgan Freeman does his voice-overs with a very poetic edge and makes the narration very entertaining. I really love Morgan Freeman's voice-overs since it shows his fantastic acting. Tim Robbins is very likable as a guy feeling that he has been framed and is dying to escape the prison. But, whats different from The Great Escape ,which is another prison escape movie, is that you don't know how he is going to escape. The way he does is absolute sheer genius! All the characters are very likable including the best supporting character in this movie that everyone can feel sympathy for. Brookes is an very complex character that I felt attached to when he left prison on parole. But, I wont spoil the rest of the movie because you must go see it for yourself! You will not be disappointed! This is one of Frank Durabont's masterpieces that would have never happened without the genius writer STEPHEN KING!!!

P.S. This movie has one of the if not the best ending I have ever seen since it touches your heart!
