Talk about your school of hard knocks. In The Shawshank Redemption (Columbia, R), Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a tall, soft-spoken New England banker, is convicted-wrong- ly-of killing his adulterous wife and her lover. It's 1947, and Andy, having received a double life sentence, is shipped off to Shawshank State Prison in Maine, a maximum-security fortress packed to the grimy gills with thieves, rapists, and murderers. How bad is life at Shawshank? So bad that when Andy trudges off the bus along with a dozen other new inmates, the veteran prisoners make wagers on who'll be the first to cry. So bad that Andy finds a huge, wriggly yellow maggot buried in his lunch. So bad that, over the next two years, he is systematically beaten and raped by the Sisters, a crew of leering renegade inmates who take special delight in tormenting their fellow prisoners. Make no mistake: Andy gets worked over-and so does the audience.

But then, good things have a way of happening to unfortunate movie characters. Early in his stay, Andy makes the acquaintance of Red (Morgan Freeman), a sly survivor who is serving a life sentence for murder and who acts as Shawshank's one-man black market, smuggling the prisoners anything they want-cigarettes, reefer, cards with naked ladies (''I'm a regular Sears and Roebuck,'' he deadpans). As soon as Andy bonds with Red, things start to ! look up. He gets hold of a rock hammer so that he can sculpt an elegant chess set. He does the guards' tax returns in exchange for perks like beer on a sunbaked afternoon. He expands the dusty, neglected book room into the most comprehensive prison library in New England. Set over a period of 20 years (the passing decades are marked by Andy's pinup posters of Rita Hayworth, then Marilyn, then Raquel), The Shawshank Redemption begins as a nightmare, a postwar- New England Midnight Express, but it doesn't take long to reveal its true, feel-good colors. The movie is about survival, triumph, and a thing called hope. It's about a hero who rises above the squalor because he's blessed-a saint in the muck. It's Midnight Express Goes Gump.

You need a certain craftsmanship to traffic in twin brands of manipulation- the exploitative and the sentimental-and there's no denying that Frank Darabont, who wrote and directed The Shawshank Redemption (it's based on a short novel by Stephen King), knows just what he's doing. The moss-dark, saturated images have a redolent sensuality; you feel as if you could reach out and touch the prison walls. And Darabont is an accomplished button pusher. He coaches the actors so that you always know exactly who to root for and against. When it comes to a character like the warden (Bob Gunton), all Bible- thumping righteousness, the movie has no compunction about turning up the hissability factor. He starts out mean, then turns meaner, then meaner still. When Andy blasts Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro over loudspeakers to the prison work field, it becomes a full-scale opera-soothes-the-savage-breast number, with the prisoners standing open-mouthed at the sublime sounds. The scene is meant to fire our righteous liberal hearts. It helps, of course, that most of the prisoners don't actually behave like criminals. They never say a word about their pasts-even Andy remains a downtrodden cipher-and this lends the proceedings a hollow, generic feel, as if Darabont had constructed a blueprint out of old prison melodramas.

A movie like The Shawshank Redemption, with its brazenly mechanical plotting and its wish-fulfillment finale, requires a lead actor who can carry us on the wings of his good spirits. Tim Robbins is crafty and likable when Andy is hoodwinking the guards, and he makes you feel the character's mute anguish. Yet in shouldering what is essentially a laconic- good-guy, neo-Gary Cooper role, Robbins never quite makes emotional contact with the audience. His face, foggy and placid, suggests an overgrown baby's; there's something naggingly unformed about him. Morgan Freeman, on the other hand, with his delicate smolder, his eyes that seem to peer directly into everyone's soul, makes Red feel genuine, lived-in. Speaking of the prison walls, he says, ''First you hate 'em. Then you get used to 'em.

After long enough, you get so you depend on 'em. That's institutionalized.'' With his gift for rapt pauses, for caressing just the right syllable, Freeman can make a speech like that sound like one of the philosophical nuggets of the ages. Then again, isn't it time Morgan Freeman stopped playing the soulful sidekick? While we're on the subject of prison walls, an actor as great as he is shouldn't get too used to movies like this one. B-

Mostly through Morgan Freeman's character, who narrates the film. His portrayal of his character is more than successfully satisfying. He nails it, as he always does. They build real characters who go through real changes, something people can relate to. I'm trying to not reveal any of the plot. The plot is not complex, or not overly complex I should say. It will be easy to follow as long as you start at the beginning. It's the way to movie presents it, the way it reveals itself to the audience is what makes it so brilliant. The plot turns are unexpected. I think that what makes this movie so great is that. The way it keeps you interested, keeps you unprepared. It truly makes you feel for the characters though they're inside a prison. It shows how fragile the situation is on the inside, for all of them.

Several exterior scenes were shot at the Malabar Farm State Park, in nearby Lucas, Ohio. The sequence in which Andy is parked outside his home contemplating murdering his wife was filmed at the Pugh Cabin within the park.

The Shawshank Redemption was filmed in and around the city of Mansfield, Ohio, located in north-central Ohio. The prison featured in the film is the old Ohio State Reformatory immediately north of down town Mansfield.

The sequences representing the village of Buxton and the field where Red finds Andy's hidden letter were filmed on private land located opposite the park entrance on Bromfield Road. The oak tree is clearly visible from the roadside. The adjacent rock wall, which was constructed specifically for the film, is located on the far side of the hill away from the roadside. The wall is still standing, although it has been somewhat eroded. Other scenes were shot in Ashland, Ohio, Butler, Ohio, Upper Sandusky, Ohio and Portland, Maine.

The two scenes in Mexico were filmed on the Island of St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The first scene where Andy was driving a convertible on a road along the Pacific Coast with the top down is route 73 on the north side of St. Croix between Salt River (where Christopher Columbus landed in 1493) and Cane Bay.

The second scene was the last scene of the movie. Red was walking on a beach toward his friend Andy while he worked on repairs to a boat on the beach. That was filmed at Sandy Point National Wildlife Refuge on the south west point of St.Croix.

What can I say? What is there left to say?

The story begins with the trial of a young banker, Andy Dufrense, victimized by circumstantial evidence, resulting in a conviction for the murder of his wife and her lover. After a quick conviction, Andy finds himself serving a life sentence at Shawshank prison, with no hope of parole. He exists in this prison only in appearance, keeping his mind free from the drab walls around him. His ability to do this results in the gaining of respect from his fellow inmates, but most of all from Ellis Redding.

Andy escapes in the end by digging a hole through the wall, morgan freeman is let free after serving 40 years in prison.

Ellis, commonly referred to as Red, finds gainful use of his entrepreneurial spirit within the drab walls of Shawshank by dealing in contraband and commodities rare to the confines of prison. Andy's demeanor and undeniable sense of hope causes Red to take a deeper look at himself, and the world around him. Andy proves to Red and the other inmates that in the conventional walls of Shawshank prison convention will find no home in his lifestyle.
This film will go down in history as one of the greats!!!

Timeless classic and doesn't have to brag itself to be known as the most riveting drama of all time, a brilliant main role combination of Freeman and Robbins, exceptionally finished. I think It was a very good movie because the story was very catching, and the film was very exciting because I got him very passionate continue to watch from beginning to end. The film, in my opinion deserve a 10/10. It's an excellent movie, it's a movie you must see. It's an engagingly simple, good-hearted film, with just enough darkness around the edges to give contrast and relief to its glowingly benign view of human nature. Morgan Freeman, who is simply a great actor, a man who has never struck a false note in his career, both narrates this tale and anchors it with his authoritative playing.

Most people who see this movie for the first time are not going to appreciate it completely. This is maybe the only movie, in my opinion, that keeps getting better the more times I watch it. Having seen the movie at least 20 times I feel that it is quite possibly the best movie ever made. Some may be more entertaining, like say Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, but none as compelling. The movie creates a world of different emotions, mainly through its two main characters, Red and Andy. The acting is incredible. The message is stronger than that of most any movie, and is stated very clearly. "Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies." After being drained by the sad events that occur in the movie, the ending uplifts, and thoroughly fulfills the gaps that it could leave you with.

Although this is a great and uplifting movie I realize that are a few things wrong with it, like in any movie. The issue of race is not addressed because it wasn't originally meant to. In Stephen King's short story, Red is white. In casting Morgan Freeman the movie is left a little empty on that subject. This does not devalue it, but does leave the audience a little confused about why it is not addressed. Do not watch this movie and expect to be completely entertained, just watch it for its quality, and maybe you'll be left with as much thought-provoking material as I was. I am glad it is ranked as high as it is, which shows that does get through to most people, but I think it should move two spaces up on the list.

a best film of WB company "The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time,

patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps,

but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story,

which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair. The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

This masterpiece, directed by Frank Darabout, explores two men seeking redemption as they dream of freedom in Shawshank prison. Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted for the murder of his wife and her lover; he also befriends a convict named Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman) as he eventually gains the respect of the other inmates. Roger Deakins' cinematography has the ability to capture Andy's sense of determination and optimism in Shawshank prison. This unforgettable drama deeply explores the essence of hope as the audience learns that "some birds are not meant to be caged; their feathers are just too bright."

This is a good movie, but I'm surprised to see that it's got the #1 spot on IMDb's top movie list. The acting is excellent, and it has a great message; however, it's lacking a big "wow" moment for me. A lot of things that happened weren't necessarily "predictable", but I also wasn't shocked either. Still, it's a good movie that everyone should see.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

"The Shawshank Redemption" or "Shawshank" as I'm sure it's said to death in the film is an elongated short story that just 'lingers' from one hour to the next. There's no real 'charm' to the film except of course 'dry wit' from Red as if it's the gospel according to Red. He basically plugs Andy the entire movie as if he's his agent. "Now Andy this" and "Andy that". Not to mention a walking brochure for penitentiaries "Shawshank this" and "Shawhank that" his gospel just never lets up.

Now Tim Robbins was perfectly cast for about 5 minutes playing 'the babe in the woods' who "looks like a stiff breeze would blow him over" a "tall drink of water with a silver spoon up his ass". But once nothing seems to break him, its definitely a part for Mel Gibson. Tim Robbins didn't have the 'acting chops' to bring the 'required depth' to this character. Fortunate for Robbins in post production Morgan Freeman saved his ass with extensive voice overs. Most people think this was premeditated but 'the truth' is Robbins gave such a wooden performance it was necessary.

Most people think this isn't your average prison drama ether because its not about violence and melodrama. But 'the truth' is this film is no better than your TV movie of the week that features a 'prison escape'. The whole 'poster thing' couldn't be more 'implausible' if an elephant hang from a cliff by a daisy. Don't let me get started on how he just happened to have the cell on the end ether! The music was 'elevator music' at best. The only time I even took notice was when they actually featured it in the plot And even then if I'd heard it id have personally punctured my eardrums. Why the 'sound' was nominated for an academy award is beyond me. If it weren't for packaging and distribution this film would be a made for TV movie. Which it was if you consider its box office taking against home rental.

The entire cast reeked 'cartoon'. You have your 'evil' warden with his 'religion'. You have your 'mean' guards you 'grow to love'. Not to mention 'the kid', 'the old guy', 'the black guy' and 'the guys'. The prison was so stereotypical it even had 'fags'. Some other failings of this 'pathetic' movie. The dialog was 'harebrained'. If it was supposed to fascinate, well, it 'failed'. The manner in which the mini stories unfolded was 'not stimulating'. His ability to get beers and do taxes in particular 'sucked'.

In short this film 'sucked'. Worst film 'since', well since ever!

This movie was easily the best one based on a Stephen King and Frank Darabont screenplay. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman act very well together as best friends who find a way to deal with their difficult circumstances. Morgan Freeman's name in the movie is Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding. He is a person who can get you things, for a profit. Tim Robbins' name in the movie is Andrew Dufresne. He is someone accused of killing his wife. Andy asks Red to get him such items as a small rock hammer and posters of famous starlets. Red is someone disillusioned by the racist prison system, and serves as the main narrator for the film. This places the audience deeply inside the minds of the protagonists and even of the villains. I thought that Frank Darabont's directing was excellent. While close to three hours, it is time well spent as the movie is well written, well cast, and well directed. A solid 10/10 and recommended purchase.

This movie is not your ordinary Hollywood flick. It has a great and deep message. This movie has a foundation and just kept on being built on from their and that foundation is hope.

Other than just the message of this movie the acting was phenomenal. Tim Robbins gave one of the greatest performances ever. He was inspiring, intelligent and most of all positive. His performance just made me smile. Robbins plays Andy Dufresne who was wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is gets to life sentences but yet never gives up hope. In he becomes friends with Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding played by Morgan Freeman. Freeman who gives the finest performance of his career has unlike Robbins lost hope. He is in deep regret of the crime that he committed. His way of deflecting the pain away is by trying to not feel anything at all. With his friendship with Andy he learns that without our hopes and dreams we have nothing. Andy also becomes friends with the rest of Red's group. James Whitmore also gave a great performance as Brooks Halten who gets out of prison parole but in the words of Red he has been "institutionalized".

The directing by Frank Darabont was just magnificent. He kept this movie at a great steady pace along with the writing and great cinematography. He portrayed prison life in such a horrifying way, but not in terms of the physical pain but the stress and pain that wares mentally on the inmates, some of which deserve a second chance.

Whatever you do, don't listen to the people who say this movie is overrated because this is one of the most inspiring and greatest movies ever. It has everything you could possibly want.

I say almost because the third act loses pace a little bit but the opening two acts are superb and the final act is one of the greatest endings of anything put to film.

Acting: completely flawless, Freeman is outstanding, but as are all the supporting cast, from Prison Governor to Warden to even the small parts of the film, everybody performed Tone: on point, mostly realistic (the lack of ageing from the characters supposed to be over 20 years can be forgiven because the film is so good, and it was the 90s where there wasn't CGI and budget available like there is nowadays) Direction and cinematography: lovely

In context, it deserves a 10 due to.all things considered: it wasn't a big budget movie, okay it had a budget but we're not talking hundreds of millions, so small details can be forgiven, but from the human element it's a wonderfully well-judged movie with heart, the film at no point becomes boring, beautifully directed and acted, an outstanding piece of cinema that will live forever.

It's no surprise that so many people love this film, it's not trying to be anything that it isn't, it isn't asking permission for anything, it does what it does with complete integrity. No special effects, just a human story which everybody can relate to. 10/10.

I'd be lying to you if I told you that when Andy brakes out of his cell and crawls to freedom, I wasn't just as happy as the masses of people that call this their all time favorite move. And to say that I wasn't riveted when he is locked i the office and turns up the music while being threatened by the guards would also be untrue. But at the same time, this movie is most certainly not the second best film ever because of one simple reason: It can't decide if it wants to be real with occasional hints of hope or imaginative and dreamy. It drags you along for two hours of hard depressing facts and victory only in the most modest portions, then, for whatever reason, has a Hollywood ending of him digging through the wall then picking up the bank account that there's no way in hell that he'd be able to get in real life. This is great entertainment and I give it a ton of credit for having the ability to maintain my attention the whole time. But at the same time, the ending proved a little disappointing because it betrayed everything that this movie was trying to be.

This is the best film of all time. Where do I even begin? The foreshadowing, the charm, Morgan Freeman, the emotion, the characters, Morgan Freeman. the music, the rewatchability, did I mention Morgan Freeman?

There's a reason why this film is ranked #1 of all time on IMDb. I don't want to waste any more time. Just watch it!

The Shawshank Redemption redefines what a cinematic experience can be. Delivered with humility, honesty, and powerful performances, it weaves a captivating tale about freedom and hope that leaves an indelible mark on the hearts of viewers. Released in 1994, it may not have lit the box office on fire, but its flame continues to burn in the heart of cinema lovers.

The movie, adapted from Stephen King's novella "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption", pulls you into the bleak walls of Shawshank State Penitentiary. It follows the story of a banker, Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, who is wrongfully accused of murdering his wife and her lover, and receives a double life sentence. As he navigates the brutal reality of prison life, his friendship with Ellis 'Red' Redding, a long-term inmate, portrayed by Morgan Freeman, takes center stage. This friendship and their shared dreams of freedom form the crux of the plot.

The movie presents an array of brilliantly portrayed characters and themes, with each element skillfully contributing to the story's overall grandeur. Andy's unwavering hope and resilience against the brutal backdrop of Shawshank and Red's skepticism, which slowly transforms into belief, create a perfect on-screen balance. A curious trivia: The role of Tommy Williams, eloquently brought to life by the young Gil Bellows, was initially offered to Brad Pitt. He, however, had to turn it down due to scheduling conflicts.

The Shawshank Redemption showcases cinematic storytelling at its finest. Director Frank Darabont uses the camera to immerse us fully into the harsh environment of the prison, while Thomas Newman's score brings a distinctively emotive layer to the narrative. Not to mention, the film is interspersed with witty dialogues and philosophical insights, that further enrich the viewing experience. The famous dialogue, "Get busy living, or get busy dying", remains one of the most quoted lines in movie history.

On the critical front, The Shawshank Redemption does not falter. Its depiction of prison life is unflinchingly real yet avoids excessive pessimism. The plot does not rush but allows the characters and their relationships to evolve naturally. While some may argue that the movie's ending is overly optimistic, others would say that it perfectly encapsulates the film's prevailing theme of hope and redemption. An interesting note: while the movie ends on a different note from the novella, Stephen King has publicly stated that he prefers the film's ending.

In conclusion, The Shawshank Redemption is more than a movie; it's an experience, a life lesson wrapped in the garb of a prison drama. It delivers a powerful message about friendship, hope, and perseverance that resonates long after the end credits roll. Watching Andy and Red carve their path towards redemption is like witnessing a silent rebellion against fate. Despite being set within the confines of a grim penitentiary, it leaves you with an unconfined sense of freedom and an urge to embrace life with renewed vigor. As Red states in the movie, "Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies". Indeed, The Shawshank Redemption is one such good thing, a cinematic masterpiece, that refuses to fade away.

Its one of the most iconic films ever made. Thomas Newman as well, did great in composing the score for the movie.

The Shawshank Redemption is one of those films that the majority of people will love, and yet, it can be hard to pinpoint one particular reason why. The performances are stellar, in fact it's hard to think of any particular cast member who lets the team down, but that's not it. The set design is suitably bleak, the dialogue is just the right balance of realism and poetry, and we once again get to hear the dulcet tones of Morgan Freeman's narration, but again, these are not what make the film great.

Everything comes together with Shawshank, creating an instant and intense atmosphere that can be gritty, distressing, and at the same time, hopeful, humorous and beautiful. This film portrays the character's life and experience with frank honesty, with the undeniable quality of the production only serving to support this incredible story. Even the score is impressive, adding tension even when you don't even notice it's there.

The only reason I don't give this film a ten is because it is not usually a genre that I love, and although this film is definitely an exception, I cannot say it is outright perfect. But it's damn near close!

We're now in 2020 and I still consider this movie one of the best I have ever seen. I watch it every couple of years or so and it always amazes me. I can now say it's an excellent classic. Pretty much every review here says it all. Brilliant I'm every level.

Anyone who has ever read any Stephen King knows that a good 98% of the time the movie is never as good as the book. Usually the movie loses so much of the characters from the books. I actually didn't read the story the movie is based on (Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption)until years after seeing the movie a few hundred times. That's why, when I read it for the first time I was very surprised to find myself saying "wow, the movie actually followed the book!!" to the point that, in an odd coincidence, the movie was on AMC when I was in the last few pages of the story and I held off onreading the last part, Reds talk about Hope, until it came up in the movie. And, as I was reading, even though the book told us Red was in fact a white, red headed Irish man, I heard Mr. Freeman telling me the whole story as I read it.

I believe that this film is the best story ever told on film, and I'm about to tell you why.

Tim Robbins plays Andy Dufresne, a city banker, wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is sent to Shawshank Prison in 1947 and receives a double life sentence for the crime. Andy forms an unlikely friendship with "Red" (Morgan Freeman), the man who knows how to get things. Andy faces many trials in prison, but forms an alliance with the wardens because he is able to use his banking experience to help the corrupt officials amass personal fortunes. The story unfolds....

I was so impressed with how every single subplot was given a great deal of respect and attention from the director. The acting was world- class. I have never seen Tim Robbins act as well since, Morgan Freeman maybe (e.g. Seven). The twists were unexpected, an although this film had a familiar feel, it wasn't even slightly pretentious or clichéd, it was original. The cinematography was grand and expressive. It gave a real impression of the sheer magnitude of this daunting prison.

But the one thing which makes THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION stand above all other films, is the attention given to the story. The film depends on the story and the way in which it unravels. It's a powerful, poignant, thought-provoking, challenging film like no other. If Andy were to comment on this film, I think he might say: "Get busy watching, or get busy dying." Take his advice.

Based on Stephen kings 'Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption' this movie is a modern masterpiece that I could not recommend more, upon watching it just once it has instantly become one of my favourites. Characters such as Brooks, an old man who looks after a wounded bird within the prison, truly shine and their individual stories leave you feeling as they feel. Closest thing to cinematic perfection and story telling that I have come across.

Its interesting to read the comments on this movie. I don't think any film has polarized users as much as this one has. Almost 53% gave it a 10! 10 is perfection in cinematography, acting, screenplay etc. This movie is not perfect. Granted it tells a heartwarming story and is entertaining enough, so I charitably gave it an 8 and I think that's fair. Is this movie the second best of all time? NOT! I think 53% of the voters have been blinded by the redemption scene and the twist at the end, sure it was neat but check your warm n' fuzzies folks. Other movies that are overrated at IMDb because of a neat twist at the end are The Usual Suspects and The Sixth Sense. A twist does not make it Perfect.

The amount of time that has past since I last saw a movie as interesting and faithful to the making of film has been more than I can remember. After that extensive wait, my thirst for a film as engrossing as The Shawshank Redemption grew to the point where it did not even register anymore. This film though, has broken the wall of disinterest I've held for cheesy, hi-tech, flashy cute flicks that have littered the cinemas as of late. The character development, cinematography, and script for The Shawshank Redemption shine through the bleak cloud that I see surrounding Hollywood these days, as it concerns itself with special effects and big name actors bent on budgets and wages. A rental that I so wish I had seen in the theaters five years ago, the camera work and display from Freeman and Robbins is a relief to view, and eye-opening connection to movies that is so rare. It's one film that tugs at all your emotional strings, and even plucks at the brain a little.

After being slightly dissappointed by "The Green Mile", I decided to check out Frank Darabont's first adaptation of a Steven King prison story once again. "The Shawshank Redemption" remained as much of an enjoyably original modern classic after this second viewing. In this second viewing, I appreciated even more the sparklingly sharp dialogue between Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. Like in "Green Mile", Darabont set the scene of a depression-era prison extremely well. The director was also well-served to use King's vivid character descriptions to make the supporting characters as memorable as the leads. The result was an instant, uplifting classic about hope brought to the most hopeless locations.

There is not one thing I can complain about with this movie and you shouldn't either because it is just pure perfection in movie history. Many folk rate Shawshank Redemption as one of the best films they have ever seen. I'm not so impressed. Firstly, I agree that the absence of special effects is a boon in any 1990s film. Secondly, Freeman and Robbins act well and are well-directed. The storyline, though, lacks subtlety (not in the telling - this is a very well directed film - but as a story) and Dufesne comes over as a kind of everything-he-touches, incarcerated upper-middle class Forrest Gump. The film is suffused with a kind of Manichean morality which tips over too readily into sentimentality (again, despite the best efforts of Freeman and Robbins) and which, ultimately, I found cloying.

Perhaps, though, I'm being too harsh. Is it just that the film is a lot better than the story from which it is taken? Rita Hayworth: eat your heart out?

In 1947 Portland, Maine, banker Andy Dufresne is convicted of murdering his wife and her lover and is sentenced to two consecutive life sentences at the Shawshank State Penitentiary. He is befriended by Ellis "Red" Redding, an inmate and prison contraband smuggler serving a life sentence. Red procures a rock hammer and a large poster of Rita Hayworth for Andy. Assigned to work in the prison laundry, Andy is frequently sexually assaulted by "the Sisters" and their leader, Bogs.

In 1949, Andy overhears the captain of the guards, Byron Hadley, complaining about being taxed on an inheritance and offers to help him shelter the money legally. After an assault by the Sisters nearly kills Andy, Hadley beats and cripples Bogs, who is subsequently transferred to another prison. Andy is not attacked again. Warden Samuel Norton meets Andy and reassigns him to the prison library to assist elderly inmate Brooks Hatlen, a front to allow Andy to manage financial matters for other prison staff, guards from other prisons, and the warden himself. Andy begins writing weekly letters to the state legislature requesting funds to improve the prison's decaying library.

Brooks is paroled in 1954 after serving 50 years, but he cannot adjust to the outside world and eventually hangs himself. The legislature sends a library donation that includes a recording of The Marriage of Figaro; Andy plays an excerpt over the public address system and is punished with solitary confinement. After his release from solitary, Andy explains that hope is what gets him through his time, a concept that Red dismisses. In 1963, Norton begins exploiting prison labor for public works, profiting by undercutting skilled labor costs and receiving bribes. Andy launders the money using the alias "Randall Stephens".

Tommy Williams is incarcerated for burglary in 1965. Andy and Red befriend him, and Andy helps him pass his GED exam. A year later, Tommy reveals to Red and Andy that his cellmate at another prison had claimed responsibility for the murders for which Andy was convicted. Andy approaches Norton with this information, but Norton refuses to listen, and when Andy mentions the money laundering, Norton sends him back to solitary confinement. Norton has Hadley murder Tommy under the guise of an escape attempt. Andy attempts to discontinue the laundering, but relents after Norton threatens to destroy the library, remove Andy's protection from the guards, and move him to worse conditions. Andy is released from solitary confinement after two months, and he tells a skeptical Red that he dreams of living in Zihuatanejo, a Mexican coastal town. Andy also tells him of a specific hayfield near Buxton, asking Red-once he is released-to retrieve a package that Andy buried there. Red worries about Andy's well-being, especially when he learns Andy asked a fellow inmate for 6 ft (1.8 m) of rope.

At the next day's roll call, the guards find Andy's cell empty. An irate Norton throws a rock at a poster of Raquel Welch hanging on the cell wall, revealing a tunnel that Andy dug with his rock hammer over the previous 19 years. The previous night, Andy used the rope to escape through the tunnel and prison sewage pipe, taking Norton's suit, shoes, and ledger, containing proof of the money laundering. While guards search for him, Andy poses as Randall Stephens, withdraws the laundered money from several banks, and mails the ledger and other evidence of the corruption and murders at Shawshank to a local newspaper. State police arrive at Shawshank and take Hadley into custody, while Norton commits suicide to avoid arrest.

After serving 40 years, Red is finally paroled. He struggles to adapt to life outside prison and fears that he never will. Remembering his promise to Andy, he visits Buxton and finds a cache containing money and a letter asking him to come to Zihuatanejo. Red violates his parole by traveling to Fort Hancock, Texas, and crossing the border into Mexico, admitting that he finally feels hope. He finds Andy on a beach in Zihuatanejo, and the two reunited friends happily embrace.

It goes without saying that Stephen King is the master of horror fiction. So many of his works have been adapted into films that star phenomenal actors. To date: I have seen The Shining, the new ITs, Shawshank Redemption. The Green Mile, and all three Carries.

I have yet to see The Stand and the original IT. I also haven't finished watching The Mist which is a television series based on his short story by the same name.

As far as books go however, I have read The Shining, Carrie, began IT (need to finish it), and On Writing. Clearly, I must read Shawshank Redemption, Green Mile, and maybe Christine. Of course there's also Doctor Sleep (sequel to The Shining) which is already a movie and The Stand which I must read as well.

But I feel this review went from Stephen King to why I read and watch Stephen KIng films to basically nothing about Shawshank Redemption.

So let's get back on track here. The first review on I.M.D.B. for this movie is titled "Tied for the best movie I have ever seen". If I read the review, maybe I'll figure out WHY it's tied.

As for me though, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Nice bonus to have my name be mentioned: Andy Dufresne. But besides the name drop, this movie gave me a lot to think about. Stephen King/the writers really dove into the inner workings of a prison and with a stellar cast that includes Morgan Freeman, I was hooked. The prison break was even genius. I don't want to spoil too much and this film is not the best film I have ever seen, but it's up there.

Before watching the movie, I recommend reading the book (I still haven't. Guilty) and then comparing the two once you have seen Shawshank Redemption. I can't guarantee it, but I would assume you won't be disappointed.

With writes,

-Andy Ruffett

First-time director/screenwriter Frank Darabont expands Stephen King's 1982 short story 'Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption', into one of the most definitive, moving and uplifting films to be made in recent years. 'The Shawshank Redeption' is not just an acute prison drama, it remains a detailed an emotional study of humanities endeavour against hardship and repression. A standout performance by Morgan Freeman and dazeling direction by Darabont, are abetted by elaborate panoramic cinematography, a touching score and a malicious imposing character - the oppressive 'Shawshank State Prison' itself.

Any other year, this would've won Best Picture. Probably Best Director, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Screenplay too. This film had the misfortune of going against juggernaut Forrest Gump, and there was no way that it could beat the hype surrounding the good (though not great) Gump. Still, seven years later, it looks like this is the film from 1994 that people will remember long after Forrest has faded away.

If you didn't like The Shawshank Redemption, then you don't understand the concept of the film. Shawshank is the epitome of good film-making -- a fresh, interesting, verisimilar, detailed story coupled with acting that makes Tim Robbins stand out in my mind as Andy Dufresne himself. The imagery is beautiful, the story has few, if any, holes, and Morgan Freeman plays the character of Red, the film's narrator, exceedingly well. To those who find it unnatural that a murderer has matured into a wise, thoughtful man during a long tenure in prison, I suggest that there is no more logical place for such a transformation. Red has had 20 years (upon Andy's arrival) to think about the crimes of his youth, and has grown as a result. In short, Shawshank is a movie for people who like good stories. It will make you laugh, it might make you cry, and in the end, you'll simply feel good about life itself.

The Shawshank Redemption is one of those films of which people used to say "they don't make 'em like that anymore". Well, Frank Darabont had the courage to do it and the world owes him a debt of gratitude. With the advent of the 90s there was the feeling that Hollywood, and Hollywood audiences, could never again accept such a thoughtful, emotional and "feelgood" movie as Shawshank. It shouldn't have been made in this era but thank God it was. Stick it in black and white and it could quite easily have come right out of the 50s along with It's A Wondeful Life. Most 90s films to which the critics automatically responded with the word "classic", Pulp Fiction, American Beauty, Fight Club, may or may not endure "the test of time" but there's no such doubts about The Shawshank Redemption. It is a true classic.

I have been an avid fan of Stephen King since elementary school. I went to a catholic school from kindergarten through 8th grade. Of all places for me to pick up my first King book, it was at a book fair for my school. It was "The Eyes of the Dragon". I was hooked. I remember reading this short story and not thinking much of it. Previous King books-turned-movies offered a glimpse of what was to come. 90% of his movies are almost perfect transitions from print to screen. Green Mile is among the best as well, but...

...This movie definitely is what it is all about. I know it is cliché to say it, yet I feel there has never been a more appropriate comparison. This movie is like a fine wine. Not quite appreciated fully at first but as time passes, it is clearly head and shoulders above the rest. It was released in a year that saw amazing film-making. Gump takes the best picture, and there were a handful of others which could have taken that honor - had they been released any other year. Pulp Fiction most notably... Don't get me wrong, Gump is a great movie just not even close to best that year. 3rd or lower.

By far, one of the best movie adaptations of a Stephen King novel to date. Perhaps a bit maudlin and sappy at times, it is an age old story of friendship, hope and redemption. A formula that head been done time and time again. What differentiates this film is that it doesn't get weighed down in that stereotypical quagmire. A brilliantly adapted screenplay, that conveys what daily life in prison is like. Not in the cartoonish manner of say, Jailhouse Rock. It is a journey into the dark, hopelessness of an evil institution resplendent with corruption, violence, and desperation. This is the rare Hollywood production that not only stirs up just about every human emotion, it reaches into your soul. All of the acting is superb, particular Tim Robbins. I suggest you read the book first, then watch the movie.
Best movie Alltime. That's it nothing better then this movie a classic that brings all the emotion into picture so yourself a favor and watch this movie you won't regret it. A must watch.

The Shawshank Redemption, is one of those films, that stays in your mind long after the credits role off the screen. It is nothing short of a Masterpiece, adopted from a story written by Stephen King, Entitled "Rita Hayworth and The Shawshank Redemption". The story takes place in the 1940's, in New England, and opens with the murder Trial of Andy Dufresne (Tim Robins), who is being tried over the murder of his wife and her lover. Andy is sentenced to life imprisonment, over a crime which he maintains he did not commit.

It is here, confined within the grey stone walls of the Prison, that he meets "Red", played superbly by Morgan Freeman. Red and Andy become the most unlikely of friends, and over the years their friendship grows. Andy shows Red that there is always hope, even in the bleakest of circumstances, and Hope is what will set you free.

The Shawshank Redemption is remarkable in every aspect. The storyline is fantastic, and the director pays a lot of attention to every part of it. The prison cellar shots are extremely realistic, even though they are built on a giant set. The acting is supurb, from the lead characters to the supporting cast. All in All, this film is nothing short of Brilliant, and will go down as the greatest film i have ever seen. 10/10

Shawshank Redemption like Forrest Gump, 1 + 1, And in my soul I'm dancing Until I played the box, Knocking on Heaven's Door, etc. This is the category of films after which you want to live and appreciate this life, as Andy Dufresne did . Secondly, the film itself is gorgeous and brilliantly shot. Thirdly, this film is a clear illustration that the success of the film depends not on a huge budget, not on a star cast, not on critical awards (yes, Moonlight?), not on a PR company, not on exorbitant box office receipts or awards (Escape from Shawshank has no big fees and no Oscar). No, a successful film needs a talented director and talented actors, and as a result, a film that has been on the first position of the Top 250 in IMBd and Kinopoisk for more than a decade. It would seem that the entire film takes place in one building, the main character does not plan to escape the entire film. He just lives and throughout the film we observe his relationship with other prisoners, guards, the head of the prison. And all this is really interesting. After all, in fact, the film is about life in all the diversity of its emotional spectrum, at the head of which is hope, like a ray of light to which we all aspire. Thanks for the masterpiece!

This is quite simply,the best film ever made. Taken from a short story by Stephen King,it turns out to be a true cinematic masterpiece. It takes you through just about every single emotion possible,happiness,sadness,elation,fear and jubilation at the end. The more you see this movie,the more you appreciate just how amazing it is. Tim Robbins' character is one you sympathize with right from the word go,you're rooting for him all the way through the movie,when he has his run-ins with Boggs and his cronies,to when you see him on the beach and he sees Red walking towards him. One word Masterpiece. I have never seen such an amazing film since I saw The Shawshank Redemption. Shawshank encompasses friendships, hardships, hopes, and dreams. And what is so great about the movie is that it moves you, it gives you hope. Even though the circumstances between the characters and the viewers are quite different, you don't feel that far removed from what the characters are going through.

It is a simple film, yet it has an everlasting message. Frank Darabont didn't need to put any kind of outlandish special effects to get us to love this film, the narration and the acting does that for him. One of better of all times.Shawshank as a metaphor for surroundings of a human being,unfortunately more evil averagely,Andy for wiser,more just human in interactions with it.He confirms the rule that more just,wiser live longer and better because their ability is closer to the Ideal,Absolute.This humans can go closer to All,Unlimited because they understand themselves and the world more and better.With their wisdom they choose actions which lead them to lesser and lesser limitations.Andy is smarter and he sees the way out(a pipe) of bigger suffering over the river(closer to Freedom)which flows into the Pacific(Silence,Freedom).That scene when he exits the pipe and lifts his hands,smiling while the rain is falling on his face, is first among more astonishing in the history of film.On his way to Big Pax he doesn't forget others which need redemption.Red is among them (great Freeman who has the best last name a man can have and especially a black man).He is a killer so he can only partly redeem himself.Andy helps him and others showing them better way in life(cold beers,library,education).Red almost looses the will to carry on (Brooks)but Andy lifts him.And than the final embrace scene on the beach of the Pacific(Freedom)which is also among more beautiful in cinema.Because of all that The Shawshank redemption is a artistic masterpiece which I watched and will watch many times.

"The Shawshank Redemption, directed by Frank Darabont and based on a novella by Stephen King, stands as a beacon of hope within the realm of cinematic storytelling. This film intricately weaves the dark and grim corridors of Shawshank prison with an underlying theme of friendship, resilience, and ultimately, redemption, which resonates deeply with audiences across generations.

Tim Robbins delivers a stellar performance as Andy Dufresne, a man convicted of a crime he insists he did not commit. His journey is one of quiet strength and intellect, qualities that carve out a space of hope and renewal amidst the oppressive walls of Shawshank. Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Ellis "Red" Redding, the seasoned inmate and the film's narrator, is both touching and profound, offering a humane perspective to the harsh realities of prison life.

One of the film's standout attributes is its capacity to build complex, believable characters that evoke empathy and understanding. The camaraderie that builds between Andy and Red is both heartwarming and soul-stirring, representing the blossoms of friendship in the most unlikely of places.

Moreover, the cinematography is nothing short of brilliant, with each frame carefully constructed to depict the juxtaposition of confinement and freedom. The score complements the narrative perfectly, adding layers of emotion to an already poignant tale.

What makes 'The Shawshank Redemption' truly transcendent is its adept ability to encapsulate the essence of hope, the belief that there is a chance for something better, even in the face of insurmountable odds. It is a film that touches upon the human spirit's unyielding capacity for hope and redemption, making it a timeless classic that continues to inspire and uplift."

I always thought The Godfather or the Dark Knight were the gold standard of how movies should be written, until I saw the Shawshank Redemption. Forget Batman or Superman, Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman are THE World's Finest both in cinema and in general. Their chemistry as actors really sets them apart from every actor in the world. The director and the writers did a damn good job of tugging at my heartstrings 4. Times. That's never happened to me before. And parts like the one where Andy gave the maggot to Brooks to feed it to Jake the Crow, completely broke me and my heart into thousands of pieces. If you want a movie that will change your life or leave you a sobbing mess, The Shawshank Redemption is the movie for you.

One of the greatest movies ever made. The Shawshank Redemption is truly a masterpiece in my eyes, with a perfect cast, score, direction, and writing. The film explores friendship, struggle, freedom and perseverance, and a film that is impossible to dislike in my opinion. I loved every single performance in that movie, from Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, Bob Gunton, Clancy Brown to James Whitmore, and the direction by Frank Darabont was extraordinary and he went on to direct more great movies including"The Green Mile" and "The Majestic". The story which was originally a short story by Stephen King was also one the best stories I've ever seen, along with a terrific and catchy score by Thomas Newman that could stay in my head for days, and I could not be tired of it afterwards.

This truly one the greatest movies of all time and one of my favourite movies too, in fact I think is not only the Best movie of 1994, but the the best movie the decade, in my honest opinion. Films like The Shawshank Redemption are why I love the movies.

Its difficult to put a finger on what exactly it was about The Shawshank Redemption that I fell so in love with that I have seen it over and over again and every time there was a new element in the movie that fascinated me.

A seemingly simple story of two men in prison and their lives over a period of twenty years.But presented with such elegance that you can actually relate with all the characters and feel bad for them,love them,hate them.A superb movie and an ever better adaptation of a Stephen King novella,beating even one of my personal favorites 'The Green Mile' in the process.The development of the characters is so realistic that you can actually see them aging,physically and emotionally,throughout the length of the movie.The story,in spite of its simplicity,keeps you glued to the screen due to the brilliant handling of the main plot and various sub plots and how they come together in the end.Every small,seemingly insignificant element merges seamlessly with the story which is rare to see in any movie these days.The lead actors,Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman both are at their best,although the better actor without a doubt is Tim Robbins playing an incredibly complex character and looking at ease throughout.

This is the kind of movie that you will think and talk about long after you are done watching it.The theme of never losing hope is somewhat a lesson to all of us.I wouldn't dream of letting out the plot in anyway because if you haven't seen the movie yet,just go and watch it.It will move you and amaze you like nothing you have ever experienced.

Smiling, laughing, and crying are some of the main emotions that come out of the film. No matter what time of day it is, if this movie is on tv, it will stay on and be watched.

This is one of my all time favorite movies. The storyline, acting, set design, and cinematography were some of the best I've ever seen.

From scene to scene, everything made sense, everything was logical, and the manner in which each character had their own "breakout" moment is one of the things that set this movie apart from others like it. The emotional connection or feeling that every actor brought to this movie, made it entertaining, compelling, and worth watching.

Andy delivers moments of mental exhaustion, conflict, and turmoil that would've broken a normal man in his situation. While being falsely imprisoned, he manages to find ways to get through the daily uncomfortable grind of being in prison in the 60's, while at the same time trying to keep from snapping.

Red's character brings something to the film that is meaningful, inspiring, and motivational to every scene he was featured in. Life lessons, charming whit, and a wise man demeanor puts him on a level only seen by "mob bosses" during this time.

There were a few timeline inaccuracies that kept me from giving this movie a full 10 stars, but it's definitely worth watching.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a critically acclaimed film released in 1994, directed by Frank Darabont and based on Stephen King's novella of the same name. It is widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time and has garnered a large and dedicated fanbase over the years.

The movie tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is sentenced to life imprisonment at Shawshank State Penitentiary, where he faces the harsh realities of prison life. The film primarily focuses on Andy's experiences and his unlikely friendship with another inmate, Ellis "Red" Redding.

What sets "The Shawshank Redemption" apart from other prison dramas is its emphasis on hope, friendship, and the indomitable spirit of the human soul. The movie explores themes of perseverance, the power of the human spirit, and the quest for redemption. It beautifully captures the complexities of the prison system and the personal struggles faced by the inmates.

The performances in the film are outstanding. Tim Robbins delivers a nuanced and compelling portrayal of Andy Dufresne, capturing his quiet strength and determination. Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Red is equally impressive, bringing depth and warmth to the character. The chemistry between Robbins and Freeman is a highlight of the film, and their friendship forms the emotional core of the story.

The screenplay, written by Frank Darabont, is superbly crafted. It skillfully balances moments of heart-wrenching drama with moments of humor, creating a captivating narrative that keeps viewers engaged throughout. The film's pacing is excellent, allowing the story to unfold at a steady and satisfying pace.

Visually, the film is well executed, with atmospheric cinematography that captures the bleakness of prison life and the beauty of freedom. The production design and costumes effectively recreate the period setting, immersing the audience in the world of Shawshank.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant film that leaves a lasting impact on its viewers. It explores universal themes of hope, friendship, and the capacity for redemption, making it a timeless classic. The movie's enduring popularity is a testament to its quality and the profound effect it has on audiences. Whether you're a fan of dramas, prison stories, or simply great storytelling, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a film that should not be missed.
