Perhaps the greatest challenge of the AMPAS is determining what defines a "Best Picture." I have heard it defined from some forgotten source directly tied to the AMPAS that a Best Picture is one that holds itself superb in the following three categories: Direction, Writing, and Acting, not necessarily in that order. A good example would be Citizen Kane, arguably the most worthy winner of these three categories (Kane lost to How Green and never picked up the Best Picture statue). However, it is certain that the greatest film of all time would need to excel especially in one field: Originality. How many people would even go bother to see another interpertation of Titanic? However, if this particular film had come out before the Cameron version, it would certainly be hailed with critical acclaim. Shawshank is one that meets the AMPAS standards of excellence, and most certainly would have taken the Best Picture title, if not for Forrest Gump, a film which many members perhaps found it impossible to not vote for due to the momentum it had gained. If Shawshank had been nominated almost any other year of this decade, the statue would have been a lock. However, we must look at Shawshank not as the year's Best Picture, but as a film in the long timeline of movie history, a film which tells an original story with original acting style and original directing. Can we look at Shawshank and with all sincerity call it the greatest film ever? Before deciding, a prerequisite should be to see at least 50 of the best films of this century. In this way, Shawshank loses the advantage of being fresh in our memory, losing the emotional effect, and must bow to the annals of time as do all the other superb films of history. Shawshank is not the Best Picture of all time nor the greatest film of all time. This is a fact we must face and learn to live with, no matter how much the storyline touched us all.

This film was great - and that's a poor way to describe it. IT was fantastic!!! You see into the lives of Andy and Red and all the others in Shawshank. Not only do you gain insight as to how the prisoners live, but also how they work and live with one another, and how badly they are treated at times, by both fellow prisoners and by the guards. This movie also shows how that in some cases instead of preparing a prisoner for life back on the streets, prison will make them prepared for life only on the inside. The example of this is the elderly librarian prisoner. He has been in prison for many many years, and finally he is let out. This movie is a must see for anyone who likes a good prison movie or just one that seems to be real life.

This movie has gradually become my favorite. After the first viewing, I was in complete awe at the way the events lead up to the final events with Andy. The second time, I realized that the prevalent theme is hope. The third, then the fourth, then the fifth... etc.... forever, I realized that this movie has so many elements, that a review such as this doesn't provide ample space to discuss them all.

I think that what makes this movie so unique, is its portrayal of prison life. Most of the time, prisons are either romanticized in that they don't portray all of the harsh elements of it. The other times, the writers try too hard to prove how harsh a prison is. They portray them as places where the convicts should give up hope because its Hell on Earth until you die, and everybody begs to come out as soon as the parole board gives their say-so. This movie, however, completely illustrates the harsh realities of prison, as well as a place where one learns to hate it, but then gets used to it (as Red said). Andy made a best friend there. Had he not gone to prison, he never would've met Red. Besides, the prisoners (for the most part) seemed to be having a fairly good time most of the time and probably couldn't imagine being anywhere else.

Stephen King also brings out an element of crime and punishment. I find it very ironic that Andy, a fairly good man is the only one that doesn't give up hope of living on the outside. I think that one of the most important parts of the movie is when Andy talks about how whatever sins he has committed, has been paid for. Andy is one of the only ones that doesn't give up hope because he doesn't belong there.

One more thing is the way that Andy brings a form of salvation to others. He makes prison more human. He gets the guys the beers so that they'll never forget the freedom of the outside world. In addition, he asks for the name of the "fresh fish" in the beginning. As proven by a later movie, Saving Private Ryan, asking what a person's name is seems to prove as a very effective way of humanizing what is actually inhumane.

There are a gajillion other themes, but I would exhaust myself trying to explain them all. So if the thousand of other good reviews on this page don't influence you to watch it, hopefully this will. The acting is incredible (as a guy, its hard to imagine that a two hour plus movie without an actress is bearable). I don't think that you can compare this movie with any others because there aren't too many movies that inundate the watcher from the beginning with loads and loads of themes and concepts. Furthermore, its impressive the way almost every element has some significance. In the beginning, even the most trivial of details that evade the eye the first time become essential elements in Andy's final scene (in hope not to spoil the ending).

But I must warn you. The first time: this movie is good, the second time: its better, the third time: its addicting. Don't say that I didn't warn you. Ten plus out of ten!!! Thank you IMDB for finally putting this very underrated movie in its rightful place.

It's a great thing when you can finally find a movie you can definitively call "your favorite". This is mine. "The Shawshank Redemption", based on Stephen King's short novella entitled "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption", is an excellent adaptation of said literature...I will go out and say it; I've read the story and seen the movie, and although the movie took some parts out (in the story, there were three different wardens over the course of the story, and Red was Irish, not black), it expanded the detail greatly, covering parts the novella never bothered to touch on (such as Andy getting a new set of clothes and a shiny pair of shoes from the Warden ^_^). The characters are all detailed and alive, not once did I find a character unbelievable. And I've never EVER seen an ending so incredible. My eyes were wide, I was chanting "Oh My God" over and over...This movie makes you feel good all over and gives you a new perspective on life and freedom. This movie is nothing short of a masterpiece. The only fault I find is that it came out at the time as Forrest Gump, which had a lot more advertising and thus beat this great movie out in the box office. Had it come out a few months later, it would have been much more successful.

"Fear can hold you prisoner, hope can set you free." The Shawshank Redemption is the very touching story of a man who makes mistakes with his life and is imprisioned. While there, Andy (Tim Robbins) is faced with some very cruel people, including Byron Hadley(Clancy Brown) and a group of inmates called "the sisters". But he also meets a man named Ellis Redding (played by the oh so talented Morgan Freeman) and forms a heart warming friendship. Basically, Andy Dufresne goes through many life trials which will chill your blood, make your heart race, bring a tear to your eye, and a smile to your lip. Wonderful movie, my all time favorite. This is also based on the short story "Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption" written by my favorite author, Stephen King.

This movie also has MANY wonderful monologues and great quotes.

Please watch, and I am sure you will enjoy. "Get busy livin', or get busy dyin'." ~~ML

I'm not going to elaborate on what has already been written by others - except to say that the popularity for this film is enormous. I don't think I know ANYONE who didn't like it - it will be recognised as one of THE films of the 90's.

An amazing movie. Easily one of the best movies made during the 90s and definitely one of the top "prison" movies of all-time. Pretty much everything about this movie works and works extremely well! The film touches upon many subjects, including the ideas of hope, redemption, love, loneliness, justice, life/death, friendship, endurance, fear, patience, inspiration and so much more. Watching this movie always makes me feel a million times better, and if that's not the greatest reason to watch a film, I don't know what is. Give it up to both Freeman and Robbins for completely engulfing their characters with heart, soul and the spirit of humanity. I appreciated the message in this film, I absolutely loved the way it ended, I surrendered to its pace, I enjoyed all of its characters, I thought it was wonderfully photographed, I loved the score and I could seriously watch this movie 10 times a year and not bat an eyelash the whole way through.

This is much more than a prison film. This is a film about how the human spirit can conquer the most unspeakable abyss and come out clean at the other side. In addition, the story at the heart of it, of Andy (Tim Robbins) and Red (Morgan Freedman)is simply a story of two men's friendship -- something seldom explored in cinema, and rarely as well. Lastly, the theme of hope echoes and throughout the film and reverberates in the viewer's minds like an aria against hard prison walls.

Hope, love, belief, friendship, feeling. Watch this film and re-establish once again what is good about the movies. If you don't particularly like watching films, I urge you to watch this and experience something unlike you have experienced before. This, alongside AMERICAN BEAUTY, is one of the greatest films ever made.

This was an awesome movie. I didn't expect it to be that good, when I first started to watch it. First time I saw it I fell asleep. It must have been because I was tired. Because now it was a wonderful movie. And if anybody from Mt. Vernon, Iowa reads this. It's great to watch it as we were supposed to do it in a class there last year but weren't allowed to because of the rating (R).

I made my Stephen King debut with this particular story when I was in my late teens. Frank Darabont shot a wonderful adaptation which is not very common. Great actor Tim Robbins played the unfortunate Dufresne with such a grace that you never think that the guy was very small in size in the original story. Morgan Freeman is in his prime playing Red, the most useful person in the jail. The suicide of the old prisoner and the last scene where both friends meet are the most emotional ones. And of course we should salute the most beautiful supporting actress ever, Rita Hayworth. Darabont never tries to steal parts from the original story. May be this is why the film is always remembered as a good piece of art.

It is almost impossible to glorify this movie more than it deserves because, simply I believe it is the greatest ever made. The story, characters, music are absolutely mesmerizing. For those who have not seen The Shawshank Redemption, you have, so far, missed a genuine treat. I have seen hundreds of films. I don't think I have ever seen more than two or three that combined what I consider to be the five basic aspects requisite for consideration as a masterpiece. This is one of those films. The five basic elements are great acting--in which we the viewer see the character, feel the character, not the actor; a great score/sound-track; a cinematic quality that enables the viewer to experience the surroundings, not just view them; great dialogue and non-dialogue--the best scripts usually utilize not only the verbal abilities of actors, but non-verbal expression as well (see a film with Cary Grant or Robert De Niro to know what I mean); and most important a compelling story.

The Shawshank Redemption not only offers ALL of these, but does so at a level few films have ever reached.

The basic plot is simple enough: a man is wrongly convicted of murdering his wife and the man with whom she is having an affair. Why then is it so great? The performances, all around, but especially of Robbins and Freeman are so rich, so human, the viewer feels they are living their experiences. The film demonstrates, magnificently, how a man can create a meaningful life against horrid (mentally and physically) circumstances. The film wrenches the guts of its viewers, yet provides great satisfaction in the end. It is a great film celebrating determination, friendship, revenge (as sweet as you will ever see), education, and the basic goodness intrinsic to all people.

...that if you've never seen this movie, that you'll take the time to watch.

Even if it's from the beginning, the middle or the last 20 minutes. I watch this movie when it's on TV. Morgan Freeman is one of the finest actors in America, and his portrayal of Red's journey of friendship and to freedom is touching. His words, "get busy living or get busy dying," never fail to hit home. It's just a good story that Frank Darabont turned into an excellent movie. The performances are all good - Freeman deserved an Oscar. Absolutely one of the best movies ever.

I saw Shawshank quite a few years ago now. However, upon visiting the IMDB Top 250 list and finding it two from the top, I was not surprised. Despite the fact that I saw the movie is 1996 or 1997, I can still remember some of the poignant momments in the film and how the entire film made me feel (heartfelt and happy!).

Overall, I think Shawshank was an absoloutely amazing film. It showcases great performances from both Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins, and also demonstrates the quality of writing that people should expect from somebody like Steven King.

this is the greatest movie i have ever seen. by reading the plot you may think of it as just another prison movie. it's more of a friends movie. the greatest portrayal of how wonderful a friend is i have ever seen. i love this movie and have seen it a million times and will see it another million times.

Perhaps the only thing more remarkable than this masterpiece of a movie is the fact that neither Tim Robbins nor Morgan Freeman won Oscars for their performances. I would put Freeman's portrayal of Ellis Redding amongst the best performances ever in a movie...so moving, so powerful. And the fact that this film did not win Best Picture is all the more unsettling.

This movie isn't just about a couple of guys in prison. Anyone who sees that, well, that must be where the "1" ratings came from. The message of hope is so positively inspiring. This is a movie that immensely impacted my life, something I can't say about any other film. Forrest Gump? Sure it was a good movie, but it really was just about a slow-witted man on a bench discussing his life. It never should have won Best Picture. I'm not sure if the MPAA ever saw this movie, maybe that explains it. Not only was the acting magnificent, but the ending is one of the best in movie history. I'm a 19 year old male, and I can't remember the last time I cried for anything. But the final scene in The Shawshank Redemption reduced me to tears. If there is anyone reading this who has not seen this movie, you would be doing yourself a huge injustice if you didn't run to the video store immediately. I've seen all the "Great" movies -- Citizen Kane, Casablanca, Godfather (not to mention American Beauty, the most overrated movie ever), but none of them even comes so close as to compare to this movie. Plain and simple, the Shawshank Redemption is the best movie I have ever seen, and it will be a very long time before something better comes along. 20/10 if I could.

The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont, based on the 1982 Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. It tells the story of banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who is sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary for the murders of his wife and her lover, despite his claims of innocence. Over the following two decades, he befriends a fellow prisoner, contraband smuggler Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), and becomes instrumental in a money-laundering operation led by the prison warden Samuel Norton (Bob Gunton). William Sadler, Clancy Brown, Gil Bellows, and James Whitmore appear in supporting roles.

This simply is the best movie I've ever seen. With 2 of the greatest actors (Tim Robbins & Morgan Freeman) and such a great ending, it will be difficult to beat (in my case). This movie will be the standard for 'jail-movies' for a very long time!

In my book this is the best movie ever made, or at least my favorite. I know that may be going out on a limb, but it is that spectacular. It makes me smile every time in the end, it actually brings me near tears which very few movies have ever done.

With all due respect to the people that complain of it's too stark good vs. evil characters, simplicity and so on... you are missing the point. Having been raised on a steady diet of Hollywood crap, this was first, and only, movie that has been truly inspirational and moved me to tears. This is NOT standard Hollywood material. It has been pointed out that, in general, optimism is equated with ignorance. I was of that opinion as well, but this was truly a LIFE-CHANGING movie for me. This wasn't a movie so much as it was a wake-up call. I've seen all the classics. But nothing I've encountered has conveyed such a message of positivity and hope as this movie, without being contrived or obvious. To all those who pour negative reviews on "Shawshank", stop being a critic, and start being human. To everyone else, I think we're all better people for having seen it.

Low budget, weak at the box office, winless at the Academy Awards, and often considered a weak and clitched film. It's too bad that the greatest film ever made is also the most underrated.

The Shawshank Redemption is the story of Ellis Redding (Red), and his views on life, society, and an inmate named Andy Dufresne.

The story is flawless, the score is memorable, the cinematography is splendid, and the movie flows at a smooth pace all the way through its three hour length. While it often appears to be a weak film at first glance, it really just requires multiple viewings. After several viewings, anyone can begin to realize its greatness.

While movie critics can keep calling Citizen Kane the greatest, I realize it doesn't come close to so much as comparing to Shawshank. Citizen Kane doesn't let its viewers relate to its character, think his every thought, walk his every step, or breathe his every breath. Citizen Kane is a puzzling and riveting masterpiece, but like most "greats", it doesn't compare to The Shawshank Redemption.

The Shawshank Redemption is leagues away from any film I've ever seen in terms of greatness. It is timeless, memorable, original, and ultimately the best film I probably will ever see.

This film's high ranking on IMDB is both a testimony to its greatness and a spotlight on how embarrassingly out of touch the Oscar Academy is.

Congratulations to all of those involved in making one of the truly greatest films of all time.

Words cannot describe this movie. I feel this is the best escape/prison movie ever made. The analogy to the human situation is uncanny and it is this fact that makes this movie great and not just very good. Now I know what it means to be institutionalized. ESCAPE WHILE YOU CAN !!!

Our world can be like that scary prison. A place where life is monotonous and crazy. Moving on a straight path to death. But only this hope will help us get out of the prison of the world and break this cycle. "Hope" may be considered the last weapon of mankind. Philosophers describe hope as something that keeps us alive psychologically and makes us wait for the sunrise with joy instead of sadness. Hope means the confidence we have in our current situation. Even if we are stuck in a painful hell, hope promises a time when everything will be better. Well, we're not going to be caught in hell now, are we? We all know hell as a place full of ugly demons, endless torture, and painful death and resurrection. Such a place may belong to another world, but "The Shawshank Redemption" takes us to a real hell on earth: prison.

The prison in The Shawshank Redemption may not be absolute hell, but it is the most hellish part of the planet. Some thinkers think that existence consists of three levels: the highest level is heaven and the lowest level is hell, and the human world is in between these two and contains elements from both upper and lower levels. Earth can be as painful as hell and as pleasurable as heaven for humans. When Andy Dufrin walks into prison, the old-timers make a bet on which of the fresh fish will cry first. The first person to cry is beaten so badly by the prison captain that he dies. This is how we get to know the dual state of the prison (earth). The head of the prison introduces the most important rule of the prison to the new arrivals: respect the Lord and never use his name for trivial things. Then he continues: "God protects your soul, but your body is mine." Although the head of the prison seems to be a God-fearing man and in other circumstances he should treat the prisoners better, but his words and behavior are completely different from each other.

Back in high school, I had an English class where we read the short story by Stephen King and then watched the movie. The short story is wonderfully to read by itself. However, the movie manages to both perfectly capture the whole feel and atmosphere of the original story, and improve upon it. It is rare for a movie to be better than the book, yet everyone agreed it was so. In the movie, many of the characters are more developed, and the warden is made much more crooked. Much of the narration is directly from the short story, but the parts that are not blend perfectly. It is a long movie, with little action and no special effects, yet it is always mesmerizing and beautiful, a movie about hope, with an incredible surprise ending. I still feel cheated because I read the story first and knew the ending before I ever saw the movie.

Many of the most powerful stories are the soulful ones that teach us not to despair, not to be swamped by sorrow. They remind us that hope is a precious and buoyant emotion which can give our lives substance and meaning.

The Shawshank Redemption is based on a novella by Stephen King. Tim Robbins plays Andy, a banker who is sent to prison for the murder of his wife and her lover. The judge who sentences him finds him "a particularly remorseless and icy man." Andy's cool reserve and aloofness is not accepted well by the other inmates at Shawshank maximum-security prison in Maine. He is raped by some angry men and given several long stretches in solitary confinement for his bad attitude.

Luckily, Andy is befriended by Red, played by Morgan Freeman, the prison fixer. He is awed by this young man's quiet reserve and inward resolve to make the best of his bad situation. Andy's accounting skills come in handy, and he begins doing the taxes for the guards and laundering money for the corrupt warden. This lands him the cushy job of librarian. Eventually, Andy wrangles money out of state officials to build the best prison library anywhere.

Writer and director Frank Darabont draws out strong and intense performances from Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins as soulmates who support each other while doing hard time. Red sees hope as a dangerous thing that can drive a man insane, but Andy believes it is fuel that keeps one going against all odds. The Shawshank Redemption is a jubilant tribute to hope as an essential quality of soul.

Shawshank Redemption is famously one of the greatest movies of all time, maybe even the best. Along with being one of the best it is also one of the most human, the most real, the most heartfelt, and the most impactful film. I've seen people change their lives and perspectives over the message Shawshank is trying give. I've seen this movie nearly 15 times now and everytime I watch it, I notice something new about it that I can apply to my life. It sticks in your head. When you're done with the movie, you don't leave and think, "Well that was neat". You leave with the intention to do and be better.

Right now, we have a lot of "harmless movies", movies that have you leaving the theater thinking, "That scene was cool" or "That was funny", leaving with no real impact, just a memory of two harmless hours of entertainment. It's the same stuff over and over and doesn't leave you thinking about the core aspects of the movie or how it can apply to your life. These stories are barely stories. Shawshank is not one of these stories.

There's a reason why Shawshank Redemption is IMDb's favorite, or why it sits on the shelf of the Library of Congress, or why it's considered a modern classic and a masterpiece, or why it's symbol of humanized hope and a prime example of a great film. Discover these reasons for yourself. Check it out, you won't be disappointed.

In people's descriptions of films, the terms "best", "favorite", "great", "a classic" and the like often get bandied about with no real meaning. I've heard someone describing ten different movies, and refer to all ten as the best movies he'd ever seen, all within the span of five minutes.

But with The Shawshank Redemption, those words most definately have meaning. This movie is, quite simply, the single most masterful film I have ever seen. It is completely and utterly amazing, and I have never seen a movie that has surpassed it. Others have come close, but none can match the sheer power of The Shawshank Redemption. Words simply don't do justice to the emotions I feel each time I watch this film, and I am left in awe of how profound it is.

To anyone who has not seen this flawless gem, you are missing out on the single greatest film ever made. Film is Art, and The Shawshank Redemption is the film equivalent of a DaVinci, a Michaelangelo, or a Rembrant. It is simply amazing.

How ironic that an innocent man winds up being surrounded by the corruption of the legal system.

And it is not necessarily redemption for the actual crimes you might have commited,but it is redemption for the way you have lived your life. "The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

But Andy does not cry, and Red loses the cigarettes he wagered. Andy turns out to be a surprise to everyone in Shawshank, because within him is such a powerful reservoir of determination and strength that nothing seems to break him. Andy was a banker on the outside, and he's in for murder. He's apparently innocent, and there are all sorts of details involving his case, but after a while they take on a kind of unreality; all that counts inside prison is its own society -- who is strong, who is not -- and the measured passage of time.

Red is also a lifer. From time to time, measuring the decades, he goes up in front of the parole board, and they measure the length of his term (20 years, 30 years) and ask him if he thinks he has been rehabilitated. Oh, most surely, yes, he replies; but the fire goes out of his assurances as the years march past, and there is the sense that he has been institutionalized -- that, like another old lifer who kills himself after being paroled, he can no longer really envision life on the outside.

It doesn't get much better than this. Perfect performances throughout, wonderful direction... just amazed it didn't do well when first released. Time put it in its rightful place though... top of the tree!

Shawshank Redemption is a defining moment in cinema.

The movie (directed by Frank Darabont) takes a straight-forward, soul- searching novel by horror icon Stephen King and transforms it into a somber, bloated prison drama designed to fill you up with inspiration.

Thanks to supreme performances and beautiful cinematography, you get that inspirational jump-start frame after frame. And you get generous helpings of the novella's deft ironic humour about a inmate quietly turning a corrupt system against itself.

A small box office release which made its name once released on home video, this movie is well worth a watch if you happened to have missed it first time around.

"The Shawshank Redemption" stands tall as a cinematic gem, a powerful and emotionally gripping masterpiece that leaves an indelible mark on the hearts of its viewers. Directed by Frank Darabont, this adaptation of Stephen King's novella is a triumph of storytelling, featuring brilliant performances, a poignant narrative, and a profound exploration of the human spirit.

Set within the confines of Shawshank State Penitentiary, the film introduces us to Andy Dufresne, portrayed with remarkable depth by Tim Robbins. Wrongfully convicted of murder, Andy embarks on an arduous journey through the prison system, enduring its hardships while clinging to an unwavering sense of hope. Robbins effortlessly portrays Andy's quiet resilience, making him an unforgettable protagonist whose unwavering spirit captivates audiences from the very beginning.

Morgan Freeman delivers a career-defining performance as Red, a seasoned inmate and narrator of the story. Freeman's soothing voice and wise portrayal add a layer of richness to the film, serving as the perfect counterpoint to Andy's unwavering optimism. The bond that forms between Andy and Red is the heart and soul of the film, embodying the true essence of friendship and the strength it provides in the darkest of times.

At its core, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a story of hope and the indomitable human spirit. Through its vivid characters and thought-provoking dialogues, the film delves into themes of perseverance, friendship, and the quest for redemption. It reminds us that even in the most desolate circumstances, hope can be a powerful force that propels individuals toward transformation and renewal.

The film's cinematography paints a hauntingly beautiful portrait of life behind bars. The use of shadows and contrasts adds an atmospheric depth to the prison setting, mirroring the characters' emotional turmoil and yearning for freedom. Every shot is a visual delight, allowing viewers to immerse themselves fully in the world of Shawshank.

The screenplay, penned by Darabont himself, exhibits a perfect balance of humor and heartache, culminating in a story that leaves no emotional stone unturned. Each character, no matter how small their role, serves a purpose in the larger narrative, contributing to the film's emotional resonance and making it a truly unforgettable experience.

Accompanied by an evocative score composed by Thomas Newman, the film's music elevates every scene, evoking a range of emotions that stay with the audience long after the credits roll. The combination of captivating storytelling and a haunting musical score forms a harmonious blend that weaves its way into the hearts of its viewers.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a timeless classic that transcends generations, reminding us of the power of hope, friendship, and the human capacity for redemption. It remains an enduring testament to the strength of the human spirit, leaving an eternal impression that will continue to inspire and touch lives for years to come. A cinematic triumph that should not be missed, this film stands as a shining example of the transformative power of cinema.

The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

But Andy does not cry, and Red loses the cigarettes he wagered. Andy turns out to be a surprise to everyone in Shawshank, because within him is such a powerful reservoir of determination and strength that nothing seems to break him. Andy was a banker on the outside, and he's in for murder. He's apparently innocent, and there are all sorts of details involving his case, but after a while they take on a kind of unreality; all that counts inside prison is its own society -- who is strong, who is not -- and the measured passage of time.

Red is also a lifer. From time to time, measuring the decades, he goes up in front of the parole board, and they measure the length of his term (20 years, 30 years) and ask him if he thinks he has been rehabilitated. Oh, most surely, yes, he replies; but the fire goes out of his assurances as the years march past, and there is the sense that he has been institutionalized -- that, like another old lifer who kills himself after being paroled, he can no longer really envision life on the outside.

Morgan Freeman was even more dreadful and has been giving the same dreadful performance ever since. A phenomenal film. A rare gem that surpasses entertainment, resonating with meaning and enlightenment. The film, and the Stephen King novella it derives from, are a treasure. Even if you're not a big reader, seek out Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption. It's contained in a collection of 4 novellas - one for each season. After you've seen the film, it should be apparent which season Shawshank is allocated. The book also has enough deviations, including a different ending, to keep you enthralled even if you've seen the film several times.

When someone who has never seen this asks why this is my favorite movie - I never know what to tell them. It's the perfect movie, it's like God decided to allow the creators, writers, and actors to blend perfectly together - with the end result being the greatest movie ever written. The first time I saw it, I thoroughly enjoyed it but didn't allow for the intake of dramatic genius to fully set in. I have seen it over 100 times since I first 'experienced' it, and now it is impossible for me to watch any scene without getting chills down my spine. Frank Darabont should have a day made in his name for his adaptation of Stephen King's compelling and brilliant story. No one could have surmised that allowing for one of the more likable inmates to be killed would make the movie even MORE powerful...but he did. One last thing...I just wanted to thank God for allowing them to change the ending to that of a diminishing Robbins and Freeman at the end, no words needed.

With L.A. Confidential running a close second, this is the best film in a surprisingly good decade for movies. Finally, somebody gets Stephen King right. The film is based on one of his short novellas, and director Frank Darabont absolutely nails it. Of course, he has a lot of help from Morgan Freeman, Tim Robbins, Bob Gunton, Clancy Brown, and Gil Bellows. All give amazing performances. Throw in Darabont's screenplay, Roger Deakins' cinematography, and Thomas Newman's score, and you have a bonafide masterpiece. If you don't dig this movie, please check your pulse.

It's a real shame Hollywood did not know how to market this back in 1994, because word-of-mouth came too late for the film to make money or win the Oscars it deserves. So when you see Shawshank for the first time, you'll wonder how in the hell Forrest Gump won best picture. To this day, I've never left a movie theater feeling better than when I saw The Shawshank Redemption.
It's a movie you must watch, enjoy and learn from how to not lose hope, identity and to be unbreakable

The Count of Monte Cristo isn't a very good book, and has spawned a few pretty poor films, but it's the ideas which make it an enduring story. Now whether Stephen King was consciously inspired by Dumas's ("Dumass's") book when writing the original short story I don't know - what I do know is that Frank Darabont took a dour, typically coarsely-detailed potboiler and evolved it into something special. The big step for me, was that having taken an interesting idea and made it good, Darabont then found an ensemble cast and a cinematographer who could make it sing. I don't think there's a dull line of dialogue in the movie, and barely a camera shot either out of place or wasted. Why it is that equally talented filmmakers can spend millions and produce the kind of mindless gibberish which actually wins Oscars (like 'Braveheart' did in the year 'Shawshank Redemption' was nominated) I'll truly never fathom. Maybe there should be another way of formally recognising talent: wait ten years then take a vote - that way the mindless and the popular will have time to find their level and what's left is worth remembering.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time. The movie is based on a story, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption
This film inspired me in so many levels and has given me hope to never give up.

It is a strange comment to make about a film set inside a prison, but "The Shawshank Redemption" creates a warm hold on our feelings because it makes us a member of a family. Many movies offer us vicarious experiences and quick, superficial emotions. "Shawshank" slows down and looks. It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

Interesting that although the hero of the film is the convicted former banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the action is never seen from his point of view. The film's opening scene shows him being given two life sentences for the murder of his wife and her lover, and then we move, permanently, to a point of view representing the prison population and particularly the lifer Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). It is his voice remembering the first time he saw Andy ("looked like a stiff breeze would blow him over"), and predicting, wrongly, that he wouldn't make it in prison.

From Andy's arrival on the prison bus to the film's end, we see only how others see him - Red, who becomes his best friend, Brooks the old librarian, the corrupt Warden Norton, guards and prisoners. Red is our surrogate. He's the one we identify with, and the redemption, when it comes, is Red's. We've been shown by Andy's example that you have to keep true to yourself, not lose hope, bide your time, set a quiet example and look for your chance. "I guess it comes down to a simple choice, really," he tells Red. "Get busy livin' or get busy dyin'."

The key to the film's structure, I think, is that it's not about its hero, but about our relationship with him - our curiosity, our pity, our admiration. If Andy had been the heroic center, bravely enduring, the film would have been conventional, and less mysterious. But we wonder about this guy. Did he really kill those two people? Why does he keep so much to himself? Why can he amble through the prison yard like a free man on a stroll, when everyone else plods or sidles?

People like excitement at the movies, and titles that provide it do well. Films about "redemption" are approached with great wariness; a lot of people are not thrilled by the prospect of a great film - it sounds like work. But there's a hunger for messages of hope, and when a film offers one, it's likely to have staying power even if it doesn't grab an immediate audience.

"The Shawshank Redemption" premiered at the Toronto Film Festival in September 1994, and opened a few weeks later. It got good reviews but did poor business (its $18 million original gross didn't cover costs; it took in only another $10 million after winning seven Oscar nominations, including best picture).

There wasn't much going for it: It had a terrible title, it was a "prison drama" and women don't like those, it contained almost no action, it starred actors who were respected but not big stars, and it was long at 142 minutes. Clearly this was a movie that needed word-of-mouth to find an audience, and indeed business was slowly but steadily growing when it was yanked from theaters. If it had been left to find its way, it might have continued to build and run for months, but that's not what happened.

Instead, in one of the most remarkable stories in home video history, it found its real mass audience on tapes and discs, and through TV screenings. Within five years, "Shawshank" was a phenomenon, a video best seller and renter that its admirers feel they've discovered for themselves. When the Wall Street Journal ran an article about the "Shawshank" groundswell in April 1999, it was occupying first place in the Internet Movie Database worldwide vote of the 250 best films; it's usually in the top five.

Polls and rentals reflect popularity but don't explain why people value "Shawshank" so fervently. Maybe it plays more like a spiritual experience than a movie. It does have entertaining payoff moments (as when the guards from another prison, wearing their baseball uniforms, line up to have Andy do their taxes). But much of the movie involves quiet, solitude, and philosophical discussions about life. The moments of violence (as when Andy is sexually assaulted) are seen objectively, not exploited.

The movie avoids lingering on Andy's suffering; after beatings, he's seen in medium and long shot, tactfully. The camera doesn't focus on Andy's wounds or bruises, but, like his fellow prisoners, gives him his space.

The Morgan Freeman character is carrier of the film's spiritual arc. We see him at three parole hearings, after 20, 30 and 40 years. The first hearing involves storytelling trickery; the film has opened with Andy's sentencing, and then we see a parole board, and expect it's about to listen to Andy's appeal. But, no, that's when we first see Red. In his first appeal he tries to convince the board he's been rehabilitated. In the second, he just goes through the motions. In the third, he rejects the whole notion of rehabilitation, and somehow in doing so he sets his spirit free, and the board releases him. Advertisement

There's an underlying problem. Behind bars, Red is king. He's the prison fixer, able to get you a pack of cigarettes, a little rock pick or a Rita Hayworth poster. On the outside, he has no status or identity. We've already seen what happened to the old librarian (James Whitmore), lonely and adrift in freedom. The last act, in which Andy helps Red accept his freedom, is deeply moving - all the more so because Andy again operates at a distance, with letters and postcards, and is seen through Red's mind.

Frank Darabont wrote and directed the film, basing it on a story by Stephen King. His film grants itself a leisure that most films are afraid to risk. The movie is as deliberate, considered and thoughtful as Freeman's narration. There's a feeling in Hollywood that audiences have short attention spans and must be assaulted with fresh novelties. I think such movies are slower to sit through than a film like "Shawshank," which absorbs us and takes away the awareness that we are watching a film.

Deliberate, too, is the dialogue. Tim Robbins makes Andy a man of few words, quietly spoken. He doesn't get real worked up. He is his own man, capable of keeping his head down for years and then indulging in a grand gesture, as when he plays an aria from Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." (The overhead shot of the prisoners in the yard, spellbound by the music, is one of the film's epiphanies.) Because he does not volunteer himself, reach out to us or overplay his feelings, he becomes more fascinating: It is often better to wonder what a character is thinking than to know.

Roger Deakins' cinematography is tactful, not showy. Two opening shots, one from a helicopter, one of prison walls looming overhead, establish the prison. Shots follow the dialogue instead of anticipating it. Thomas Newman's music enhances rather than informs, and there is a subtle touch in the way deep bass rumblings during the early murder are reprised when a young prisoner recalls another man's description of the crime.

Darabont constructs the film to observe the story, not to punch it up or upstage it. Upstaging, in fact, is unknown in this film; the actors are content to stay within their roles, the story moves in an orderly way, and the film itself reflects the slow passage of the decades. "When they put you in that cell," Red says, "when those bars slam home, that's when you know it's for real. Old life blown away in the blink of an eye. Nothing left but all the time in the world to think about it." Watching the film again, I admired it even more than the first time I saw it. Affection for good films often grows with familiarity, as it does with music. Some have said life is a prison, we are Red, Andy is our redeemer. All good art is about something deeper than it admits.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is an unforgettable movie experience that left me speechless. From the moment the film began, I was captivated by the story of Andy Dufresne and his journey through the Shawshank State Penitentiary. Tim Robbins delivers a standout performance as Andy, a man who refuses to let his circumstances define him. Meanwhile, Morgan Freeman is equally phenomenal as Red, the wise and witty narrator who serves as a source of inspiration for Andy and the audience.

The film's themes of hope, friendship, and determination are woven seamlessly into the story, creating an emotional rollercoaster that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Frank Darabont's direction is impeccable, bringing the characters and their struggles to life in a way that is both raw and real.

The cinematography and score are also top-notch, adding to the film's overall impact. The stunning shots of Shawshank and the surrounding countryside are a true work of art, while the score effectively sets the mood and amplifies the emotional intensity of each scene.

In conclusion, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a must-watch movie that will leave you inspired, moved, and grateful for the gift of cinema. It's a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll and will leave a lasting impact on your life. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves films that are both thought-provoking and emotionally charged.

Rarely do movies come along that change a persons perspective on life, but for The Shawshank Redemption this statement is granted. From start to finish a beautiful adaptation of what movies are supposed to be like, displaying humanities most important elements, hope, joy, retribution and redemption, they all come into play and thats what makes it a cut above the rest. Society changes views on certain aspects of life but somehow hope always stays at the forefront, for change, for a better life. To change ones situation and to free the soul of a prison of emotion. Shawshank doesn't have special effects or big blockbuster openings and endings, but it does have one thing that is more deep and special, it has a message that appeals to the good in everyone, that no ones situation is indefinite and that where there's hope, there's life.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.
I liked the film from the bottom of my heart. Absolute masterpiece.

This is the film that seems to make people excited that they can tell other film-lovers that they like, because it seems sophisticated. With it's captivating title and the feel-good story of friendship, it's about as complicated as most American movie-goers can get. This can be a decent one to keep on, if you switch to it on TV and have some laundry to fold. However, there are hundreds of films I'd rather watch to stimulate my mind. I would have said thousands but I've only seen slightly over a thousand films so far. I know that many people have a special place for this film in their heart, but they never really seem to stop and ask themselves "why?". Shawshank does have a few, fun gotcha-type moments, and the shot of Andy in the stream after escape is quite memorable. However, the film itself is not one of those birds whose feathers are too bright that "are not meant to be caged." This film needs to stay shelved when we are discussing the greats. It can find itself comfortably and appropriately filed between Shallow Hal and Shiloh.

Based on a novella by Stephen King, it was critically acclaimed upon release, but bizarrely won no Academy Awards, despite being nominated in seven categories.

They'll just have to satisfy themselves with the equally prestigious recognition of being voted the best film of all time by LADbible readers.

As for the other films in the running, they were chosen because of their high-rating on film encyclopedia website IMDb.

Currently, Christopher Nolan's second Batman film holds a rating of 9.0 on the website, as does The Godfather Part II.

The Godfather starring Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, and James Caan - among others - has a rating of 9.1, whereas The Shawshank Redemption rates at 9.2.

All of the films in the running were stone cold classics, but when everything is eventually boiled down, The Shawshank Redemption has it all.

There's 2 kinds of people who watch this film - this who get it and those who don't.

Of the latter category, yeah OK, it is just a film about a couple of guys in prison. It's excellently acted, scripted, directed and filmed. And yeah it does have a great ending.

But there's something more than that. And this is where former category of people come in.

The film is about hope, and living with hope. "Andy Dufrenes" (Tim Robbins) is imprisoned wrongly. Where many people would have given up, he refuses to do so and throughout his time in prison, clings to that hope. A journey of 1000 miles is taken one step at a time.

Contrast this to "Red" (Morgan Freeman). He's become used to being in prison, he's institutionalised, his repeated parole refusals have meant he's give up hope. And like Brooks before him he knows that he wouldn't survive on the outside.

"Get busy living, or get busy dying", says Andy. It's the hope that Andy has carried throughout that provides the salvation, the redemption, for both himself and Red.

I can't recommend this movie highly enough.

The Shawshank Redemption, based on a Stephen King novel, was directed by Frank Darabont.

It's challenging to adapt a book to the big screen (especially if it is a popular book). Due to Mr. Darabont's work, the movie not only respects its source material but also stands on its own.

Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Red (a great example of adding or differentiating an essential part of the original material) makes it new and more effective.

Red's friendship with the protagonist Andy Dufresne (played by Tim Robbins) adds more layers to the story.

Andy's Journey keeps the viewer engaged for the entire length of the film.

Having a flawed and complex protagonist made the story more compelling, and having not two heartless villains alongside The Sisters, gave the audience more reasons to root for Andy.

Also, shout out to Brooks he has the most heart wrenching character arc in the entire film.

Overall a must-see movie that will give us hope and teach us not to give up on anything in life.

I saw the Shawshank Redemption with my parents when it first came out in 1994. I remember being sucked into a story that I could not stop watching. I do not want to give any spoilers, so being as vague as possible... as the story unfolds you start to wonder how the story could possibly end for Andy, and then when the crucial scene comes... wow. This movie has quite probably the best ending in movie history. An ending that has been built all the way throughout the entire movie without you even noticing. I have always thought this was the best movie ever made. When I discovered the IMDb website I was very excited to see that many people must agree with me. If you haven't already noticed, it has been given a 9.2 rating which is the #1 highest movie rating of all time.
Everything about this movie is excellent. The plot, the acting, the suspense, the "realism", so much more. Love it.
Everyone deserves a Oscar for the way each actor has acted in the film.

The cast is superb. A real chemistry seems to bond Robbins, Freeman, and their inner circle. Will Sadler, the stone-faced bad guy in Die Hard 2, steals several scenes as the country-loving Heywood, and Vancouver native Gil Bellows shines as Tommy, the cocky high-school drop-out whose fate is pretty much sealed once we're told he has a wife and baby son waiting for him outside the prison walls. Brown, with his hair trimmed so neatly he's this close to being a dead ringer for Al Gore, displays an obsessive brutality that his Highlander role never hinted at. Freeman delivers a subtle but potent performance, letting just the teeniest dabs of despair leak through the cracks of his easy- going facade. Robbins brings the perfect mixture of fresh-faced bewilderment and canny deceit to his role as Dufresne, handling the dramatic and comic elements with equal ease. Watching these actors work together is a real treat, and they more than make up for the script's deficiencies.

Even though the story is simple it is still timeless with classical motives of friendship, belief, and of justice.

I think everybody should watch it even once because it is entertaining, motivating, and especially satisfying. It all clicks at the end and leaves you fulfilled.

Some day this movie will be considered one of the most essential classical movies of all time!

Interesting that although the hero of the film is the convicted former banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the action is never seen from his point of view. The film's opening scene shows him being given two life sentences for the murder of his wife and her lover, and then we move, permanently, to a point of view representing the prison population and particularly the lifer Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). It is his voice remembering the first time he saw Andy ("looked like a stiff breeze would blow him over"), and predicting, wrongly, that he wouldn't make it in prison.

What an amazing emotional film. Performances are all top notch, and the story is so moving. Tim Robbins as the quiet and introverted Andy gives us a look at performances to come, and Morgan Freeman proves as always he can be counted on to give an authoritative performance. While the name "Stephen King" attached to a film might suggest something in the horror genre, this simple tale of men in prison is so much more. The sublime moments, while small move so much. And the character Brooks deserves special mention too, simply moving. Frank Darabont has created something with this film, and it will stand as one of (if not THE) greatest films ever made for quite some time.

Andy Dufresne has been at Shawshank for 19 years. He spent 19 years of his life in captivity for a murder he did not commit. During this time, he especially told Red and the people around him not to lose hope by turning on small lights in such bad conditions. It's time for Andy to get rid of Shawshank. In his last conversation with Red, he tells her that he has to choose between living fast and dying fast.

Andy makes a will-like request to Red. If he goes out, he says that there is something very important belonging to him under the volcanic glass, a stone that is not of this world and buried under an oak tree in the place he describes. This is one last piece of advice that will keep Red's hopes up.

This film is probably the best life-in-prison film ever made. It depicts one man's time in the big house for something he (supposedly) didn't do. This man is Andy Dusfresne (pronounced Duframe) played in his best ever, Tim Robbins. But he isn't alone; he is joined by fellow inmate (who is the only guilty person in Shawshank) Red played also very well by Morgan Freeman. Freeman narrates the life in The Shawshank prison all the way up until the end (not to mention some very memorable escape scenes). Very memorable, showing what movies are made of. Based on Stephen King's novel (one of his best) and adapted for the screen and directed by Frank Darabont, who 5 years later would write and direct the Green Mile, another good (but can't be matched to this one) prison movie. This is a movie that stands the test of time and still resonates with viewers. Call this the Stand by Me of prison stories. Stephen King, who penned Stand by Me, also wrote the short story on which The Shawshank Redemption is based. Here we have all the things that made Stand by Me such a satisfying experience: lovable characters, writer flourishes, one- dimensional evil antagonists, enduring friendships, poetic justice, and a happy ending. This one is far darker and far more violent than Stand by Me and so ought to be reserved only for older teens. The story is slow to develop, and younger kids and children sensitive to the suffering of others may find this world a difficult one to sit with for the film's duration.

This film has a special place in my heart. It starts with setting a brief premise to the overall cause of 'How our protagonist ended up in the Shawshank?', and which serves the purpose. Latter the story opens up with more characters, their perspective on life, and their course of activities which they assume are necessary to survive in Shawshank. Although Andy is the main protagonist, the movie also gives its supporting cast good opportunities, which gives the story a more mature, realistic, and solid foundation.

The story opens up layer by layer and throws you into the heart of Shawshank, where you can observe its analogies with human life brilliantly depicted by eye-soothing cinematography and exceptionally well-written screenplay. At its core, it's a story of faith and hope.

This film is a remarkably best example of setting a difference between 'Reaction and Response' to unfortunate incidents in our life. While everybody was busy reacting to these events, licking them till they bleed again, Andy was busy engraving his future in Zihuatanejo.

The narrative let you feel the experiences of the protagonist at the time of his stay in Shawshank. The enormous tragedies that lie between Andy and his salvation will astound you. Andy's selfless actions are the highlights of his journey in Shawshank, which defines pure Karma. His belief in tiny actions and unprecedented faith in hope is the backbone of the Shawshank Redemption.

The experience of a lifetime, definitely recommended watching it.

The Shawshank Redemption is written and directed by Frank Darabont. It is an adaptation of the Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. Starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, the film portrays the story of Andy Dufresne (Robbins), a banker who is sentenced to two life sentences at Shawshank State Prison for apparently murdering his wife and her lover. Andy finds it tough going but finds solace in the friendship he forms with fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding (Freeman). While things start to pick up when the warden finds Andy a prison job more befitting his talents as a banker. However, the arrival of another inmate is going to vastly change things for all of them.

Can Hollywood, usually creating things for entertainment purposes only, create art? To create something of this nature, a director must approach it in a most meticulous manner, due to the delicacy of the process. Such a daunting task requires an extremely capable artist with an undeniable managerial capacity and an acutely developed awareness of each element of art in their films, the most prominent; music, visuals, script, and acting. These elements, each equally important, must succeed independently, yet still form a harmonious union, because this mixture determines the fate of the artist's opus. Though already well known amongst his colleagues for his notable skills at writing and directing, Frank Darabont emerges with his feature film directorial debut, The Shawshank Redemption. Proving himself already a master of the craft, Darabont managed to create one of the most recognizable independent releases in the history of Hollywood. The Shawshank Redemption defines a genre, defies the odds, compels the emotions, and brings an era of artistically influential films back to Hollywood.

The story begins with the trial of a young banker, Andy Dufrense, victimized by circumstantial evidence, resulting in a conviction for the murder of his wife and her lover. After a quick conviction, Andy finds himself serving a life sentence at Shawshank prison, with no hope of parole. He exists in this prison only in appearance, keeping his mind free from the drab walls around him. His ability to do this results in the gaining of respect from his fellow inmates, but most of all from Ellis Redding. Ellis, commonly referred to as Red, finds gainful use of his entrepreneurial spirit within the drab walls of Shawshank by dealing in contraband and commodities rare to the confines of prison. Andy's demeanor and undeniable sense of hope causes Red to take a deeper look at himself, and the world around him. Andy proves to Red and the other inmates that in the conventional walls of Shawshank prison convention will find no home in his lifestyle.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate audiences with its powerful storytelling and outstanding performances. The film follows the journey of Andy Dufresne, a man who is wrongly convicted of murder and sent to Shawshank prison. The bond that develops between Andy and fellow inmate Red is at the heart of the film, as is the exploration of hope, redemption, and the human spirit. The film's pacing is perfect, with each scene building on the last to create an emotionally charged and unforgettable experience. The performances by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman are nothing short of brilliant, and their chemistry on screen is a joy to watch. "The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic triumph that should be on every movie lover's must-watch list.

'The Shawshank Redemption' is a very popular, successful and classic drama film. But is this movie worth watching? Well, the answer is more than "yes".

Based on Stephen King's novel of the same name, the story focuses on Andy Dufresne, who is suspected of killing his wife and her lover. After Andy is found guilty and sent to Shawshank Prison, he becomes friends with Red, one of the inmates. During his many years in prison, he realizes something very powerful: hope is the only thing that can set him free.

The whole plot of the movie is brilliant, the characters (and of course the actors playing them) are great, and so on. In conclusion, this movie is a true masterpiece.
This is an engagingly simple, good-hearted film, with just enough darkness around the edges to give contrast and relief to its glowingly benign view of human nature.

"The Shawshank Redemption," directed by Frank Darabont, is an absolute gem of a film that continues to resonate with audiences even decades after its release. It is a remarkable adaptation of Stephen King's novella, skillfully crafted with precision and emotional depth. Seamlessly blending elements of drama, friendship, and hope, this cinematic masterpiece stands as a testament to the power of the human spirit to triumph over adversity.

At the heart of "The Shawshank Redemption" is its extraordinary storytelling. Darabont's direction is masterful, capturing the essence of the prison environment with both raw authenticity and a touch of poetic beauty. The narrative unfolds in a deliberate and engaging manner, carefully balancing moments of despair with glimmers of hope. The pacing is deliberate, allowing the audience to connect deeply with the characters and their struggles, creating an emotional resonance that is hard to shake off.

The film's central performances are nothing short of extraordinary. Tim Robbins delivers a tour de force portrayal as Andy Dufresne, a man wrongly convicted of murder who finds solace and purpose within the confines of Shawshank State Penitentiary. Robbins exudes a quiet strength and determination, embodying Andy's resilience and unwavering belief in his own innocence. Opposite Robbins, Morgan Freeman delivers a career-defining performance as Red, the wise and worldly inmate who becomes Andy's closest confidant. Freeman's narration, with its soulful and melodic timbre, adds a layer of richness and introspection to the story.

"The Shawshank Redemption" excels in its portrayal of the complexities of human relationships. The friendships that develop within the prison walls are poignant and genuine, offering glimmers of light amidst the darkness. The camaraderie among the inmates is palpable, showcasing the profound impact of genuine connections and shared experiences. These relationships not only serve as a source of emotional support but also illustrate the transformative power of empathy, compassion, and redemption.

Visually, "The Shawshank Redemption" captures the stark reality of prison life while infusing moments of visual poetry. Roger Deakins' cinematography is both atmospheric and evocative, capturing the oppressive nature of the prison environment while also highlighting the beauty and freedom that lie just beyond the walls. The muted color palette reflects the somber tone of the narrative, yet moments of vibrant intensity are carefully woven throughout, underscoring the characters' pursuit of liberation and self-discovery.

The film's score by Thomas Newman is a work of art in itself. It weaves a tapestry of emotions, guiding the audience through the highs and lows of the characters' journeys. From moments of melancholy reflection to triumphant crescendos, the music beautifully enhances the film's emotional impact, creating an immersive experience that lingers long after the credits roll.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a film that transcends its prison setting to explore universal themes of hope, resilience, and the indomitable human spirit. It reminds us of the transformative power of kindness, friendship, and the unwavering belief in the possibility of redemption. Through its nuanced storytelling, impeccable performances, and powerful visuals, the film leaves an indelible mark on the viewer, evoking a range of emotions and inspiring introspection.

The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont, based on the 1982 Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. It tells the story of banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who is sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary for the murders of his wife and her lover, despite his claims of innocence. Over the following two decades, he befriends a fellow prisoner, contraband smuggler Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), and becomes instrumental in a money-laundering operation led by the prison warden Samuel Norton (Bob Gunton). William Sadler, Clancy Brown, Gil Bellows, and James Whitmore appear in supporting roles.

Darabont purchased the film rights to King's story in 1987, but development did not begin until five years later, when he wrote the script over an eight-week period. Two weeks after submitting his script to Castle Rock Entertainment, Darabont secured a $25 million budget to produce The Shawshank Redemption, which started pre-production in January 1993. While the film is set in Maine, principal photography took place from June to August 1993 almost entirely in Mansfield, Ohio, with the Ohio State Reformatory serving as the eponymous penitentiary. The project attracted many stars of the time for the role of Andy, including Tom Hanks, Tom Cruise, and Kevin Costner. Thomas Newman provided the film's score.

The Shawshank Redemption is a classic film that has made an indelible mark on the film industry and stands as a testament to the power of storytelling. Directed and written by Frank Darabont, the movie stars Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, and tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker wrongly-convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. The film follows Andy's journey from prison to freedom, where he finds liberation in the most unlikely of places.

Tim Robbins does an incredible job of portraying Andy's journey, from a broken and scared man to one who triumphs against all odds. He embodies the character with a quiet strength and unwavering determination, showing the audience Andy's never-ending will to survive. Morgan Freeman's role as Red is equally impressive, adding a layer of wisdom and wit to the story. His character provides the perfect foil to Robbins' Andy, and the chemistry between the two is palpable.

The Shawshank Redemption is an excellent example of how a powerful story can still have a lasting impact on viewers, even decades later. It's a powerful reminder of the importance of resilience in the face of adversity and the power of friendship to carry us through even the toughest times. The film also teaches us that no matter how bleak the situation may seem, there is still hope, and that with the right mindset, anything is possible.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a film that will leave you in stitches... from laughter! This hilarious prison comedy-drama follows the adventures of Andy Dufresne, a wrongly convicted banker who finds himself locked up in the Shawshank State Penitentiary.

Andy is played by Tim Robbins, who gives a truly comedic performance as the bumbling and often clueless prisoner. His interactions with the other inmates, including the lovable and charismatic Red (played by Morgan Freeman), will have you in hysterics.

The film's script is also chock full of comedic moments, including the iconic scene where Andy tricks the warden into playing Mozart over the loudspeakers, sending the prison into a state of chaos.

But it's not just the laughs that make "The Shawshank Redemption" such a great film. The incredible set design and cinematography also add to the comedic effect, with the prison looking like a cross between a haunted house and a cartoon.

Overall, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a film that will have you laughing, crying, and calling your friends to tell them how much you loved it. Don't miss it!

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic masterpiece that tells a poignant and powerful story about the human spirit. Directed by Frank Darabont, the film is based on a Stephen King novella and features outstanding performances from its lead actors, Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman.

The film is set in a conservative prison in the mid-20th century, and it explores themes of hope, redemption, and the resilience of the human spirit. The characters are complex and multifaceted, and their journeys are both inspiring and heart-wrenching. The film's pacing is deliberate and thoughtful, allowing the story to unfold in a way that is both satisfying and emotionally resonant.

The cinematography and production design are top-notch, creating a gritty and realistic world that draws the viewer in and immerses them in the story. The musical score is also notable, perfectly complementing the film's tone and mood.

Overall, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a must-see film that will leave a lasting impression on anyone who watches it. It is a timeless classic that has earned its place in the pantheon of great American films, and it is a testament to the power of cinema to move and inspire us.

I saw this movie yesterday again. First time I saw it I was 13, and I had already loved it. The pleasure and sensations felt while watching this picture are difficult to describe. It had been a long time since I had last felt this way about a movie. I was completely submersed in the plot, all my mind concentrated in the facts of the movie. One loses connection with reality and, for some time, one's life disappears and the movie becomes one's life. This is the sign that indicates us that we are in presence of a great masterpiece. The plot is a beautiful story about hope, freedom and friendship. The cast couldn't be better: both Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman (one of the greatest actors of all time, when are they going to give him an Oscar?) are superb in the leading roles. Supporting cast is great too, especially veteran James Whitmore. Thomas Newton composed the music, which perfectly supports the scenes in an extremely subtle, but at the same time incredibly effective way. It brings sensibility to the images without using sentimental tricks. And this is one of the great qualities of the movie: it's moving and evocative, without ever being sentimental. Sentimental music could have ruined the movie, but Thomas Newman made a great job. The director of photography is Roger Deakins, who has already astonished us with the amazing black and white photography of "The man who wasn't there". A masterpiece.

This gem of a movie The Shawshank Redemption, ironically, was snubbed during its time (1994)---both critically and commercially. In recent years, however, there's a growing legion of cineastes singling out this film as the best, if not, one of the best of all time.

This movie is the perfect example of a masterpiece way ahead of its time. Take it as Beethoven's Symphony #5 of cinema. Years go by and the echo of its message gets louder and becomes even more relevant. It's about how we are defined by the establishment's greed and corruption.

It's about how we have forgotten our humanity.

It's about why our possessions, especially money, continue to deny us of the ever-elusive happiness we all yearn for.

It's about our capability to love our fellowmen under any circumstances.

Most importantly, it's about life as a matter of choice and how we can outdo the fear that imprisons us in misery. If only we tap our power from within. As its main message suggests, "Fear can hold us prisoner. Hope can set us free."

It is underrated and over qualified.

My criteria: unlike The Godfather, The Shawshank Redemption does not only grip the viewer's heart. It zaps the audience to boldly declare: LIFE IS AMAZINGLY BEAUTIFUL!

As a movie lover, I can confidently say that "The Shawshank Redemption" is a film that every cinema enthusiast must watch at least once in their lifetime. This movie has everything that makes for a great film - a captivating storyline, brilliant performances, powerful emotions, and an unforgettable ending.

The movie is set in the 1940s and tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a successful banker who is wrongly convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is sentenced to life in prison and is sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary, where he is subjected to brutal treatment from the prison staff and fellow inmates.

The Shawshank Redemption, directed by Frank Darabont, is an extraordinary film that leaves an indelible mark on the viewer's soul. Adapted from a Stephen King novella, this cinematic gem stands the test of time, continuing to captivate audiences with its profound storytelling, impeccable performances, and themes of hope, friendship, and redemption.

One of the film's greatest strengths lies in its ability to create a rich and authentic atmosphere. The Shawshank State Penitentiary becomes a character in itself, with its towering walls, dimly lit corridors, and palpable sense of confinement. Through masterful cinematography, the film captures the claustrophobic nature of prison life while juxtaposing it with moments of breathtaking beauty, reminding us that hope can flourish even in the darkest of places.

The performances in The Shawshank Redemption are nothing short of exceptional. Tim Robbins delivers a nuanced portrayal of Andy, embodying a quiet strength and resilience that is truly inspiring. Morgan Freeman's narration, as well as his portrayal of Red, adds an extra layer of depth to the story, his soothing voice becoming the guiding voice of reason and wisdom.

The screenplay by Frank Darabont is a work of art, seamlessly weaving together multiple narratives and characters into a coherent and deeply moving tale. Each character is well-developed, with their own flaws, hopes, and dreams. The relationships between the prisoners, especially the bond between Andy and Red, are beautifully explored, reminding us of the power of human connection in even the harshest of circumstances.

At its core, The Shawshank Redemption is a story of hope and the enduring human spirit. It explores the themes of friendship, resilience, and the quest for redemption with a rare sincerity that lingers long after the film ends. It reminds us that no matter how dire the circumstances, there is always a glimmer of hope, a reason to keep fighting and believing in a better tomorrow.

With its compelling narrative, superb performances, and profound themes, The Shawshank Redemption stands tall as a masterpiece of cinema. It is a film that reminds us of the power of storytelling to touch hearts, challenge perceptions, and ignite the flames of hope within us. Even years after its release, it continues to inspire and resonate, making it a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the power of cinema to move and transform.
