The Shawshank Redemption is a film that has captivated audiences since its release in 1994. Directed by Frank Darabont and based on Stephen King's novella, this cinematic gem has become a beloved classic and is often hailed as one of the greatest movies of all time. Some essential things make The Shawshank Redemption a must-watch and explore its enduring appeal.

The Plot: At its core, The Shawshank Redemption follows the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is wrongfully convicted of murder and sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary. Within the confines of this harsh environment, Andy befriends a fellow inmate, Ellis "Red" Redding, portrayed brilliantly by Morgan Freeman. Through their unlikely bond, the narrative unfolds, weaving a tale of hope, resilience, and the power of friendship. The film takes the audience on an emotional rollercoaster as they witness Andy's relentless pursuit of freedom and eventual redemption.

Cinematic Excellence: One cannot discuss The Shawshank Redemption without acknowledging the impeccable execution of its various elements. From the compelling performances to the seamless direction, every aspect of the film contributes to its brilliance. Tim Robbins delivers a powerhouse performance as Andy, effortlessly portraying the character's intelligence, strength, and unwavering determination. The chemistry between Robbins and Freeman is palpable, enhancing the authenticity of their friendship and making it the heart of the movie.

The Shawshank Redemption also stands out for its visually stunning cinematography. The deliberate use of color palettes and lighting techniques adds depth and symbolism to each scene, effectively immersing the viewer into the world of Shawshank. The hauntingly beautiful score by Thomas Newman complements the narrative perfectly, evoking a wide range of emotions that stay with the audience even after the credits roll.

Themes of Hope and Redemption: One of the main reasons The Shawshank Redemption resonates with audiences is its exploration of profound themes. The film depicts the indomitable power of hope amidst despair and the transformative nature of redemption. Through the character of Andy, we witness his unwavering belief in the possibility of a better future, inspiring others around him to hold onto their own dreams. The movie serves as a reminder that no matter how dire the circumstances may be, the human spirit can triumph against all odds.

Movie's importance: The Shawshank Redemption may not have achieved commercial success upon its initial release, but it garnered widespread critical acclaim and has since gained a dedicated following. Its enduring popularity can be attributed to its universal themes, nuanced storytelling, and exceptional performances. Over the years, the film has been celebrated for its profound messages of hope, friendship, and the resilience of the human spirit.

The Shawshank Redemption is a cinematic masterpiece that continues to captivate audiences and inspire viewers around the world. Its timeless tale of hope, friendship, and redemption resonates with audiences of all generations, making it a truly remarkable film. From the stellar performances to the expert direction, every aspect of this movie contributes to its enduring legacy. Whether you are a fan of drama, crime, or simply appreciate storytelling at its finest, The Shawshank Redemption is a must-watch that will leave a lasting impact on your heart and mind.

Shawshank has somehow transcended the test of time; and I believe that it has endured, not because of the great performances (which don't seem to be acting at all, but real), not because of the simple, but multi-level, story line with its twists and turns,

The Shawshank Redemption is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece. Every frame, every line of dialogue, and every performance in this film is a testament to the power of storytelling and filmmaking.

First and foremost, the performances are absolutely stellar. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman deliver performances that are nothing short of iconic. Robbins' portrayal of Andy Dufresne is a tour de force, imbuing the character with a quiet strength and determination that is truly compelling. Freeman's portrayal of Red is equally mesmerizing, with his wise and soulful narration providing a perfect counterpoint to Robbins' character.

The screenplay, adapted from Stephen King's novella by Frank Darabont, is a work of art in itself. The dialogue is sharp, poignant, and often laced with a dark humor that adds depth to the narrative. The pacing is impeccable, allowing the story to unfold with a sense of both urgency and deliberation, keeping the audience engaged from start to finish.

One of the most striking aspects of The Shawshank Redemption is its ability to evoke a wide range of emotions. From moments of heart-wrenching despair to soaring triumphs of the human spirit, the film takes its audience on an emotional rollercoaster that leaves a lasting impact.

The cinematography by Roger Deakins is nothing short of breathtaking. The way he captures the starkness of prison life juxtaposed with moments of transcendent beauty is a visual feast for the eyes. The use of light and shadow, particularly in the iconic "Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption" scene, is a testament to Deakins' mastery of his craft.

Moreover, Thomas Newman's hauntingly beautiful score serves as the perfect musical backdrop to the story. It weaves seamlessly with the narrative, enhancing the emotional resonance of each scene.

Beyond its technical brilliance, The Shawshank Redemption is a story of hope, friendship, and the enduring power of the human spirit. It reminds us that even in the darkest of circumstances, there is the potential for redemption and the possibility of finding meaning and purpose.

i love movies!!! i really truly do. i realize that everyone on thisplanet has a love of their life. it may be a guy or a girl. it may be a sport, or it maybe a hobby or skill. for me, i love movies! i strongly believe in my heart that everyone loves movies in theor own special way. they all can have an effect on us in their own very special way. thats what makes them special. what films are special to you? i love asking that question becuase you would be amazed with the types of responses you might here! iwas once asked that question seriously about a month ago. " tanner, what film is the most special to you?" it took me about 2 seconds to give a response! it was easy....." THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION."

everyone has a moment or two in their life that stands out above th rest. they are those special moments that will live with you for the rest of your life. i also find that these special moments come at time when you are least expecting it. when i sat down for the first time top watch this masterpiece i felt that i was going to be in for anything but..... i knew absolutley nothing about this film except it was a prison drama and it was long....wow....i was really on the edge of my seat! about 2 hours and 30 minutes later when the credits began to roll against that beautiful heavenly landscape i could only think one thing.... " this will forever be the greatest motion picute i have ever seen!"

when one talks about their favorite all-time movie one usually hears the same responses: THE GODFATHER, SCHINDLER'S LIST, CITIZEN KANE, CASABLANCA.... these are the usual nominees. i have been thrilled to see THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION being added to this nominee list more frequently! why is this happening? it is truly one of the all- time great hollywood stories! the film came out in 1994 to dismal boxoffice and while it received strong reviews...it failed to gather an audience. this even proved to be true when the film gatherd 7 oscar nominations including best picture. than....when it seemed as if this film had been lost forever a miracle happened.....it came to video and television. becoming more and more praised through word of mouth on video, the film reached a new public view when it premiered on TNT to a record viewing audience for a film. the film sincer than has become nothing short of the "ITS WONDERFUL LIFE" of hte 21st century!!! it meens that much to people!

why is this filmed loved and appreciated by so many people? i beleive the answer is oh so simple. the film is unlike any love story ever made; the film is a love story between two men! we become increasingly involved with these two men as we learn about them. we eventually begin to care deeply about these men and their friendship. the wonderful, music, cinematography, and direction bring us a film and a story that has touched our hearts in a way that no other story has before. this film focuses on the two greatest thems in all of life: hope and friendship! we learn through the film that one cannot exist without the other....just as andy and red cannot live without their beautiful friendship formed against all odds.

as we are shown throughout the film the many unnecassary horrors and butalities life can bring, then we are shown as the clouds break....just how wonderful, special, and beautiful life can be. this film accomplishes this task like no other film has in history.

walk with andy and red as their friendship grows into a love none of these men thought could ever exit for them again. we see them as their friendship brings a light into lives that we all dream about, but seldom find. its that darn good!!!!!

so....what am i finally getting at. if there ever comes a day in your life when you might lose sight of all the glory and beauty that is life.....if you ever want to see what can happen if you have hope.....if you ever want to know that a happy ending does truly exist for all of us in the end.... sit down, place the film in your vcr...and be prepared to see a display of all these themes of life in a light that you cant even imagine!!! "GET BUSY LIVI'N....OR GET BUSY DYI'N....thats dam right!!!!"

"Schindler's List" is an emotionally devastating masterpiece that powerfully captures the horrors of the Holocaust while also celebrating the indomitable human spirit. Steven Spielberg's direction is nothing short of brilliant, and Liam Neeson's portrayal of Oskar Schindler is hauntingly poignant, making this film a timeless testament to the capacity for good in the face of unspeakable evil. The black-and-white cinematography, the haunting score by John Williams, and the outstanding performances from the entire cast combine to create an unforgettable cinematic experience that leaves a profound impact on the viewer. "Schindler's List" is a harrowing, essential work of art that serves as a stark reminder of the atrocities of the past and the importance of never forgetting them.

The Good: The story is Epic. The acting is top notch. The message is sublime. The writing is off the charts. The cinematography is superb. The soundtrack (when there is music) is great and even symbolic to the story. You want a movie that excellently tells a story about I guy going to prison and at the same time demonstrates the universal value of self-forgiveness,patience, and sear determination ? THIS is the movie and THIS is how you do it.

The Bad: None. One of the few films I give 10/10,

The Ugly: Hahhahaha. If you think there is any ugly in this movie, may Morgan Freeman have mercy on soul. Just watch the movie.

The Shawshank Redemption isn't just a film-it's an experience, a poignant exploration of human endurance in the face of profound adversity. Set against the grim backdrop of a maximum-security prison, this narrative seamlessly intertwines themes of injustice, friendship, and indomitable hope. Robbins delivers a beautifully understated performance as Andy Dufresne, while Freeman's portrayal of Red is both captivating and heartfelt, offering a voice that guides us through the shadowy confines of Shawshank. Director Frank Darabont's storytelling prowess shines, turning Stephen King's novella into a cinematic triumph that resonates deeply. Its powerful climax and memorable score leave a lasting impact, making it a compelling watch, time and again. This film isn't just one of my all-time favorites-it's a testament to the resilience of the human spirit and an absolute must-see for every cinephile.

I think that those who are saying that the movie is unoriginal is unaware of what a sequal is. It is the same demon, so some of the same things will still occur. It differs from the original in that there are a couple of jump scares, and the entire way around getting an exorcism is different. The fact that the possessed girl goes into a chick has only been done in one other movie, that I can think of, and that's one of that annabelle movies. I think that others are comparing it to other 2023 horror movies where you much be at the edge of your seat the entire time, while that is just not the case for the original (when viewing now), or the new version of it. It makes amazing references to the first movie, and was honestly one of the best horror movie "sequals" that has come out from an original in the last few years.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a 1994 dramatic film and adaptation written and directed by Frank Darabont. Inspired by Stephen King's story "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption".

The film is about the wrongful imprisonment of a banker named Andy Dufresne and his life in prison. Despite being wrongfully accused, Andy remains hopeful and humane and fosters change by forming friendships among the inmates. "The Redemption of Slavery" deals with universal themes such as not losing the goodness and hope within man, friendship, freedom and justice.

The acting performances of Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, the emotional depth and character development in the film were praised by the audience. The film has achieved cult status over time and is among the best films in cinema history. It is considered a production that is both critically successful and loved by audiences.
This movie is just simply fantastic. Every scene is perfect. I had a very good time watching it. It is definitely a must-see.

It's deeply in your mind, only one thing really belongs to you, no one can touch it..." How I hope it's a true story... It's best story I've ever known, it's the best movie I've ever seen.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic masterpiece that delves deep into the human spirit's resilience. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman deliver compelling performances, portraying the enduring friendship between two prisoners. The film's poignant narrative, gripping plot twists, and themes of hope and redemption make it a timeless classic that resonates with audiences across generations. With its powerful storytelling and emotive storytelling, "The Shawshank Redemption" remains a must-watch for all movie enthusiasts. Darabont's direction, coupled with Stephen King's poignant storytelling, creates an unforgettable cinematic experience that continues to resonate with viewers worldwide.

One of the ways that I figure out if a movie is really good or not is by watching it several times and seeing if it keeps my interest.

Some movies are just good movies with people that you associate with and like to be around. "Forrest Gump".

Some movies make you envy the star or the character and make you a better person for the watching (Gary Cooper in High Noon).

Some movies are just cool (Pulp Fiction).

This movie is one you want to watch because you feel the respect between two men, the determination of one man, and the power of friendship. Watching Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman develop their relationship over the course of 20+ years is a journey you don't want to miss and a journey that you enjoy seeing over and over again. The grit and determination to survive in a world that was so alien to Andy is a revelation on the human spirit.

Finally the friendship that Andy and Red developed, kept Red from committing another crime just to go back to something safe and familiar. This is a testimony to the ability for one man to truly change the life of another. This is one of the three best movies of the 90's and one of the best films of all time.

Having read Stephen King's short story when it was first published I never would have predicted it would be made into a movie. It is a simple film, yet it has an everlasting message. Frank Darabont didn't need to put any kind of outlandish special effects to get us to love this film, the narration and the acting does that for him. THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION is a kind of morality tale that is definitely one of Stephen King's more restrained kind of stories, dealing mostly with a character study of two individuals sharing imprisonment and the consequences that await them when the tale ends.

TIM ROBBINS is a man wrongly convicted of murder and serving a long prison term while MORGAN FREEMAN (who plays the narrator with great dignity) describes himself as "the only guilty man in Shawshank." The hardships of prison life are captured in brief scenes that make the viewer wish that Robbins will find a way of escape.

Along the way, he is gang raped by prisoners and treated harshly by a brutal warden and some of his spirit seems to vanish. But Robbins is quietly effective as a prisoner who makes a good adjustment when he takes charge of the prison library and sees to it that there's a wider selection of books than the kind of potboilers that King is noted for writing. A touch of irony here, no? The closing scenes are a bit of a stretch and a reminder of just who wrote this prison tale--but still, they make an impact because of all that happens before.

It's a bittersweet story, a sort of horrific fairy-tale of what might have happened, but the viewer will be caught up in the story because of the tremendously skillful story-telling magic of Stephen King and director Frank Darabont who also wrote the screenplay.
The movie was just brilliant. Just the right actors had been picked and the movie was just great. I recommend sincerely if you haven't already seen it.

Shawshank is different. I have seen this movie, literally, hundreds of times. I watch every time I see it on TV. I will never tire of it. It is as close to perfect as a movie can be. It evokes every human emotion you can imagine, but never allows itself to mire in any of them. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins are superb. James Whitmore as the "institutionalized" Brooks Hatlen, just breaks my heart in his last few scenes. You grow to truly care about these people. The ending is just and satisfying and makes you think, even if only for a few minutes, that everything will be right with the world.

First, I would like to say I did not see this film when it originally came out in the movies. The trailers and the fact it was a "prison" film never interested me. My manager recommended it about three years ago to me when I was looking for films to rent on a cold snowy weekend. Because it did have Morgan Freeman in it, I made a mental note and said to myself, "If its available I may give it a go". All my manager would tell me was it was "long, drawn out and tedious" but that I should hang with it cause it would be "well worth the wait". Now he's a decent manager but our lifestyles are so different outside of work, I was like "yeah right. He would recommend something that I would like." But it was available and I rented it. I held on to it for seven days, about to just take it back since it was due without watching it but hey--I hated to feel like I wasted money.

I watched it and I did not waste my money.

This has become to me one of the best films I have ever seen(so far) in my life. It was long but I got into it slowly, methodically and so captivatingly, the time drifted slowly. Sucking me in, I could hardly know what to expect. And what I expected didn't happen and I just was transfixed. Tim Robbins to me was brilliant. He painstakingly went through those years, aging and moving forward through all the disappointments, growth and experiences as if he were in a long chess game. I became so caught up I could not even begin to think about how this would turn out all the stories and events.

And when the end came, I was just blown away by it. I truly loved all performances and so many "character actors" now are faces and names I know and they all performed well and are remembered in my head when I see them--for this movie.

I find myself recommending it now to people and I too ask them to "hang with it. its well worth the wait".
Never gets old. A masterpiece and worth watching more than once. Little details emerge that you might not have noticed first time round.
The best movie I've seen so far. it is from 1994 but it is still in the top

There is something in each one of us, which nobody can touch, defile or pollute. That is our sacred place where resides our strength, hopes, dreams and character.

What this movie amazingly shows us is that it is possible to access our strength and keep alive our hopes when situations would otherwise defeat us.

I have seen Shawshank 3 times over a span of 8 years. I can't see it again and again as it hurts...it's so perfect. When I viewed the movie for the first time, all by myself, it was on a cold winter morning. Who would go and see a movie 9 am on a regular working/week day (college, actually)? But the international film festival was on in my city and it was the last screening of the movie in the festival. So I missed some lectures, rode through the morning fog, and sat long after the projector was switched off in the theater to an incredible movie experience. The press and public had given the Shawshank a standing ovation that day.

And I was aching to share it. So saw the movie again, once with my father and once recently with my husband.

Just now when I happened to see the Top movies listed on IMDb and that Shawshank is listed at no.2, I was hit by the memory of that cold winter morning.

And when I clicked away and read other viewers comments, I noticed how majority of them remember vividly the how, when and where they had seen this film for the first time. For most, like me, it was an unforgettable thing.

Just wanted to applaud the voters at IMDb to give Shawshank the right spot on all time top movies. I went and registered with the web site right now, just that I too could add a vote in its favor.

9 out of 10!
A stunning example of the craft of film making in all aspects.

I am sorry to say that one who hasn’t seen ‘Shawshank Redemption’ hasn’t had experienced any good English films yet. But I was wondering how such an awesome film could be deprived of an Oscar and to add a pinch of salt to injuries, I was zapped to find that ‘Forest Gump’ was considered as best pictures, Robert Zemeckis as best director and Tom Hanks for best actor. No offence, I am a die hard fan of Tom Hanks. Not to mention his performance in ‘Philadelphia’, Oscar was written all over it. But in ‘Forest Gump’!!!!! He could have got it in ‘Cast Away’ had ‘Russell Crowe not been there in ‘Gladiator’. But in ‘Forest Gump’ in comparison to ‘Morgan Freeman’ in ‘Shawshank Redemption’, I personally don’t buy the idea. As far as ‘Best Picture’ is concerned, again how in the world could ‘Forest Gump’ earn the best picture award when ‘Pulp Fiction’ & ‘Shaw shank Redemption’ were there in the proximity? One of the prime features of ‘Shawshank Redemption’ is its dialogues, so heart rending. The cinematography, acting of Tim Robbins, (Andy Dufresne) an innocent banker, sentenced 30years back to back is so brilliantly executed and ‘Morgan Freeman’ my man, my ‘Red’ is simply outstanding. It is his best performance till date (Don’t know about ‘Invictus’ though (2010)) and to me it is undoubtedly better than ‘Million Dollar Baby’ (in which he finally got the Oscar). I personally feel sorry for Frank Darabont, ‘Shawshank’ is probably the best film of his life. A rare gem did not get its true worth. No wonder it is no. 1 out of the top 250 films on IMDb, (9.2 out of 10). I give it 10.

No spoilers here.

A remarkable Stephen King penned story. King has often found ways of getting to wonder about even our most strongly held values. Most consider people in prison as throwaway members of society, and those that guard the prisons as public servants. King twists this into the protagonist prisoner (Robbins) against the hopelessness of prison and the brutal display of power by the warden. The story is beautifully narrated by Morgan Freeman as ex-con Red.

It lost out to Tom Hanks' portrayal of Forrest Gump for Best Picture, which is a shame, but I'll never forget the impact it made on me.

The film has an edge, and a heart. I couldn't recommend it enough.
This movie change my life forever..all time best movie.

In 1994 I saw Pulp Fiction in the theater 5 times. I was obsessed with it. Still am...it's my #2, and on occasion, #1. But there was another film I saw multiple times in the theater in '94 - The Shawshank Redemption.

And this one, hardly anyone saw in the theater. Nobody really knew about it, until all of a sudden it was nominated for Best Picture and lots more Oscars. But honestly no one in the world thought it would win, I'm sure the Vegas odds were laughable. And of course Forrest Gump overshadowed both Shawshank & Pulp Fiction.

So Shawshank was my film for years, I found it - randomly at my local theater. I owned it on VHS, I watched it incessantly. It's been my favorite film for 20 years.

It's well known it gained a cult following on VHS. But IMDb really put it on the map. And IMDb is to be thanked for the last 7 or 8 years, of idiots who've just come into the film recently claiming it's "a trendy film to claim as your favorite." I want to get physically violent with people who say that. Rather, it's trendy for idiots to say it's trendy to love Shawshank.

Yes, friendship is the key theme of the movie that propels the plot till the very last shot of the film since the beginning of the narration but apart from the main theme of film being hope and friendship, this film strongly con-notates the power of patience and persistence.

Would not like to talk about the entire story here but next time you watch this, just take a close look at Andy, and the way he holds his emotion at the beginning in the court and till the very end when he wears the polished shoe of Warden, no doubt there is deep sorrow and regret but above all, a sign of hope and his patience to make things happen is always there throughout the movie-be it winning to get the books, more books or even beer for his friends despite he doesn't drink himself.

Well, I always discover so many hidden subtle meanings every time I watch this, I loose track of the information and the key things but for sure, apart of Hope and Friendship thing, patience and persistence tops the reason why is film is so courageous in its way.

The depiction of brutal injustice and hopelessness in this movie is utterly convincing. I was totally taken in, and by 80% of the way through was dreading the end: on the one hand, I knew that stagnation, institutionalization and hopelessness are the fates to be expected in the U. S. prison system, and would not be disappointed or surprised to see an end similar to the beginning in those regards; on the other hand, I hoped for some kind of positive uplift at the end. Unfortunately I was disappointed in both expectations. The Hollywood ending was too contrived and unbelievable to maintain the high level of realism of the first part of the movie.

1. You cannot tunnel through 15 feet of concrete with a rock hammer, even in 20 years. 2. A Portland newspaper cannot banner-headline a prison corruption story, ever. 3. The Warden could have notified all the banks to expect an escapee masquerading as a customer before Dufresne could have withdrawn funds from 10 banks. Have you tried to close a bank account recently? 4. Dufresne could not have kept his suit and papers intact crawling through 500 yards of sewer pipe.

Etc., etc. No ending is better than a contrived feel-good ending. Were the producers concerned that we might be too inspired to advocate prison reform unless they gave us a shot of feel-good at the end? Fortunately the power and artistic perfection of the first part of the movie dominates.

Very disturbing and powerful. I am grateful for the conversation it inspired between my stepdaughter, my girlfriend and myself this morning. We ranged over the Massachusetts Geoghan case, the death penalty, criminal justice in the U. s. vs. China, and the thousands of movies that do NOT have Hollywood endings.

`The Shawshank Redemption' tells the story of wrongly accused murderer, Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) and his story of survival inside a maximum-security prison. As Andy enters Shawshank prison, he soon realizes his innocence doesn't matter. He's in a place where everybody thinks they are innocent. Andy is portrayed from the view of a second person, and most of the time we see what this second person sees. He meets Ellis `Red' Reddings (Morgan Freeman), the man who can get things from the outside. Red was able to obtain almost anything the prisoners want, but always for a price. Slowly a friendship grows between Andy and Red. It's interesting Red is the only `guilty' man in Shawshank Prison. This movie is not about the normal prison violence that is seen in many prison films. There is some violence, but nothing too drastic. The film focuses more on making the best of a bad situation. Andy demonstrates if a person's life is based on strong values, he doesn't compromise his values in any situation. Often these values can affect others in a positive way. Andy never gave up his hope, his hope that someday things will go right. The tagline `get busy living, or get busy dying' sums up the message of the film. It is a good film. It has a simple story that is easy to follow. The acting is good, and the director Frank Darabont, is able to keep me interested through the entire movie. It also has a surprising and memorable ending. I don't know much about prison life and how it really is, but there are a few things which seem a little unrealistic: alcohol for the work crew, and how Red is able to obtain almost anything the prisoners want. Overall, it's a good movie. It can give the viewer something to think about and maybe learn from.

After watching try to add some of the aspects of the movie to your life as this movie teaches us many lessons of life.It also shows to us that how harsh prison life can be and a person needs to be mentally strong to handle himself in the jail.He must also make friends in jail as they can help him.

After we returned home, we viewed the movie (just finished it), and having been there, it gives new depth to the film. If you ever get the chance to visit the Shawshank Trail, or just tour the Reformatory, do it.

Remarkably perfect screenplay, wonderful dialogues and an unmatched cast, this movie takes you to a journey through a life of a prisoner. You realize what it is to be a prisoner and its horrible after effects and the deferment of human rights there. Perhaps you may have committed a crime, but that surely makes you think twice before you commit a mistake/crime.

There is one simple reason why the Shawshank Redemption is the second best movie I've ever seen. It made me want to be a BETTER PERSON. It actually changed my life. I wanted to help and be kinder to others after watching it. The character of Andy defines the human spirit and how a person whose life is based on values of honesty, goodness, and freedom, will not be compromised no matter what the situation. Others may have their opinions that it isn't that great based on artistic and technical merits, but they don't understand, it is the STORY that is compelling and what that story represents. The reason it is #2 in the voting is because it resonates that universal truth of the human spirit. It also portrays how one person by being resolute in their goodness can affect others and lift them up. That is why this movie has so many emotional high points. Andy is constantly lifting those around him and making their lives better even in one of the hell holes of our society. The two most emotional points in the movie for me are when he plays the music and when Andy and Red embrace on the beach in Zihuatenejo, Mexico.

(Bye the way, my #1 favorite movie of all time is 'A Man for All Seasons' which is similar to Shashank in that it tells the story of a man who is uncompromising in his beliefs.)

Many, including myself, would wonder what the point is of writing the 4,368th review of this film.

Well, I have been a member of this website under one log-in or another for the last couple of decades and never written a review, so if i'm going to write just one review, it may as well be about the best film ever made I suppose.

The Shawshank Redemption undoubtedly, in my opinion, deserves to be the highest rated movie of all time. It is a film you can watch again and again and take something more from it each time. It is simply life affirming, which we often need in these times where so many of us float through life, not appreciating what we have, and taking simple pleasures for granted.

It is a moving tale of hope, friendship & redemption. The friendship between the two main characters is unforgettable and the score is fantastic.I feel sorry for people who say this film is overrated. Not because I don't respect that other people have different opinions, but because if you cannot appreciate this film and the messages it gives us, then I feel you are missing out.

If anyone ever bothers to read this, the 4,368th review of this film, then I thank you for reading the only review I feel the need to write.

Forget about what others (including myself) might suggest you'll discover in "The Shawshank Redemption;" when you watch it, you'll identify something very personal in your own life with a scene, a character, or a moment in this uncomplicated movie. When you need hope, you'll look for Shawshank. When you want to believe in the will of overcoming even the greatest obstacles, Shawshank will uplift you in ways that you can't find in movies today.

My personal opinion is that the Shawshank Redemption is the greatest film ever made. However I fully appreciate the fact that this is not everybodys opinion. My knowledge of the film industry while not conclusive, is considerably extensive, and in my short time on earth I would like to believe that I have seen enough movies and learned enough about them to warrant comment on this particular gem. From the opening sequence to the memorable finale, this is filmaking at its finest hour. Yes, the overall message may be simple, but the study of human nature throughout the film relays the complexities and frailties of the human race. I dont think there is one fault in this film and I have watched it many times now. I have seen many film opinion polls at this stage and I cannot remember shawshank being outside the top five in any of them. So we all cant be wrong. What it all boils down to is whether or not a film can move you, or leave a profound effect on you. Films like Shawshank, Seven, Braveheart, American History X and Jaws had a hugh effect on me, these films to me are what makes movies magical. For someone else it might be pulp fiction, the godfather or its a wonderful life. The magic of the movies is the effect that a particular film has on the particular person. I think the shawshank redemption had a profound effect on so many people, because we can identify so well with the point its trying to put across (Hope is a good thing, even when all seems lost) and that true friendship can get us out of the worst of times. Films will always have their critics, thats the nature of the business, but I was always told they dont make them like they used to, this film is proof that they still can. P.S. Stephen King is a genius.

Woooow this movie the best for me The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.

The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

But Andy does not cry, and Red loses the cigarettes he wagered. Andy turns out to be a surprise to everyone in Shawshank, because within him is such a powerful reservoir of determination and strength that nothing seems to break him. Andy was a banker on the outside, and he's in for murder. He's apparently innocent, and there are all sorts of details involving his case, but after a while

The Shawshank Redemption was a film that I have heard so much about. Many of my friends have hailed it as their favorite film and one of the greatest films ever made. Now, being someone who isn't easily pleased; I went into The Shawshank Redemption with reservations.

Coming out of the film, I realized that it made me feel warm. I know that's a weird saying but it's a comfort film. A lot of people love it because it leaves you feeling happy and hopeful; not disturbed like Chinatown or frightened like Halloween (1978).

Shawshank is sentimental, joyful and has one great ending. Yet, the film feels so "safe"; leading the audience to a bittersweet and somewhat forced conclusion.

Overall, The Shawshank Redemption is a good film; it just doesn't take risks. Shawshank feels just fine in its little comfortable cinematic world.

If people enjoy that type of film, that's fine; I just think a film that takes more risks (2001: A Space Odyssey or The Tree Of Life) should be deserving of the top spot of the IMDb Top 250.

Every so often, a certain type of movie comes along that deeply moves anyone who watches it. This movie is grand in scope and scale, its character portrayals so moving and so real, that you cannot help becoming completely engrossed by it. I believe that the Shawshank Redemption is one of these movies. Often times, movies based on books are sub par, with the common complaint being, "The book is better." Well I, for one, have read the book and watched the movie, and I assure you that the movie is not a let down at all, but rather a triumph of modern cinema. The Shawshank Redemption saw career-defining performances from many of its cast members,including Tim Robbins, who became a top star after his incredible performance, and Morgan Freeman, who added to his already impressive list of accolades with his perfect supporting role. Robbins plays Andy Dufresne, a Maine banker who is unjustly convicted of killing his wife and her lover after he discovers that she is having an affair. Andy is a true outsider in the bleak world of Shawshank prison, an educated man not used to violence and despair that are an everyday part of prison life.
The plot is so good. Everyone should watch it. Morgan's character is one of the best ever.

"The Shawshank Redemption" has a hype so high that it is unfair to the film and its potential viewers. But it is an expertly written ocean of what a movie should be, and how a movie should capture such emotions from the audience, and how an audience will realize it is not glorified, but a masterpiece that is sure followed by almost any filmmaker by the slightest of touches. In this single film, it contains all of the basics (humor, drama, dread and redemption), but it tacks on much more. From the depths of its characters to Andy's shoes. It is about freedom, friendship and those metaphorical shackles. It's final scene could have not been so touching in a lesser movie, but it all pans out. Pans out in ways we hoped. In ways we dreamed.
What good can I say about this movie that hasn't been said already if you're in the mood for a good long movie and a happy ending then this is it.

The short novel by Stephen King has been adapted by Owen O'Neill and Dave Johns and is likely to prove popular with fans of the film as well as those who are too young to remember the original format. Based on the 1982 novella Rita Hayworth and The Shawshank Redemption, the play examines desperation, injustice, friendship and hope behind the bars of a maximum security facility. The 1994 feature film, regularly voted Britain's favourite ever movie, starred Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman and was nominated for seven Academy Awards. Two of TV's best loved leading men, Ian Kelsey (Doctors, Casualty and Emmerdale) and Patrick Robinson (Casualty, Midsomer Murders), star in this new production of The Shawshank Redemption, which is running at Milton Keynes Theatre until Saturday. Despite protests of his innocence, Andy Dufresne is handed a double life sentence for the brutal murder of his wife and her lover. Incarcerated at the notorious Shawshank facility, he quickly learns that no one can survive alone. Andy strikes up an unlikely friendship with the prison fixer Red, and things take a slight turn for the better. However, when Warden Stammas decides to bully Andy into subservience and exploit his talents for accountancy, a desperate plan is quietly hatched. A minimalist set is the perfect backdrop as the story unfolds in the confines of the prison walls. Dim lighting with the sound of doors slamming and keys turning makes you feel as though you were inside the 'Shank' with the inmates. The onstage partnership of Kelsey and Robinson has a genuine warmth to it, and this is complimented by their co-stars who bring both light and shade to the performance. No one can miss the distinctive laugh of Rooster, wonderfully but hauntingly captured by Leigh Jones, and Ian Barritt as Brooksie and George Evans as Tommy Williams shine in their 'darkest' moments. Owen O'Neill is perfect for the role of Warden Stammas, chillingly bringing a sense of fear to the stage every time he features. With the film's cult status, some die-hard fans may not like the fast-pace of the stage adaptation, which takes you through the years inside at a much quicker pace than the original film. But there is no harm in breathing new life into a classic and if you loved the film, why not indulge yourself in re-living it in a new format. The show contains strong language and adult content and is recommended for people aged 15 and over.

This movie is a must watch because of directing, acting and an excellent script. Morgan Freeman is the star of the movie. He played the best role of his professional life in Shawshank redemption.

In 1946, a banker named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted of a double murder, even though he stubbornly proclaims his innocence. He's sentenced to a life term at the Shawshank State Prison in Maine, where another lifer, Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), picks him as the new recruit most likely to crack under the pressure. The ugly realities of prison life are quickly introduced to Andy: a corrupt warden (Bob Gunton), sadistic guards led by Capt. Byron Hadley (Clancy Brown), and inmates who are little better than animals, willing to use rape or beatings to insure their dominance. But Andy does not crack: he has the hope of the truly innocent, which (together with his smarts) allow him to prevail behind bars. He uses his banking skills to win favor with the warden and the guards, doing the books for Norton's illegal business schemes and keeping an eye on the investments of most of the prison staff. In exchange, he is able to improve the prison library and bring some dignity and respect back to many of the inmates, including Red. Based on a story by Stephen King, The Shawshank Redemption was the directorial debut of screenwriter Frank Darabont.

The best so far I watched this movie when I was a kid and still the best for me The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

But Andy does not cry, and Red loses the cigarettes he wagered. Andy turns out to be a surprise to everyone in Shawshank, because within him is such a powerful reservoir of determination and strength that nothing seems to break him. Andy was a banker on the outside, and he's in for murder. He's apparently innocent, and there are all sorts of details involving his case, but after a while they take on a kind of unreality; all that counts inside prison is its own society -- who is strong, who is not -- and the measured passage of time.

Red is also a lifer. From time to time, measuring the decades, he goes up in front of the parole board, and they measure the length of his term (20 years, 30 years) and ask him if he thinks he has been rehabilitated. Oh, most surely, yes, he replies; but the fire goes out of his assurances as the years march past, and there is the sense that he has been institutionalized -- that, like another old lifer who kills himself after being paroled, he can no longer really envision life on the outside.

The Shawshank Redemption is actually a very good movie what I had seen two pass. This good movie is about hope, which is a very importance thing in our life. In 1947; Andy who is a young New England banker is wrongfully accused of killing his wife and her lover. And he is sent to Shawshank prison. In fact Andy is innocent. But only Andy knows that he didn't commit the crimes. The prison is really black. Andy does not lose his heart about his life and he can quickly adapt to prison life. Andy makes many friends in the prison. His quiet strength slowly earns the respect of his fellow inmates--most notably, Red who is an older prisoner and has given up hope --and even much of the prison staff. Andy and Red develop a deep friendship during their prison life. Andy gets a job in the prison library and He uses his intelligence to befriend the guards. Then he starts helping the guards with their taxes and pension plans. He never gives up frightening realities of prison life. And he has spent nineteen years on digging a tunnel in his cell wall behind a picture. Finally he has escaped from the prison successfully, and he takes with him 1/2 million in unmarked dirty money from the crooked warden. Yeas later Red is set free from the Shawshank prison and he gains the money that Andy fell to him. And then Red goes for Andy. The Shawshank Redemption is a nice, funny, emotional, moving, inspiring and powerful films with a high quality of greatness that you cannot put your finger on, but The Shawshank Redemption is there to show the greatness, and it being one that reaffirms our faith in society and in the power of hope, whether that hope is found in God or ourselves. Hope is a very good thing, perhaps the best of things, and if a film can remind us of that fact, then it is a really valuable movie.

It has been a pretty long time since i have seen such a great movie , great actors and great play of roles. Watching this movie made me realize a little evolution on movies spirit,knowing that lately film companies are trying to put technology first. In general , the movie managed to build a very strong emotional link between characters in the film , and apparently , that link is strong enough to make us feel for them and share feelings with the cast.I simply love everything about this movie, beginning from Andy's first day in prison , to his last day locked.I was impressed with the details ,they were perfectly handled,(per say) like the time when Andy tried to hit the pipes on the same time with the storm so the guards would not hear him trying to escape. Those little things matter a lot. I gave it a 10 and enjoyed watching it. Simply beautiful.
From opening scene.. to the very last scene this movie is phenomenal.

The caption basically shows you my opinion of that movie. It is a top film with a great storyline and perfectly described characters who are performed by actors knowing their craft well. Furthermore I also praise Darabont for turning King's short story into an almost 3-hour long drama without losing the basic message of the book and its atmosphere. Namely how different the two main characters are who represent a certain life philosophy : Red is the pessimistic one who never raises hope because life taught him that there is none but Andy is the total opposite: He never loses his hope even in such a terrible place. Nevertheless it is definitively NOT the best film of all time! Come on my fellow IMDb voters, how can you deliberately ignore the other movie masterpieces?! It is the without doubt the best prison movie (The Green Mile?!) and also one of the best book-adaption but there a better movies...admit it!!

The storyline takes you through the prison life of intelligent banker Andrew Dufresne who even though the crime he has been detained for he did not commit, remains quiet and takes the life sentence on the chin.

Throughout the film he encounters many characters, some who take a liking to him for the right reasons, and some for the wrong reasons. But what Andrew is plotting in secret will shock the entire Shawshank prison, and indeed the audience.

With twists and turns at every corner, ups and downs and emotional drama, Shawshank is undoubtedly one of the best film ever made.

The acting is incredible. The message is stronger than that of most any movie, and is stated very clearly. ¡° Hope¡± is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever does.¡± After being drained by the sad events that occur in the movie, the ending uplifts, and thoroughly fulfills the gap that it could leave you with.

I believe that one reason that this movie is under appreciated is that people have not seen it multiple times. At first viewing it is the story of Andy and his struggle to maintain hope despite his circumstances. However, this is really a movie about Red and his struggle to find meaning and purpose. The final segment of the movie testifies to the fact that the final resolution of the story comes about only when Red is faced with the same fearful situation as Brooks. Because of Andy, Red can find different path of freedom that is lit by hope.

No matter what circumstances you live in, do not forget that hope is the best thing in the world. And you will have courage to struggle, to forward, and to live better in the world.

(1) Simple but outstanding Storyline with so many twists and turns. (2) All twists and turns are natural and logical. You find them somewhere near to you but fail to detect till they are revealed on the screen. This is one of the most interesting feature of this movie. (3) Direction is per excellence as may be expected from any great movie. (4) Characters and Acting: Outstanding. (5) Narration by Morgan Freeman. (6) Music: suffice to mention the harmonica played when Red approaches the oak tree he was searching for. (7) One of the most loving ending that leaves you in a state of virtual ecstasy. You leave the screen smiling from within. In fact all great movies contains the features I have mentioned above but what distinguishes Shawshank Redemption from other great movies, in my view, and what makes it most deserving for No. 1 spot, is, undoubtedly, the last 20 minutes of the movie that is pure ecstasy that leads to the most satisfying ending.

One of my all time favorites. Shawshank Redemption is a very moving story about hope and the power of friendship. The cast is first rate with everyone giving a great performance. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman carry the movie, but Bob Gunton and Clancy Brown are perfect as the Warden Norton and prison guard captain Hadley respectively. And James Whitmore's portrayal of an elderly inmate Brooks is moving. The screenplay gives almost every actor at least one or more memorable lines through out the film. As well as a very surprising "twist" near the end that almost knocked me out of my chair. If you have not seen this movie rent it or better yet buy it. As I bet you'll want to see this one more than once.

While maintaining some of the poetic and moving dialogue of the novella, Darabont also proves that a film's score can generate a great deal of emotional response from its audience, as dialogue does. He employs the cunning Thomas Newman, son of the legendary Hollywood composer, Alfred Newman. Darabont shows recognition for the film's needs by employing Newman, who makes the gentle piano chords whisper softly to the viewer, as if a part of the scripted dialogue. Newman lends himself to individualism and tends to drive more towards the unique in the realm of score composition. His effort in Shawshank did not go unnoticed, as his score received an Oscar nomination in 1995. While unique and independent, Newman's score never once intrudes on your concentration or distracts from the film.

The greatness of this movie is beyond the stellar acting of Tim and Morgan, the remarkable story of Stephen King, the flawless screenplay or the wonderful direction of Darabont. The Shawshank Redemption is one of the most beloved movies ever because it awakes something in the viewer.

The Shawshank Redemption is my favorite movie ever. I feel blessed because I was one of the few people that actually saw it in theaters in 1994, when it was considered a flop. I was 14 years old, and i saw it alone in an almost empty Morehouse. Don't ask me why I watched it, but to this day I remember what I felt inside that theater. I recalled feeling different, somewhat inspired and anxious to talk to someone about my experience. I bet every Shawshank lover remembers the first time they saw it, because is unforgettable and moving.

You can say that thanks to Shawshank I felt in love with movies, and the art of movie-making. After Shawshank I have seen thousands of movies, amazing movies... I felt in love with Hitchcock, and discovered the classics of Wilder and Capra, felt amazed with the creativity of Almodovar and Jeunet, but to this day I had yet to experience the same sensation of hope and wonder that I felt in that empty movie theater more than 10 years ago. If you haven't seen this movie, buy it, because you will want to see it again and again.

Andy Dufresne s sentenced to two consecutive life terms in prison for the murders of his wife and her lover and is sentenced to a tough prison. However, only Andy knows he didn't commit the crimes. While there, he forms a friendship with Red and his life changes forever.

One of the great movies ever made.

It really has everything a movie should have and I wonder why Forrest Gump won the Oscar that year...

I'll go out on a limb and say this is the greatest movie ever made. The first time you see this movie and are not aware of its "secret" it seems like an average movie, with a good plot and great acting. This is the rare movie that actually gets better the more times you watch it. I've seen it more than 30 times and I just never get tired of it. If you like movies about perservering in the face of adversity and never giving up, then this movie will definitely appeal to you. Be sure and buy the DVD so you can see the extras about the location and all the backstories related to the movie. It's well worth the price. The cinematography, the writing, the acting, the direction -- everything is brilliant. This is one case where the movie is actually far better than the book or short story.

The best film I have ever seen. Period. No other film in history has come closer to perfection. In terms of the acting, the screen-writing, the directing, the music, the plot and its various sub-plots... The story in general is heart-warming and inspiring, portraying both the best and the worst of mankind. There are few films that I can watch over and over again without getting bored, but Shawshank Redemption more than any other movie does that for me. Even when I watch it for the umpteenth time at some point in 2014, I can guarantee that I will still feel the same goosebumps when Andy memorably advises Red to 'get busy living' or get busy dying', and the same upsurge of warmth, emotion, happiness and relief when Red is finally granted parole and he re-unites with Andy in the final scene. Perfection, perfection, perfection. 10/10

There are so many histories to tell wherever is fiction or real life, and seeing movies is my favorite way to connect with these histories. This is a film that moves you, makes you really go deep into the story and connect with the characters. It is fantastically written and directed, keeps you entertained, makes you laugh and shed serious tears. I like to read, but one of the things I love the most is to watch movies, I saw this one when I was 15 and it opened my mind to a movie world that I never imagined, puts your mind into how life can be unfair and how to look a way out and take advantage with what you have in hand, and think that when you put your mind into something wonderful things can happen. I am sure I'm not the only one that has been touched by this film, and I don't know what to say anymore than this is one of the most wonderful movies ever made, with this one I became a Morgan Freeman and Frank Darabont's fan. Ever since this movie my list of genres change into a list with no numbers (maybe a handful of absolutely favorites), I see every film that time allows me. This is a movie that definitely is time very well spent and keeps lingering in your mind always.

Nothing to say regarding this movie. Yea best of the best.

Why this movie didn't win all seven Oscars is beyond me, but don't let that sway you to not see this film, let its ranking on the IMDb's top 250 list sway you.

The Shawshank Redemption served as a message of hope to Hollywood as well. More than any film in memory, it proved there is life after box office. Besting Forrest and Fiction, it ran solely on strong word of mouth and became the hottest rented film of 1995

A movie hard to forget. Excellent at every aspect. Great performances by Tim and Morgan.

This movie is amazing, no doubt about it. Forget about all the people saying it's the most overrated movie of all time, they're just bitter. Maybe Shawshank didn't have the most amazing, jaw-dropping cinematography, camera work, etc. ever from start to finish (all the things that made films such as the Godfather so great. Granted, it's not like Shawshank had a lot to work with since a majority of the film was set at the prison), but it had an enjoyable, moving, inspirational story. It also had really enjoyable characters, particularly Andy Dufresne, who is my favorite fictional character. I liked him from the start.

Anyway, I think the Shawshank Redemption is the highest rated movie on this site because it's simply a great film. Easy to understand and follow, easy to love, and easy to be moved by. As IMDb has in the FAQ for this movie, "It is perhaps worthwhile to remember that the top 250 list doesn't really measure what individuals consider the best movies of all time. It measures the collective opinion of the films in which people have the greatest positive feel when they are rating it. People are not voting for the movie against other movies. They are voting for it based on their opinion at the time have decided to rate it on IMDb." So, when people complain about how it's overrated, just think about that.

Tim Robbins, when asked about why he chose to do this movie, (in addition to saying how he was moved and inspired by the story) said, "it's not just about prison. It's about the limitations we put on ourselves and life, and the limitations, more importantly, we allow others to place on us. And if we listen to them, and we believe what these people are saying to us, then we're really building walls around ourselves. We're really building our own prison What the film is saying in a larger way is that in order to keep alive and keep living in a strong and thorough way that oftentimes you have to look beyond the walls around you. And you have to not believe in the prison and believe in that light, and that hope, and that person that you think you can be, and the person that you believe you are, and not listen to what your boss is saying, what your spouse is saying, what your leaders are saying." I don't think I can elaborate much further. The Shawshank Redemption taught me to hold onto hope and believe in myself. I'm reminded of that Emily Dickinson poem, "Hope is the Thing with Feathers," and I think it represents a lot of what Andy stood for.

This movie is one of my all time favorites. I can quote this movie pretty much through the whole movie. It is a riveting film, and it never bores you. It makes you feel every emotion. It makes you laugh, cry, cheer, and empathize over the course of the movie. I've seen very few movies that almost every type of person enjoys. I seriously question people's tastes if they don't at least acknowledge the fact this was a brilliant movie. They don't have to like it ( which I find out pretty rare ) but they have to admit, they acting was great. Writing this review makes me want to watch it again. The ending always makes me smile.

Misery and Stand By Me were the best adaptations up until this one, now you can add Shawshank to that list.

This is simply one of the best films ever made and I know I am not the first to say that and I certainly won't be the last. The standing on the IMDb is a true barometer of that. #3 as of this date and I'm sure it could be number 1. So I'll just skip all the normal praise of the film because we all know how great it is. But let me perhaps add that what I find so fascinating about Shawshank is that Stephen King wrote it.

King is one of the best writers in the world. Books like IT and the Castle Rock series are some of the greatest stories ever told. But his best adaptations are always done by the best directors. The Shining was brilliantly interpreted by Kubrick and of course the aforementioned Misery and Stand By Me are both by Rob Reiner. Now Frank Darabont comes onto the scene and makes arguably the best King film ever. He seems to understand what King wants to say and he conveys that beautifully.

This review is written to contribute my fair share to making sure this stays the number 1 film of all time, because it is really thoroughly deserved.

The beauty of the simplicity. The depth of the characters. The strength of the bonds. The legendary performances. The captivating score.

This movie excels on so so many levels. If you read this review and haven't seen this movie yet, go watch it. Turn off the lights, have a glass of wine with you and listen to the story of Andy Dufresne. It will stay with you for the rest of your life.

It's hard to beat a classic, and this film ticks all the boxes of a classic box office hit. With a deep underlying moral, as well as a hard hitting narrative that makes you question how good a person you truly are, this film makes you think about life itself, and the security and contentment we all seem to fall into the trap of.

Freeman gives his all time best performance, with Tim Robbins' character Dufresne making you question your own true identity, and where do our morals lie?

Few films have ever been made with such subtext, and yet it is so blindingly brilliant how Darabont put together King's novel in such a way that an audience would have to be made of pure stone to not shed a tear during multiple poignant scenes.

All in all, this film is a truly magnificent masterpiece, faultless from the get go. If you have a film 'to-do' list, I advise you to place this at the very start, as there is not a single flaw.

I was made to watch this film in my English class for doing coursework. I am sooo happy my teacher set me that work. A class of 30 teenagers walked way from the lessons we watched it in so influenced by the film heading to the shop to by their own copy. I am proud to say I was one of them. Once I got to uni and found out some people hadn't watched it I sat them down at night and forced them. Sadly watching it in a kitchen shared by 16 people even at night isn't the quietest place to watch this film. Half drunk student would walk in and all my friends who hadn't seen it turned to them and before they had chance to speak they were told to shut up so they could watch it in peace. I was happy to see my friends having the same reaction I had to the film. It is proof that a film doesn't need special affects to hook a bunch of young people onto it. It needs something and what ever it is the Shawshank Redemption has it by the bucket full. I am afraid to say I still have friends who haven't watched it but I will continue to try and get them to watch it and I hope you take up this fight, if you haven't watched it, watch it, if you have, make more people watch it.

In 1946, a banker named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted of a double murder, even though he stubbornly proclaims his innocence. He's sentenced to a life term at the Shawshank State Prison in Maine, where another lifer, Ellis Red Redding (Morgan Freeman), picks him as the new recruit most likely to crack under the pressure. The ugly realities of prison life are quickly introduced to Andy: a corrupt warden (Bob Gunton), sadistic guards led by Capt. Byron Hadley (Clancy Brown), and inmates who are little better than animals, willing to use rape or beatings to insure their dominance. But Andy does not crack: he has the hope of the truly innocent, which (together with his smarts) allow him to prevail behind bars. He uses his banking skills to win favor with the warden and the guards, doing the books for Norton's illegal business schemes and keeping an eye on the investments of most of the prison staff. In exchange, he is able to improve the prison library and bring some dignity and respect back to many of the inmates, including Red. Based on a story by Stephen King, The Shawshank Redemption was the directorial debut of screenwriter Frank Darabont.~ Mark Deming,

But I must explain to you how all this mistaken idea of denouncing pleasure and praising pain was born and I will give you a complete account of the system, and expound the actual teachings of the great explorer of the truth, the master-builder of human happiness. No one rejects, dislikes, or avoids pleasure itself, because it is pleasure, but because those who do not know how to pursue pleasure rationally encounter consequences that are extremely painful. Nor again is there anyone who loves or pursues or desires to obtain pain of itself, because it is pain, but because occasionally circumstances occur in which toil and pain can procure him some great pleasure. To take a trivial example, which of us ever undertakes laborious physical exercise, except to obtain some advantage from it? But who has any right to find fault with a man who chooses to enjoy a pleasure that has no annoying consequences, or one who avoids a pain that produces no resultant pleasure?

On the other hand, we denounce with righteous indignation and dislike men who are so beguiled and demoralized by the charms of pleasure of the moment, so blinded by desire, that they cannot foresee the pain and trouble that are bound to ensue; and equal blame belongs to those who fail in their duty through weakness of will, which is the same as saying through shrinking from toil and pain. These cases are perfectly simple and easy to distinguish. In a free hour, when our power of choice is untrammelled and when nothing prevents our being able to do what we like best, every pleasure is to be welcomed and every pain avoided. But in certain circumstances and owing to the claims of duty or the obligations of business is will frequently occur that pleasures have to be repudiated and annoyances accepted. The wise man therefore always holds in these matters to this principle of selection: he rejects pleasures to secure other greater pleasures, or else he endures pains to avoid worse pains.

To be fair, I also have to admit that I am a big fan of Stephen King and the screenplay was so honest to the story so there's probably that extra appreciation personally. I just read another review and I felt obligated to agree! There really aren't words to describe this movie. It gets better and better every time I see it and it doesn't matter where I start. I have seen it at least five times every year since 2000. It has to be my all-time favorite, hands down. The movies are the ultimate escapism for me and this movie does just that, yet it depicts something that we know too well, being a victim of circumstance or a witness of circumstances. Andy is the victim and Red is the witness, connecting in a way where you had to be there to understand. Kudos too to Stephen King for always knowing exactly how to capture our worst fears and materializing it. Whether it's the harsh punishment for a crime one did not commit or realizing that you've been so "institutionalized" by the very walls you hated that you no longer know how to live without it, this movie exudes a sense of hope much welcomed to many.And though some of us may not absolutely believe in it, we are nonetheless glad it's lingering just close enough for us to know it's there. It's such a well done piece, please go see it.

i don't even know what to write about this movie. while i was leaving the theatre, i already knew it became my favorite movie. its degrading to this film to even call it a movie, its a masterpiece. a one of a kind portrait which can't be duplicated. every scene is perfectly crafted; perfectly filmed. the pace is perfect; there is never a dull, or too fast moment during the film. the music is beyond words, how the director was able to incorporate such feeling with the music he used is beyond my comprehensibility. the acting is phenomenal (obviously, how can Morgan freeman be bad in anything?), Tim Robbins ain't to shabby either. the writing is the true work of art, though. the script is completely magnificent; its a gem.

The movie Shawshank Redemption is based on a novel from Stephan King. The movie is directed by Frank Darabont (1994) and it is one of the best movies ever made. The movie is not only a depressing story but it contains friendship, loyalty, hope and wisdom. Andy (Tim Robbins) is convicted for the murder of his wife and his lover. he is sent to Shawshank prison. He has a life long sentence and in his time in prison Andy becomes friends with Red (Morgan Freeman). Andy tries to adapt to the life in prison and does this together with his friend Red. Through time Andy overcomes the tortures of prison, and he tries to inspire other prisoners ("While the body may be locked away in a cell, the spirit can never be truly imprisoned). The movie shows the determination of Andy and leads us into a world of imagination, filled with courage and desire. The setting of the movie is extremely realistic and the establishing shot immediately shows the setting of the movie, so you know what to expect. I personally think Shawshank Redemption is the best film ever made. It has already been a number one movie on IMDb for a while now. The costumes, the make-up and acting are done extremely well and the story is very well thought through. To conclude, the movie has many inspiring messages in it, such as "never give up" and "always have hope to achieve what you want" for example.

This movie is the definition for hope! All those souls who lost their hope due to unfortunate reasons must watch this film.

Morgan Freeman's brutally honest words when asked about rehabilitated are life changing. You can never change the past nor control the future, but you can change the mood of the day by touching someones' heart with your smile.

In the lead roles, both Robbins and Freeman are outstanding, layering their performances with snippets of individuality: Their small, daily sustenances and minor triumphs are wonderfully inspiring. Top-notch performances, exceptional cinematography, and masterful direction combine to make this film something special indeed.
One of my favorite movie of all time it's a amazing that characters are well placed and put up there 100% in acting...must watch...

This is (just like Shutter Island) one of the best movies I've ever saw in my whole life. This film is really long, but it doesn't matter, for me it wasn't long enough! :) I really liked the whole story, from the beginning till the very end. It is a pretty sad movie at some points, but at the end it's actually a 'feel-good' movie. After watching this you realize how happy you have to be because you are a free man. Some people spend they're whole life in prison, and that's pretty sick. Because yeah, you life only 1 time, and now I really know how lucky I am. This movie is now number 1 for a very long time, that means 1 thing: you definitely need to watch this, you can't die without watching this movie! You won't regret it :). It is pretty funny to see Morgan Freeman acting in his younger years, then you realize how old this movie actually is. Time flies by, and that's actually one of the lessons you learn from this movie.

that is of course till the screen went dark and the credits rolled.

First, I read Stephen King's "Different Seasons" as soon as it came out (I was around 19 I guess), and was enthralled by his writing. Of course, I had no idea 3 out of the 4 novellas would eventually adapted into movies, but I am not surprised. It is impossible to put whatever pictures you have in your mind onto the screen, so that is why everyone compares the book to the movie. The same happened to me with "Treasure of the Sierra Madre" (HIGHLY recommend reading the book), even with Bogie playing, it was a tough transition to see it on the screen. I assume at least 80-90% of those who saw either one never read the books. ANYway...the Shawshank Redemption was very "full" of character development, and amazing passion from Morgan Freeman especially. He is an expert in his craft, and for me, his peak. I will be watching this soon again with my wife who has not seen many American films.

About Movie: The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont and starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Adapted from the Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption, the film tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is sentenced to life in Shawshank State Prison for the murder of his wife and her lover despite his claims of innocence. During his time at the prison, he befriends a fellow inmate, Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding, and finds himself protected by the guards after the warden begins using him in his money laundering operation. My perspective: It is one of the favorite movie i ever seen...very inspirational, motivational and great movie. The movie depicted all kind of emotions from the characters in the life like humor, joy, surprise, excitement, vengeance, jealous, untruthful, being alone, disappointment, self motivation, Corruption, wired feeling. This movie taught me that one has not give up his or her wish at any circumstances..From this movie i understand one should not wish for immediate result it may disappoint them, but if he or she should focus on the progress towards the goal. It only give real success. after watching this movie, i ask myself what is your purpose of the life because hero will redemptive entire jail even he is in the prison.
This will forever be a classic. "get busy livin or get busy dyin"

it's came out in 1994 and was an absolute flop but found its real audience in home video, peaking as the most rented video of 1995 in the USA.

A wonderful film that takes you into the prison experience of Red(Morgan Freeman) and Andy (Tim Robbins). Andy being a banker convicted of murder and Red a murderer already serving time, this movie takes you to the limits of human endurance, where the human spirit eventually prevails.

The TSR takes you on an emotional journey that you will remember for a long time, thanks to the superb crafting of the film and sincere performances by the cast. The score is deep and haunting, this film is for the ages and will permanent have a place in my heart. To me it is the best film of the 90's and quite possibly one of the best of all time.

The fact that this film is sitting at No.1 is a testament to just how many people love this film, many viewers seem to have an emotional bond with the film, and I don't blame them. I only wish that I could view the film for the first time again, and experience that redeeming feeling Andy and Red experienced at the end.

Ignore the hype surrounding the film and judge it on your own experience, the last half hour are especially beautiful. Watch this if you already haven't, and enjoy the masterpiece that Frank Darabont has so gracefully given us the privilege of viewing. 8/10

Print Page It is a strange comment to make about a film set inside a prison, but "The Shawshank Redemption" creates a warm hold on our feelings because it makes us a member of a family. Many movies offer us vicarious experiences and quick, superficial emotions. "Shawshank" slows down and looks. It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

Interesting that although the hero of the film is the convicted former banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the action is never seen from his point of view. The film's opening scene shows him being given two life sentences for the murder of his wife and her lover, and then we move, permanently, to a point of view representing the prison population and particularly the lifer Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). It is his voice remembering the first time he saw Andy ("looked like a stiff breeze would blow him over"), and predicting, wrongly, that he wouldn't make it in prison.

This movie does an excellent job of portraying all characters in this movie and showing how each individual deals with the fact/probability that they might never see life outside of prison walls, while also showing how certain inmates manage to handle freedom once being let out of prison. A truly inspirational movie showing the strength of hope and willpower while not being too extremely over the top and using an ending to make all viewers feel good about how everything resolves itself and lets viewers have the entire story come full circle with a true sense of irony at the very end. An awesome film that is well directed with an excellent "mood" surrounding the entire movie. The acting keeps right up with and for the most part exceeds the directing.

Clearly this was a movie that needed word-of-mouth to find an audience, and indeed business was slowly but steadily growing when it was yanked from theaters. If it had been left to find its way, it might have continued to build and run for months, but that's not what happened.
