When I was a teenager, I read a book called Different Seasons which, at the time, was a series of short stories by a man named Richard Bachman.

Richard Bachman, as it turns out, was actually Stephen King.

King was apparently worried that having his name on this book would cause people to have preconceived notions and possibly judge the work by his name alone, rather than by it's contents.

Among the short stories in this book was one titled, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption, on which the film was based.

There are a lot of memorable characters and happenings throughout, and in the center of all of them is Andy Dufresne, who was accused of killing his wife for sleeping with a golf pro at the local country club.

Andy claims he is innocent, but is convicted and sent to prison for the murder.

This film does a very good job of staying true to the story, with only a few minor changes that do not effect the outcome.

Without giving too much away, I will just say that this film is the highest rated on IMDb for a reason. It is about so many different things that it would take some time to list them, would have to contain spoilers and would not do the film justice.

This movie will elicit many different emotions and is definitely worth the viewing.

This movie is intertwined with my growth as an advocate, appreciater and lover of the art of film. So much of my life has been invested into devouring films that the world's movie industrys have the passion and drive to produce, movies like this are the reason why.

After viewing a genorously eclectic mix of genres and sub genres of titles over the years; I have still not found a more well balanced and humble portrail of human struggle/condition than the Shawshank Redemption. Although most of us cannot truly relate to serving a lengthy sentence in a 1940s penetentuary, Darabont manages to capture subtle yet poinient moments that the populous can empathise with.

The piece seems to encapsulate one of those rare moments where the writing adaptation, acting, cinimatography, score and directorial vision allign to create a masterpiece.

The fact that this is the highest rated movie of all time on IMDb gives me hope that ratings of the masses are capable of being pointed in the right kind of direction.

I gave a 10 star, but would prefer to give a 9.5. That way, the cinematic optimists can have faith that we are destined for more exceptional movies like this.

Last week some news came out from somebody online who had claimed to have seen a finished version of Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice. If you were like me, you've been leery of checking it out because you weren't sure how much might actually be true. Now Zack Snyder has spoken out about the spoiler-filled post, although his response doesn't really clear anything up.

In a word, to MTV, he called the post "hilarious," which might imply that he's saying that it's mostly, if not entirely, untrue. That might be the case, but then again he could have just said it was untrue and he didn't say that. What he did say, however, is that he doesn't like spoilers. While this may seem odd for the director who's most recent trailer appeared to give away the entire movie, Snyder says that's not the case. Even if you've seen the trailer, you can rest easy, as there is much more we have not seen in then finished film. Says Snyder: I have the benefit of seeing the movie. It's cool that fans think it's too much, and I appreciate people not wanting to know, but there's plenty that they don't know. There's a lot of movie that's not in the trailer.

In the process of calling the Batman v Superman Reddit review hilarious, Snyder goes on to talk about how he hates it when spoilers come out. The director would much rather that fans see the movie mostly blind. While he understands that some fans may wish to find the answers before hand, he wants his movies to be mysteries going in. If you're, as an audience member, exploring these articles, looking for answers to questions that you have, maybe you're okay with knowing before you go. It's like an individual taste. But like I said, I want people to see the movie without knowing.

Spoilers are a topic that mean different things to different people. While most try to avoid them to some degree, the need to solve the mystery is a nearly universal human experience. We have an inclination to want to know the truth, even while also wanting to be surprised. For most of us getting some information is good, but getting all the information is bad, of course, only getting the details that you want can be difficult.

The film is in my opinion, one of the few 'perfect movies' ever made. From the cinematography to the cast to the script. Every element of this film is a 10/10. One of the things that hits me the hardest are films about redemption. Someone overcoming a terrible hardship or someone getting a second chance in life. This is definitely one of the greatest redemption stories ever told.

The performances are spectacular. From the leads on down. Definitely my favorite Morgan Freeman performance of all time (and there a lot of good ones to choose from.) Tim Robbins was born to play this role. He shines so bright and his arc is amazing to watch. The supporting cast is also excellent.

The pace and flow of the film is also done so well. The film runs pretty long but it feels like to goes by quick. The story is told in such a way that keeps you so engulfed that you don't realize that two hours plus have just passed.

A little known fact about this movie is that it is based off a Stephen King novella. Another interesting side note is that Morgan Freeman's character of "RED' was named that in the book because he was an Irishman with red hair. Thankfully they went outside of the box when casting and brought in Freeman. If they had not, we would have been robbed of one of the greatest performances ever brought to the silver screen.

I don't get emotional over movies very often, but The Shawshank Redemption makes me feel so many different emotions in roughly two and a half hours that I can't help but watch this movie as often as my family and I can stand it.

The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest bus load of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

But Andy does not cry, and Red loses the cigarettes he wagered. Andy turns out to be a surprise to everyone in Shawshank, because within him is such a powerful reservoir of determination and strength that nothing seems to break him. Andy was a banker on the outside, and he's in for murder. He's apparently innocent, and there are all sorts of details involving his case, but after a while they take on a kind of unreality; all that counts inside prison is its own society -- who is strong, who is not -- and the measured passage of time.

Red is also a lifer. From time to time, measuring the decades, he goes up in front of the parole board, and they measure the length of his term (20 years, 30 years) and ask him if he thinks he has been rehabilitated. Oh, most surely, yes, he replies; but the fire goes out of his assurances as the years march past, and there is the sense that he has been institutionalized -- that, like another old lifer who kills himself after being paroled, he can no longer really envision life on the outside.

Red's narration of the story allows him to speak for all of the prisoners, who sense a fortitude and integrity in Andy that survives the years. Andy will not kiss butt. He will not back down. But he is not violent, just formidably sure of himself. For the warden (Bob Gunton), he is both a challenge and a resource; Andy knows all about bookkeeping and tax preparation, and before long he's been moved out of his prison job in the library and assigned to the warden's office, where he sits behind an adding machine and keeps tabs on the warden's ill-gotten gains. His fame spreads, and eventually he's doing the taxes and pension plans for most of the officials of the local prison system.

There are key moments in the film, as when Andy uses his clout to get some cold beers for his friends who are working on a roofing job. Or when he befriends the old prison librarian (James Whitmore). Or when he oversteps his boundaries and is thrown into solitary confinement. What quietly amazes everyone in the prison -- and us, too -- is the way he accepts the good and the bad as all part of some larger pattern than only he can fully see.

The partnership between the characters played by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman is crucial to the way the story unfolds. This is not a "prison drama" in any conventional sense of the word. It is not about violence, riots or melodrama. The word "redemption" is in the title for a reason. The movie is based on a story, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption, by Stephen King, which is quite unlike most of King's work. The horror here is not of the supernatural kind, but of the sort that flows from the realization than 10, 20, 30 years of a man's life have unreeled in the same unchanging daily prison routine.

The director, Frank Darabont, paints the prison in drab grays and shadows, so that when key events do occur, they seem to have a life of their own.

Andy, as played by Robbins, keeps his thoughts to himself. Red, as Freeman plays him, is therefore a crucial element in the story: His close observation of this man, down through the years, provides the way we monitor changes and track the measure of his influence on those around him. And all the time there is something else happening, hidden and secret, which is revealed only at the end.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is not a depressing story, although I may have made it sound that way. There is a lot of life and humor in it, and warmth in the friendship that builds up between Andy and Red. There is even excitement and suspense, although not when we expect it. But mostly the film is an allegory about holding onto a sense of personal worth, despite everything. If the film is perhaps a little slow in its middle passages, maybe that is part of the idea, too, to give us a sense of the leaden passage of time, before the glory of the final redemption.

The Shawshank Redemption IMHO is truly the greatest movies of all time. It is my personal favourite and I can not comprehend how anyone would not like this film. After seeing it, for nearly a dozen or so times, I can still see it with the same fervor and excitement. Not one moment of this movies is dull or uninteresting. The cast is brilliant, especially Tim Robbins as the wrongly accused Andy Dufresne and Morgan Freeman as Red. Also, the greedy and treacherous warden is wonderfully portrayed by Bob Gunton. The film sends a message about hope and the human spirit. The movie has several subplots, which each have their own pace. Andy making friends with his inmates first and then the prison guards, his building of the library, him tutoring Tommy, working for conniving Warden Norton, escaping from prison and then Red getting out and going to find him, all of which never create a boring moment. The best part of the movie is after when Andy escapes, and the story of Red untill he meets Andy. I also liked the part when Brooks gets out and cant seem to cope with the changed pace of life after being "institutionalised" for nearly 40 years. It is hope which keeps this movie alive. The hope that someday Andy will get out, the hope that Red will see his friend once again really sends a message of inspiration, to never lose hope. As Red truly says, "Get busy livin', or get busy dying "! The score by Thomas Neuman is also brilliant. For those people who have not yet seen this movie, you should definitley watch it whenever you get a chance. A true masterpiece. I cannot see how this movie did not get Best Picture. Forrest Gump can not even be compared to this film.
Finally you would be happy after watching this movie

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a timeless classic that has captured the hearts of movie lovers for over 25 years. Directed by Frank Darabont, this film tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a successful banker who is wrongly convicted of murder and sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary. Throughout the movie, Andy forms a friendship with fellow inmate, Ellis "Red" Redding, and together they navigate the harsh realities of prison life while Andy works to clear his name.

What makes "The Shawshank Redemption" so powerful is its ability to delve into the deepest human emotions, such as hope, friendship, and perseverance. Despite being trapped in a bleak and oppressive environment, Andy never loses sight of his dream of freedom, and this unwavering spirit is both inspiring and moving. Similarly, Red's transformation from a cynical prison veteran to a true friend and confidant, highlights the transformative power of hope and friendship.

The film's talented cast, led by Tim Robbins as Andy and Morgan Freeman as Red, delivers outstanding performances that bring the story to life. Their chemistry on screen is exceptional, and their portrayal of the deep friendship that develops between Andy and Red is both heartwarming and genuine. Additionally, the film's cinematography and musical score are masterful and enhance the overall viewing experience.

In conclusion, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a must-see movie for anyone who appreciates a well-told story, outstanding acting, and masterful filmmaking. Its timeless themes of hope, perseverance, and friendship will leave a lasting impression on viewers, and its universal appeal makes it a classic that will be enjoyed for generations to come.

(We do not say details of the film to enjoy it who have not seen) The film is based on the novel by Stephen King with the same title, which sold the rights to the book the director and friend, Frank Darabont (Frank Darabont), just one dollar. The Ntarampot changed the title, and considered that would mislead the public, in «The Shawshank Redemption». Two months it took to complete the script, which he claimed was the best he had ever read in his life. Immediately presented to companies and did not take long to start shooting. For the role of the banker Andy Ntoufrens producers think Tom Hanks and Kevin Costner, but the first two refused and chose Tim Robbins. O Costner few years later admitted that he regretted that decision. The Robbins spent some time in isolation to prepare mentally for the role of Andy Ntoufrens. For the role of the Red, the retentate coming in close contact with the Ntoufrens, the director chose Morgan Freeman, because of his voice. Although the description in the book did not fit his appearance Freeman as the Red supposed to be Irish, the director was erect. Indeed, Freeman today sees Red the most important role in his career. In September 1994 it came out in theaters. Day projection, the director with the producer went into one of the largest movie theaters of America and saw license. The title of the film according to Freeman was why we failed, but is not fault it. At that time the competition was tough, as they had been released and the leading Pulp fiction films and Forrest Gump. Although not well went in cinemas caused a sensation in video clubs and is still one of the best films of all time. Review from Roger Ebert: There are key moments in the film, as when Andy uses his clout to get some cold beers for his friends who are working on a roofing job. Or when he befriends the old prison librarian (James Whitmore). Or when he oversteps his boundaries and is thrown into solitary confinement. What quietly amazes everyone in the prison -- and us, too -- is the way he accepts the good and the bad as all part of some larger pattern than only he can fully see.

The partnership between the characters played by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman is crucial to the way the story unfolds. This is not a "prison drama" in any conventional sense of the word. It is not about violence, riots or melodrama. The word "redemption" is in the title for a reason. The movie is based on a story, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption, by Stephen King, which is quite unlike most of King's work. The horror here is not of the supernatural kind, but of the sort that flows from the realization than 10, 20, 30 years of a man's life have unreeled in the same unchanging daily prison routine.

I'm trying to save you money; this is the last film title that you should consider borrowing. Renting Shawshank will cost you five bucks... just plunk down the $25 and own the title. You'll wind up going back to this gem time and time again. This is one of few movies that are truly timeless. And it's entertaining and moving, no matter how many times you view it.

Forget about what others (including myself) might suggest you'll discover in "The Shawshank Redemption;" when you watch it, you'll identify something very personal in your own life with a scene, a character, or a moment in this uncomplicated movie. When you need hope, you'll look for Shawshank. When you want to believe in the will of overcoming even the greatest obstacles, Shawshank will uplift you in ways that you can't find in movies today.

This is the story of a man named Andy DuFresne, an intelligent man convicted for murdering his infidel wife, despite claiming innocence. DuFresne experiences the harsh conditions inside the prison and suffers, but works from within in search of some form of redemption. I'd recommend 15+. There's a lot of brutal, unlawful violence against prisoners, often in detail, while the overall message of how a prison spell can destroy a man mentally and physically is very depressing. There's a very sad suicide halfway through.

This movie is the greatest prison movie I have ever seen. The storyline is original and the performance of Tim Robbins is superb. The movie is about Andy Dufresne is convicted of the double murder of his wife and her lover and tells the story of his double life sentence behind bars at Shawshank prison which uses religion as a form of rehabilitation. During his sentence he is bashed constantly for three years until he meets a fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding who is asked by Dufresne to help him escape. With his escape comes the signature scene as Andy escapes through the sewers to freedom. The end of the film highlights the ability of two friends to overcome adversity to achieve a central goal. The screenplay is superb as this is based on the novel by one of the best or the best horror of all time, Stephen King. The movie is a movie that explores the REAL story behind bars and the ability of people to escape mentally and spiritually with rehabilitation

This is simply one of the best films ever made and I know I am not the first to say that and I certainly won't be the last. The standing on the IMDb is a true barometer of that. #3 as of this date and I'm sure it could be number 1. So I'll just skip all the normal praise of the film because we all know how great it is. But let me perhaps add that what I find so fascinating about Shawshank is that Stephen King wrote it.

King is one of the best writers in the world. Books like IT and the Castle Rock series are some of the greatest stories ever told. But his best adaptations are always done by the best directors. The Shining was brilliantly interpreted by Kubrick and of course the aforementioned Misery and Stand By Me are both by Rob Reiner. Now Frank Darabont comes onto the scene and makes arguably the best King film ever. He seems to understand what King wants to say and he conveys that beautifully.

What makes this film one of the best ever made is the message it conveys. It is one of eternal hope. Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, has been sent to prison for a crime he did not commit. But he never loses hope. He never gives up his quest to become a free man again. His years of tenacity, patience and wits keep him not only sane, but it gives his mind and a spirit a will to live. This film has a different feel to it. There has never been anything like it before and I don't know if there will again.

I'm not going to say any more about this film, it has already been said, but just suffice to say that I am glad that Forrest Gump won best picture in 94. I would have been equally glad if Pulp Fiction or Shawshank would have won. It is that good of a movie and one that will be appreciated for years to come.

In my opinion the greatest film ever made. Exquisite in every detail with Morgan Freeman's silky smooth narration taking you along on an unforgettable journey..

This movie has that certain indefinable screen magic, every line of dialogue spoken has real conviction and meaning, and the performances in this movie are nothing short of magnificent. Tim Robbins delivers his best screen performance ever, as the quietly spoken Andy. Here is a character like no other, so vivid, so real, that you can't help but like him. Morgan Freeman also delivers his best work ever as Red, Andy's friend. Freeman, while playing a different character from Robbins, is also able to give off a quiet dignity for his character.

The supporting cast is perfect. From Bob Gunton, chillingly evil, but never over the top as to become cartoonish, as the Warden. Clancy Brown, as the prison Guard Hadley is brilliant, as is Veteran James Whitmore, as Brooks, who while given relatively small screen time is brilliant as the lifer con who's sad journey the film details.
Truly the best movie I have ever watched. Will watch it again and again!

This film is a profound impression of truth regarding friendship and solidarity. The men are simple folk who are enslaved by thugs like wardens and guards with one credo: you can battle the entire world but you never betray a friend. We learn what happens to friends, to foes and the principles of a man's life,

The film is about relationships; the many years a man spends away from society and garners new friends. The film, like life and memories, unfolds in non-linear fashion. The director's cuts are interesting and each scene is beautifully amplified . The story is not told deceptively. Instead, the chapters of the story are revealed like pieces of a great jigsaw puzzle. Each delicious piece might make us laugh or cry or smile or feel hatred for the racist 'man'.

This film is a true masterpiece, expressing a profound statement about friendship and betrayal, with fantastic acting, writing, directing and music.
Beautifully narrated ane executed on many levels. Gone, so I thought, were the days when a movie could completely captivate an audience on dialogue alone. Thank you for this masterpiece.

Tis is a brilliant movie that must be respected.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.

The story is narrated by "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), who has been inside the walls of Shawshank Prison for a very long time and is its leading entrepreneur. He can get you whatever you need: cigarettes, candy, even a little rock pick like an amateur geologist might use. One day he and his fellow inmates watch the latest busload of prisoners unload, and they make bets on who will cry during their first night in prison, and who will not. Red bets on a tall, lanky guy named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who looks like a babe in the woods.

I would just like to begin by saying the Shawshank redemption is one of the worst movies I have ever seen despite it being number 2 in the IMDb top 250 list. As I went through the movie, it was so painful, boring and everything else which makes a boring movie, unbelievably slow movie. I am aware of the fact that most people had voted this movie as an ace movie but in my opinion it was the single worst movie i have ever encountered with. Although I admire the 1 actor in the movie I am sad to say that for me this movie is a waste of time. I regret ever watching it. However I would not be able to say "do not watch this movie" as the voting and the scores point otherwise. In my opinion the Shawshank Redemption should not even be on the 1-10000 list of the movies. It was just someone going into prison and making a difference. I am all for inspirational movies, just not this one. I would rather sit and stare into a blank spot rather than wasting my time watching this movie. No offense to the actors as they were not bad but the script, the story, the screenplay, the time period, nothing suited each other. I am just expressing how i feel about this movie and my final words to describe this movie: "DO NOT WATCH".

Excellent movie! I've seen it for several times but I can't stop watching it. It's memorable! The actors play is magnificent! Hope is what we need most! Redemption is just a word like every other word. In a corrupt system, hope never dies. Andy is not only just a smart guy. He takes advantage of the whole corrupt system. There were and there will always exist innocent people in jail. How you can prove your innocence is a matter of common sense which is not evenly distributed. Hope is always needed as long as corruption never end. When hope dies, everything else dies slowly. And in the end a question: what would one like Andy do not in 1966, but in 2006. Could he still get into prison, could he still escape, could he still take financial advantage over the system? I hope he could!

And one of the saddest in the world! Andy really had a hard time of it. This is one of those films where I always wonder if I got stuck in jail what would my life be like? What exactly would I do? How would I live and how exactly would I survive. The only current TV show that brings back those emotions is Orange is the New Black. Feeling isolated and stuck.

The breath of this film can be summed up in a few ways but most of the human spirit and the will to survive against all odds. Hope is the answer and name of the game in this film. Trying to control your surroundings even though control is the least you have.

Goonies is a never ending series of very loud, annoying and preposterous situations that will have you rolling your eyes more than a Felix the Cat clock. First and foremost, the continuous dialog and general noise in this movie is enough to make it a form of torture. The audio is pegged at 10 from the opening and never once lets up. Secondly, the gaps in reality: it's just a kids film you say? Movies like Raiders of the Lost Ark and Star Wars intelligently made a kids genre entertaining. Ditto to The Bad News Bears, Home Alone or anything Walt Disney Produced. This film bashes you over the head with every cliché and impossible situation imaginable. The characters are all one dimensional and unimaginative, most all of them have an adult wit and a snappy response for every thing posed to them like a kid from a bad sitcom, and I cannot stress this enough, all of them talk nonstop, mostly simultaneously, for the entire film.

This movie is such a heart felt movie and definitely something that will leave you thinking about yourself. This movie teaches you to persevere and keep going no matter how dark life gets to you; to look at the happy times in your most dark moments in life. A gut wrenching- screaming at the top of your lungs kind of movie.
I watched again and again. It is really a masterpiece.

He Shawshank Redemption is written and directed by Frank Darabont. It is an adaptation of the Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. Starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, the film portrays the story of Andy Dufresne (Robbins), a banker who is sentenced to two life sentences at Shawshank State Prison for apparently murdering his wife and her lover. Andy finds it tough going but finds solace in the friendship he forms with fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding (Freeman). While things start to pick up when the warden finds Andy a prison job more befitting his talents as a banker. However, the arrival of another inmate is going to vastly change things for all of them.

This was, put simply, the longest film I've ever seen. I've spent many an hour watching movies. Some of them were good. Some of them were bad. Some of them reached me so deep inside that I spent days afterward thinking about them. But the experience, watching the film itself, always lasted between one to four hours.

With "The Shawshank Redemption," the experience lasted twenty years.

I wasn't bored. At first, I was skeptical about this film. Some movies which ranked high in the IMDb weren't worthy; for example, "Batman Begins." My skepticism was so strong that it prevented me from entering the film with awe. But after a while, I found myself completely immersed in Red's narrative.

It is useless to try and explain the experience of watching this film. But I can say one thing more.

This film was the first film that brought tears of joy to my eyes. I ended up smiling and then chuckling. And then I felt a streak of water run down my cheek. And I realized I just experienced the ultimate movie: the life story of people I wouldn't have known other wise, and as real and as good as it gets.
I could watch The Shawshank Redemption, 10 times in the row... over and over again! OMG, what a movie!!!

What makes this film one of the best ever made is the message it conveys. It is one of eternal hope. Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, has been sent to prison for a crime he did not commit. But he never loses hope. He never gives up his quest to become a free man again. His years of tenacity, patience and wits keep him not only sane, but it gives his mind and a spirit a will to live. This film has a different feel to it. There has never been anything like it before and I don't know if there will again.

One of my all time favorites. Shawshank Redemption is a very moving story about hope and the power of friendship. The cast is first rate with everyone giving a great performance. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman carry the movie, but Bob Gunton and Clancy Brown are perfect as the Warden Norton and prison guard captain Hadley respectively. And James Whitmore's portrail of an elderly inmate Brooks is moving. The screenplay gives almost every actor at least one or more memorable lines through out the film. As well as a very surprising "twist" near the end that almost knocked me out of my chair. If you have not seen this movie rent it or better yet buy it. As I bet you'll want to see this one more than once.

Shawshank Redemption is the most perfect movie I've ever seen, right from flawless acting and razor-sharp screenplay to an amazing background score. A lot of thought has gone into every scene and every scene flows smoothly into the next with no abrupt transitions. Though Andy Dufresne is the central character of the movie, the characters of Brookes and Red are also vital to the theme of the Shawshank Redemption. Scenes of brutal violence in the prison have the intended effect on the audience without being too gory.

One of the few movies that have driven home the power of hope so effectively, this is one movie that will lift your spirits in times of gloom.

I remember as a child watching with awe Disney movies like the lion king and Aladdin and used to think it wont Get any better than this. Then as i matured i watched many more movies That again gave me that sense of happiness that i was fortunate enough To be able to experience such great movies in my life time. But quite soon, all these Hollywood movies started to seem quite stereotypical and quite run of the mill stuff. I used to think that Hollywood had lost its magic for me. Then came along this movie which I Watched 15 years after its release. I must admit that i watched it out Of curiosity for its being on the top of the IMDb list. And i was Skeptical of its quality, given the name was not too much of an eye Catcher plus the fact that it did not win any Oscars. How wrong i was! Hollywood has outdone itself once again. I could write a whole book on The greatness of this film, the acting, the direction, the soundtrack .. I mean it doesn't have any action sequences or any romance or Anything of the sort. But it is one of those films that makes you feel Happy inside and yet sad that you may live many more years and watch Tons of movies but never feel the same climax or emotion that you get Out of this movie. I have seen both Forrest gimp and Pulp fiction which Truly are masterpieces on their own, i truly love those movies. But Really, its nothing short of a crime to not award the Shaw-shank Redemption the best movie of the millennium, let alone the best movie of The year. I guess the box office reception of this movie had something To do with it not winning the award. A must watch for anyone having an Iota of emotion and love for artistic work.

No, I refuse to understand why this undoubtedly very good film is considered by many to be the best of the best. I would not be surprised if this film was in the top ten, but I can not accept the fact that for people this particular topic is the main one. The theme of the film, in two words, is freedom and hope. Indeed, these are the most important concepts in life, but I reviewed this film many times, and with all my desire I could not say after the credits that this movie revealed these words in full. The popularity of this film, or rather not even popularity, but a high rating and high ratings, is primarily due to the herd instinct. That's all.

I do not agree that the theme of freedom should be shown precisely on the example of a prison. It can be shown like this, but then I can't call it brilliant, and the rating obliges me to do it. But I will never say that this movie is the best.

All those who consider the topic of release from prison the most relevant for themselves, have you all been sitting there? They will answer me: 'meaning inner freedom' and all that. But nevertheless, you consider the prison-themed film to be the best film about freedom... The film 'Braveheart' reveals this concept much deeper and more extensively, but the struggle for the freedom of an entire nation is apparently placed lower than this very struggle of a single person.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasize that I am by no means trying to criticize the film as a project. I just want to say that he should not be in the first place in the rankings.

The Shawshank Redemption" is not a depressing story at all as many think. There is a lot of life and humor in it, and warmth in the friendship that builds up between Andy and Red. There is even excitement and suspense, although not when we expect it. But mostly the film is an allegory about holding onto a sense of personal worth, despite everything. If the film is perhaps a little slow in its middle passages, maybe that is part of the idea, too, to give us a sense of the leaden passage of time, before the glory of the final redemption. The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.
Masterpiece! The flow of images, acting, lighting, music.. all perfectly alligned. A harmonious balance of powerful storytelling!

The Shawshank Redemption is a timeless classic of American cinema that tells the story of two inmates, Andy Dufresne and Ellis Boyce, who form a close bond while serving time in the Shawshank State Penitentiary. From the very beginning, it is clear that this will be a deeply moving and emotionally powerful film, as we are introduced to the characters and their respective circumstances.

One of the things that stands out most about The Shawshank Redemption is its incredible cast of actors, who deliver some of the most memorable and nuanced performances of their careers. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins are particularly standout as Andy and Ellis, respectively, and their on-screen chemistry is electric.

The film's narrative is also incredibly well-written, with a compelling story that keeps us engaged and invested throughout. The Shawshank Redemption is a film that explores the human experience in a way that is both universal and deeply personal, and it is this combination of compelling characters and a well-crafted story that makes it such a timeless and enduring classic.

In conclusion, The Shawshank Redemption is a film that should not be missed. It is a masterpiece of American cinema that will leave a lasting impression on anyone who sees it. If you have not yet had the pleasure of experiencing this film, I highly recommend that you seek it out as soon as possible. It is an experience that you will not soon forget.

One of the last places you would expect to see a movie about hope and the deep bonds of friendship takes place in a prison. This drama is a worthy top 100 film, and I believe that is where it will stay for many years to come. There is a fair amount of explicit language throughout the movie, so for those that cannot tolerate language, this may ruin the redeeming qualities of the movie for you.

This is the best movie ever but I give you 15 Things You May Not Have Known About The Shawshank Redemption

1. It's Based on a Novella by Stephen King The film is based on Stephen King's novella "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption," which was published in a short story collection called Different Seasons. Two of the other short stories in the collection were made into films, Stand By Me in 1986 and Apt Pupil in 1998. Only one of them, "The Breathing Method," has not been turned into a movie.

2. It's Similar to Tolstoy King's novella shares several plot points with a nine-page short story by Russian writer Leo Tolstoy called "God Sees the Truth, But Waits." Both are about men sent to prison for murders they didn't commit.

3. Director Frank Darabont Got a Good Deal on the Rights to King's Story He bought the rights from King for $1.

4. It Almost Had a Much Different Cast Castle Rock Entertainment, the studio that made Shawshank, was co-founded by Rob Reiner—director of another King adaptation, Stand By Me—and is named after the mythical Maine town that provides the setting for many of King's books. After director Frank Darabont pitched Shawshank to the studio, Reiner originally offered $2.5 million for the script to star Tom Cruise as Andy Dufresne and Harrison Ford as Red.

5. The Original Title Was Changed to Avoid Confusion Darabont wrote the script in eight weeks before pitching it to Castle Rock Entertainment. He decided to drop the "Rita Hayworth" part of the novella because actresses sent their resumes in for consideration thinking it was a Rita Hayworth biopic. During the casting process, Darabont even received a call from an agent who represented a supermodel; he swore the script was the best she had ever read and that she'd be perfect for the (non-existent) part of Hayworth.

6. It Was Filmed in Ohio Although the film is set in Maine, the Ohio State Reformatory in Mansfield, Ohio stood in for Shawshank Prison. The structure was slated to be torn down, but the production delayed the demolition for a year. After the film wrapped, all the buildings in the complex were torn down except the cell block and main administrative building, which were preserved for historical purposes.

7. Morgan Freeman Got Really Good at Catch The scene where Andy first approaches Red about the rock hammer as Red plays catch in the main yard took nine hours to shoot. Freeman continued to play catch for the whole nine hours without complaining and showed up the next day with his arm in a sling.

8. The Film Was Inspired by Goodfellas Darabont says his main source of inspiration was Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas because of its use of voice-over narration and editing techniques.

9. Voiceovers Are Tricky Business Originally, all of Morgan Freeman's voice-over was recorded before any of the film was shot. The fact that much of it syncs up to the on screen action (see: the scene on the roof where the inmates drink beer) isn't simple editing. Darabont would playback the recorded voice-over on-set during each take for the actors to specifically play off of the audio. But the audio quality of his voice-over was too poor to include in the movie due to tape hiss, so Freeman had to re-record the entire voice-over in post-production.

10. They Got Lucky with One of the Most Famous Scenes Every take of the film's signature shot of Tim Robbins raising his arms outstretched in the rain after Andy breaks out of prison was out of focus except the one in the film. It was the final take shot for that scene.

11. The Prop Guy Was a Jokester The visual joke of Andy's rock hammer being tucked into the Bible right after the first page of the Book of Exodus came from the film's prop master Tom Shaw.

12. None of the Close-up Shots of Andy's Hands or Feet are Tim Robbins They're director Frank Darabont.

13. Stephen King's Red Was Changed for the Film In the original novella, Red is described as a middle-aged Irishman.

14. The Mug Shot of Young Red Isn't Morgan Freeman It's actually a photo of his son.

15. The Tree Where Red Finds Andy's letter Isn't in Fort Hancock, Texas It's in Ohio's Malabar Farm State Park.

I'm trying to save you money; this is the last film title that you should consider borrowing. Renting Shawshank will cost you five bucks... just plunk down the $25 and own the title. You'll wind up going back to this gem time and time again. This is one of few movies that are truly timeless. And it's entertaining and moving, no matter how many times you view it.

Forget about what others (including myself) might suggest you'll discover in "The Shawshank Redemption;" when you watch it, you'll identify something very personal in your own life with a scene, a character, or a moment in this uncomplicated movie. When you need hope, you'll look for Shawshank. When you want to believe in the will of overcoming even the greatest obstacles, Shawshank will uplift you in ways that you can't find in movies today.

Some liken the film to some kind of spiritual awakening. Of course, some can go to a church or mosque to find enlightenment and Faith in humanity, but most places of worship are open only certain days or times. But when you need affirmation of the lasting bond of friendships that prevail over the most dire circumstances, Shawshank will give it to you. It makes grown men (like me) cry, still. I wonder whether Shawshank was truly meant for viewing in the privacy of the home, because it is a personal experience that really makes you look inward. Nominated for seven, this is the best film that never one a single Oscar.

From Andy's arrival on the prison bus to the film's end, we see only how others see him - Red, who becomes his best friend, Brooks the old librarian, the corrupt Warden Norton, guards and prisoners. Red is our surrogate. He's the one we identify with, and the redemption, when it comes, is Red's. We've been shown by Andy's example that you have to keep true to yourself, not lose hope, bide your time, set a quiet example and look for your chance. "I guess it comes down to a simple choice, really," he tells Red. "Get busy living' or get busy dying '."

The key to the film's structure, I think, is that it's not about its hero, but about our relationship with him - our curiosity, our pity, our admiration. If Andy had been the heroic center, bravely enduring, the film would have been conventional, and less mysterious. But we wonder about this guy. Did he really kill those two people? Why does he keep so much to himself? Why can he amble through the prison yard like a free man on a stroll, when everyone else plods or sidles?

People like excitement at the movies, and titles that provide it do well. Films about "redemption" are approached with great wariness; a lot of people are not thrilled by the prospect of a great film - it sounds like work. But there's a hunger for messages of hope, and when a film offers one, it's likely to have staying power even if it doesn't grab an immediate audience.

"The Shawshank Redemption" premiered at the Toronto Film Festival in September 1994, and opened a few weeks later. It got good reviews but did poor business (its $18 million original gross didn't cover costs; it took in only another $10 million after winning seven Oscar nominations, including best picture).

There wasn't much going for it: It had a terrible title, it was a "prison drama" and women don't like those, it contained almost no action, it starred actors who were respected but not big stars, and it was long at 142 minutes. Clearly this was a movie that needed word-of-mouth to find an audience, and indeed business was slowly but steadily growing when it was yanked from theaters. If it had been left to find its way, it might have continued to build and run for months, but that's not what happened.

I am new to commenting on movies, so maybe I shouldn't have started with trying to put the Shawshank Redemption into words. The themes of hope, depression, friendship, greed, and triumph connect with the best acting I have ever seen in a movie. The actors are so good, you begin to look at Morgan Freeman in real life as "Red" and Tim Robbins as "Andy". The humor is ever present, such as conversations held by the inmates. But perhaps the very best thing for an average viewer is the constant surprises. I'm not talking about monsters jumping from trees, I'm talking about how every time the movie starts to seem to get slow BAM! something happens that represents one of the themes. If you have not seen this movie, maybe because the fact that it is a "prison movie," or maybe because it is now eleven years old, you have missed out on a life experience. The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont

It tells the story of banker Andy Dufresne,who is sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary for the murder of his wife & her lover,despite his claims of innocence.

This Movie Filmed the Reality of a Murderer's life inside the Prison. The Movie Seeds Excitment in Viewer & some Mysterious Moments Twist's the Normal Flow of the Movie and brought changes in his life.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is an exceptional cinematic masterpiece that transcends genres and captivates audiences with its powerful storytelling, compelling characters, and a profound exploration of hope and redemption. Directed by Frank Darabont and released in 1994, this film has stood the test of time and continues to be regarded as one of the greatest movies ever made.

Based on Stephen King's novella, the film tells the poignant tale of Andy Dufresne (played by Tim Robbins), a young banker who is wrongfully convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment at Shawshank State Penitentiary. Within the confines of this brutal and corrupt prison, Andy befriends Red (played by Morgan Freeman), a seasoned inmate known for his resourcefulness and wisdom. Their unlikely friendship becomes the heart and soul of the narrative, weaving a profound and inspiring tale of resilience, friendship, and the indomitable human spirit.

The film's greatest strength lies in its ability to delve deep into the complexities of the human experience, exploring themes of hope, determination, and the quest for freedom. The script, penned by Darabont himself, is a work of art, striking a perfect balance between heart-wrenching moments and subtle humor. The dialogue is rich with meaning, and every line is delivered with remarkable conviction by the talented ensemble cast.

Tim Robbins delivers an outstanding performance as Andy Dufresne, infusing the character with a quiet strength and unwavering determination. Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Red is nothing short of remarkable, as he effortlessly embodies the role of a wise and observant inmate. Their chemistry is palpable, and their nuanced performances bring depth and authenticity to the story.

The film's cinematography, by Roger Deakins, is visually stunning, capturing the bleakness of prison life juxtaposed with moments of transcendent beauty. The deliberate use of lighting and shadows creates a haunting atmosphere, perfectly complementing the narrative's tone.

"The Shawshank Redemption" boasts a masterful pace, keeping viewers engaged throughout its nearly two-and-a-half-hour runtime. The unfolding of the story is expertly crafted, with every twist and turn leaving a lasting impact. As the plot unravels, the film explores the intricate dynamics of prison life, shedding light on the corruption and power struggles that exist within the system.

However, what truly sets this film apart is its unwavering message of hope. Despite the harsh realities of prison life, "The Shawshank Redemption" portrays the resilience of the human spirit and the possibility of redemption in the most unlikely of circumstances. It reminds us that no matter how dark life may seem, there is always a glimmer of hope that can lead to a brighter future.

In conclusion, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a timeless masterpiece that deserves all the accolades it has received over the years. With its exceptional performances, profound storytelling, and enduring themes, it remains an unforgettable cinematic experience that resonates with audiences of all generations. This film is a testament to the power of hope, friendship, and the human capacity for redemption. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the transformative nature of cinema and its ability to touch the depths of our souls.

The Shawshank Redemption is a timeless classic that deserves its place among the great films of all time. With a 9 out of 10 rating, this movie is a must-watch for any movie lover. The storyline is captivating and keeps you on the edge of your seat, while the characters are richly drawn and bring depth to the film. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman deliver powerhouse performances that are sure to stay with you long after the credits roll. The themes of hope, friendship, and perseverance are expertly woven into the fabric of this movie, making it a truly uplifting and inspiring experience. If you haven't seen The Shawshank Redemption, do yourself a favor and watch it today.
The score was magnificent, which is no surprise seeing as it was by Thomas Newman, and the direction by Frank Darabont was masterful, especially considering this was his first film.

This is by far the best character drama I have seen. The acting is believable and powerful, the shots are perfectly framed, the story is interesting and keeps you hooked, and the comedy, while in short supply, is appropriately dark. Andy Dufresne is a relatable protagonist, and thus it is easy to connect with his struggles, and understand how he feels about being thrown into the life of a convicted criminal. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins give us incredible performances, along with everyone else in the movie. On top of that, the ending is one of the best ever put on screen. I would recommend this film to everyone who likes the industry, and consider it a must-see cinematic classic.

For a simple story which can be described in two or three sentences, the emotional impact this film has is surprising. 'The Shawshank Redemption' follows the maturation of a friendship over a thirty-year period, during which two men grow close in a cruel and brutal prison in New England. Based on a story by Stephen King, that author whose work has inspired such cheesy screen fare such as 'Thinner' and 'Needful Things', the film comes as a surprise. I had always though Forrest Gump was a great movie until I saw Shawshank. One of the strongest thoughts I had after seeing this film was that we, as a society, are wrong to sentence a man to endless years in prison. A controversial view, but it makes sense when compared to the world in the film. Hope, friendship, and an unwillingness to be broken are the main messages in a story that is beautifully filmed and flawlessly acted. Tim Robbins did deserve an Academy Award much more than Tom Hanks did, and I was disappointed to see that even Morgan Freeman's excellent turn as 'Red' slipped by Academy voters. Ah well, it's the same awards panel that gave the Best Picture nod to 'Titanic'. The world does not always make sense, 'Shawshank' teaches us. Bad things happen to good people, and it's who you are after the storm has passed that show us who, and what, we are.

The Shawshank Redemption is a movie that slid through the Theatres without drawing much deserved attention. It made no real impact at the academy award either. So why is this movie currently holding the second spot at the imdb top 250, only beaten by the untouchable "Il Padrino"? First of all, I believe the movie is spot on when it comes to the description of human endurance, persistence, and adaptation. The development of the characters also indicates that imprisonment and freedom can't always be divided by walls alone. Sometimes the highest walls and the worst conditions aren't enough to stop the human spirit, other times the absence of boundaries and even the prospect of something better, can break you down if you lack some of your primal needs. This is where I believe the greatness of this movie really shows. It perfectly pinpoints the vast scope of the human mind, and how we react both similar and differently to challenges in life, and the movie does so in a simple, straightforward way! As "Red" says upon the climax of this marvellous movie: "Every man has his breaking point"

There has never been anything like it before and I don't know if there will again. I'm not going to say any more about this film, it has already been said, but just suffice to say that I am glad that Forrest Gump won best picture in 94. He shines when it is his time to go back into the world, only to find that the world grew up so fast he never even got a chance to blink. Stephen King's story is brought to the screen with great elegance and excitement.

There are a few mistakes in this movie, but nothing real significant. The dialogue, and Morgan Freeman's monologue were perfect; went perfectly with the flow of the movie. This movie has the best finale of any movie that I've ever seen.

This film is about one thing and one thing only: HOPE. Hope will get you through anything!

Oh, and if you haven't already done so, don't bother reading the Stephen King novella from which this film is based. It foreshadows the ending a little too much and takes away that anxiety you get as you near the end of the film.

The Shawshank Redemption is, without peer, the best movie of all time. Although it may have a somewhat limited plot ( then again which film doesn't?) it makes this up with the sequences of bizarre twists and turns.

Andy Dufrene claims he was wrongly convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. The prison he is sent to is brutal - a hypocritical church-going warden who murders inmates for his own gain - and sodomy is prevalent. Andy's character is determined to survive through all of his hardships.

The rest of the characters are so complex that to describe them would merely dampen everyone elses opinion on the film. I know it was nominated for some Academy Awards, and didn't win any, but it deserved more than Titanic!

It is didactic and its main theme is hope. In fact the last few lines of the film always bring tears to my eyes - "I hope to see my friend, and shake his hand. I hope the Pacific is as blue as it has been in my mind. I hope." These words, uttered by Morgan Freemon are truely inspirational words.

My opinion is watch this movie as often as possible, and learn from it.

To say that The Shawshank Redemption is an exquisite piece of film-work doesn't even begin to scratch the surface of how this film can and will affect those that choose to view it. Yes, some points are brought violently to the surface, yet throughout Shawshank, there is a subtlety to the relationships between all of the characters, not just the lead roles. I have read a copy of the original screenplay, and although many "adjustments" were made by Frank Darabont, I honestly believe that absolutely nothing could be added or even taken away to improve this work in any way. And as strange as it may seem to my friends who ask, yes, being a woman, The Shawshank Redemption is my favorite film of all time. And yes, "hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things..."

I've recently been going through my vast collection of videos, replaying my favorites in an effort to determine which is best.

Without question, "Shawshank Redemption" towers above all the others, even "The Godfather," which slightly outranks it in the IMDb list of 250 best movies.

I have also taken the trouble of looking up most of the reviews of the movie, and I remain puzzled at the criticism that even such respected critics as Roger Ebert gave the movie. The most prevalent criticism is that the movie is too long. I don't agree. "Shawshank" is perfectly paced. Another criticism, that the story-line is predictable, is absurd. What makes "Shawshank" stand out from all other movies is that nothing that happens in it has ever happened in a movie before. It is sui generis, in a class by itself. If you've seen it, you'll know what I mean. If you haven't seen it, drop everything else and get ahold of it.

I remember when this movie came out. It seemed like a ridiculous title, and I was more into Forrest Gump then spending any hard earned money on this movie. At the local multiplex, my date coerced me into going anyway, and it was one of the greatest cinematic experiences of my life. It's like the first time you saw The Godfather, or Star Wars. It has gradually become my all time favorite, and for two main reasons: One: to the new viewer, it may appear a rough prison movie, but what lies ahead is the enchanting tale of hope, and the enduring bond of true friendship, themes that do not appear in too many modern films. The second reason is that after multiple viewings, i have yet to tire of it. It grips me each time. Perhaps it is the subtle introduction, or the mesmerizing ending. This is the only movie I would ever dream of giving a perfect score...............

This whole movie is about the real meaning of freedom, what it is and what it means to us. Those who have already seen it a couple of times know that each watching reveals another story beneath a story, and that in the end you end up asking yourself if it was not the best lecture on the thinness of the line between good and bad that you would ever have.

Not for a single moment your attention falters from what happens on the big screen. Superbly directed and superbly cast, this movie might as well be compared to a superbly orchestrated and performed symphony.

A must for everyone out for a good feature!

I am not a writer, consequently any review I might make will not capture the essence of what I wanted to articulate. Therefore instead of a review, I'll give a statement regarding this film: This is one of the few times where a film's success, it's overall feeling and merits, surpasses that of the book (or in this case story), and in stating this, there should be no diminution to what Stephen King wrote.

In regards to books being made into films, I feel that each version (film and story) itself enhances the other, and each should not be compared or critiqued for what is lacking, or plentiful. Instead, they should each be looked upon as a separate entity, with each 'form' evoking our emotions in their own unique and separate way!

In order to make these statements, I have to say that I have read the Stephen King short story (or novella), "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption". I have also listened to the audio-book, and all three inspire, give hope and yes even define the word 'Redemption', in their own unique ways.

One might not be able to fairly compare an apple's flavour, to that of an orange, but you certainly can compare a Granny Smith to a Red Delicious. They are both apples at the core, it's the texture, pulp and flavour that make it different. That core could be a story, and each medium (written, visual, audio etc) provides a similar, yet unique flavour to be savored!

OK. This is definitely my favorite movie of all time. The acting by all actors is superb, especially the roles of Dufresne and Red, played by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. I have been a fan of the story by Stephen King ever since I read it in high school. When I heard that Frank Darabont, who also directed a short King film (The Woman in the Room) in 1983, would be writing the screenplay and directing I was ecstatic. This film could not have been adapted better by Kubrick or King himself. Can't wait for The Green Mile, Frank.

I've seen some good movies in my time (The Godfather part1 + 2 come to mind), but, I can honestly say that none have moved me like this. I love the sence of hope that it gives anyone, and the fact that despite everything else, Andy Dufrense, still has hope. "Get Busy livin' or get busy dyin'!" A friend of mine recomended it to me, as the greatest movie he's ever seen. I have to agree.

>I just loved it, and with Hollywood would try harder at making good movies as opposed to trashy, shallow, movies that are aimed at the lowest common denominator.

Rating out-of-10? Guess!

This is my favorite movie of all time. It is about one man's struggle of trying to cope with his life in prison sentence for a crime he didnt commit. This movie make prisoners look like true human beings, not just savages. You really learn about each of the characters. Morgan Freeman gives a great role as Red, who stands by Andy in every instance.

I really don't like Stephen King very much, but every once in a while he really surprises me (Stand By Me and Shawshank Redemption). I also am not a very big fan of prison movies either, but this definitely is the exception. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman are both outstanding in this film. Their characters are completely convincing. This is the best film of the 1990's in my opinion, and my favorite of all time.

This is a rare movie that deserves a 10 - My reasoning; that I would not change one single, solitary thing about it, period.

This is arguably my favorite movie of all time. It fails to become boring despite repeated viewings.
This movie is terrible the worst I've ever watched bruh not worth a penny!

my comments of this film will be brief. it is a quite simply a rewarding film in which the acting is very moving and the actual storyline is superb iwas engrossed in the film from start to finish. it was a drama of what life can throw back at you in the extreme.not been a writing man i will close with the words i think describe this truly great film. moving,thought provoking,and one of the best films of its kind.

This movie is a work of art , it is a movie that makes you think about how great it is to be alive and free , and how other peoples may have a struggle each day to stay alive and free , in the mind of themselves ,for a start .

Anyone out there who takes the Academy Awards seriously is out of touch to say the least. If there has ever been a film made that was actually deserving of sweeping the Oscars it's "Shawshank". Not only should it have won the 7 Oscars it was up for, but several others it did not even get nominations for.

Terence Marsh deserved another Oscar for his set design (yes, that was a set) of the amazing prison. James Whitmore gave a performance as great as any supporting actor that year. How Tim Robbins did not join Morgan Freeman in the Best Actor category (take your pick who to give the Oscar to) is beyond me. And the saddest thing, next to the film not winning Best Picture, is that Frank Darabont did not take home the Best Director Oscar that was so rightfully his.

The Academy will continue handing out its Oscars for "The Best Picture of the Year" to movies like Titanic, The English Patient, and Forrest Gump. I guess The Shawshank Redemption will have to settle for "The Greatest Movie Ever Made".

It's easy to see why the film has received such a high rating; it's breathtaking. What can I say that hasn't said before? Mostly the plot, acting, and premise; but this film is most notable for how it leaves you feeling after watching it. When you watch a film, you may not remember it for days, but this film has a way of staying with you.

It's the ultimate tale of friendship, hope and perseverance in the face of hardship.

It's not my favourite, but I can see why so many people regard it as one of the greatest films of all time. I urge you to watch it again if you haven't or haven't done so in a while. 10/10.

If an alien who knows nothing about the Academy Awards were to suddenly land on earth and then introduced to the Academy Awards and asked to watch the nominated movies for 1995 and then shown the results, she would have absolutely no respect for the Academy Awards. Shawshank Redemption is pure genius at every level: acting, script, cinematography, character development, and on and on and on. Movies don't get much better than this!

The moral of the story is that there are great movies and performances out there that have not been properly recognized by the Academy, so make sure an award is not the only criterion you use when searching for a truly great film.

This movie was deeply moving. I have seen it about six times so far and cried the first four times I saw it. As a person who has at times felt as if I was sentenced to "the hole", I could relate to Andy and to Red. Perhaps that is one reason the movie has touched so many people.

The message and heart in this film is profound. When Red said, "I hope....." at the end of the movie, I was hoping too.

After I saw Darabont's "Green Mile" I heard that he had another movie, and I had to see it. I taped Shawshank on TV and watched it, not expecting a lot. Well, it wasn't as good as "Green Mile," but it was pretty darned close, and it was quite similar in terms of themes and character types. I thought the warden was terrific. I was so engrossed in the movie, I wanted to strangle the man myself. Although many say the movie was predictable, I was quite surprised by the ending. As in the case of the "Green Mile," the awards Shawshank richly deserved were passed on to other, not so good, films. The only downside was the portrayal of the characters. The movie basically said that criminals are good guys, and the prison guards are villains. Isn't it the other way around?

I give Shawshank a 9/10

This is the greatest film ever made.

The story of Andy Dufersne, the man who have never lost his hope, who have always believed, that one day justice would have come to being, that one day he would have forgotten with the help of Pacific Ocean and his best friend Red Redding.

I have seen it maybe for twenty times and it is even better and better. Now I have great expectations about The Green Mile.

Hey, I have to say that this movie is one of my favorites. It is up on my top 10. Anyway, this movie is amazing. The story, the acting, and anything else you can think of make this movie a classic. Morgan Freeman (plays the character red) did an excellent job on his role. I think he was totally robbed when he didn't get the Oscar for best supporting actor. To get back on the movie, if you looking for a good one to watch, you have to see this. The movie is wonderfully played. Also hats off to the great job Tim Robbins did playing his main character Andy Dufresne. If you haven't seen this one, your missing out!!

It was really very easy to like this film - in fact, it was impossible for me NOT to like it. Maybe the key is the phenomenon that is called "lagom" in Sweden. That word doesn't exist in any other language, but it means something like "just right". Not too much, not to little.

I felt very comfortable after watching this film. It didn't change my life, didn't start a revolution - it was just a very good film!

Actually, the end was a bit unexpected. It gave the film a romantic touch that otherwise wouldn't have been there. The only bad thing is that I found details in the story too improbable, and that was a disturbing moment in that type of film. It wouldn't have mattered in an action-filled story, but now it made me irritated, because it stole attention from the story!! Anyway that detail doesn't stop me from really recommending this film - its simply "just right"!

This is the best movie of all time!!! It has all you need and more. Amazing performances by Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. This movie is a CLASSIC and will stand the test of time. The story has everything but it clearly presents the true ideas of friendship and relationships between people, especially under the worst situations. Anyone who hasnt seen this movie- DONT WALK_ RUN- to see it! It will stick with you forever

this movie is one of only 3 that I have on dvd right now, and I am so glad that I own it. anyone who is a movie fan of any kind should see this. this is an amazing movie shows what someone can do when they hope. andy duphresne was a character who had hope and kept it alive for 20 years even though he was in prison for life with a crime he didn't commit. every aspect of this movie: the camera work, the acting, the dialogue, and the story work together in a perfect blend of drama. the best part was when red came in for his 3rd parole hearing. his first 2 times, he had just told them what he thought they wanted to hear. "yes, I believe that i'm entirely cured. i believe that i am no longer a danger to society." he was rejected those 2 times. but the third he was honest, and the outcome was far different. A nearly perfect movie.

I love just drifting through the IMDb just to read others opinions on certain movies, and having checked out the comments on Shawshank Redemption, I'm amazed that some of the latest reviews are from people who have who have only just watched it in the last few weeks. I'm even more pleased that they acknowledge it as one of the best films made, and that it lived up to the hype that has passed via word of mouth. It is a criminal offence that it did not win a single Oscar but at least it not one of those films that will be classed as an undiscovered gem. Career best performances are brought out of all members of the cast: Clancy Brown, Bill Gunton and Bill Sadler will surely never hit those heights again. It may not have been a box office hit but all associated with the movie should feel proud. The cliche is true of The Shawshank Redemption: they don't make them like that any more. Spread the word!

The Shawshank Redemption, directed by Frank Darabont, is a timeless masterpiece that explores the themes of hope, friendship, and redemption. The film, based on the novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption by Stephen King, tells the story of Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a banker who is falsely convicted of the murder of his wife and her lover and sent to Shawshank prison.

The film's plot is well-crafted, and it skillfully balances moments of tension and despair with moments of hope and joy. The film's characters are well-developed, and their relationships are deep and nuanced. The chemistry between the two main leads, Andy and Red (Morgan Freeman), is particularly strong, and their friendship forms the heart of the movie.

The performances in The Shawshank Redemption are superb. Tim Robbins delivers a subtle and nuanced portrayal of Andy, while Morgan Freeman shines as the wise and world-weary Red. The supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Bob Gunton as the cruel and corrupt warden and William Sadler as the tragic figure of Heywood.

The film's cinematography is striking, with its use of shadows, low angles, and close-ups creating a sense of intimacy and claustrophobia that perfectly captures the atmosphere of the prison. The film's score, composed by Thomas Newman, is also outstanding, and it perfectly complements the film's themes and moods.

The Shawshank Redemption is a poignant and emotionally resonant film that has stood the test of time. It is a testament to the power of hope and friendship, and it is a reminder that even in the darkest of places, there is always a glimmer of light. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates great cinema.

Shawshank is a story about a man who is wrongly convicted for the murder of his wife and her lover. He finds himself in the pits of hell or what is commonly known as Shawshank Prison. There he learns about the power of truth and friendship as he changes the hearts of those he knows and lives with. This story is not about the problems of our justice or prison systems and the horrors that prisoners face, not only from their fellow inmates but also from those there to "manage" them; rather this story relays the close bond that people form in tough situations and how our will to survive is not just about whether or not we live but how we live. To quote William Wallace from Braveheart, "every man dies not every man lives." This is the story about choosing to live and live with dignity and friendship in the face of all hardships. Highly Recommended

There is no movie that I love more than The Shawshank Redemption. I have seen the movie at least 10 times, and it never ceases to amaze me how well it is performed. The plot line is one of the best that I have seen in a long time, and Tim Robbins plays his character as if he were living in that life. The most amazing thing happened after I watched this movie: I started to regard everyone with the same "look inside of me instead of at me" view, and have lately even started to think "innocent until PROVEN guilty" and not "he looks guilty so he must be." If you have not seen this movie, you are missing out on an extremely well written and performed piece of art. I highly reccomend it. In fact, I urge anyone who has not seen it to rent it tonight.

In 1946, a banker named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted of a double murder, even though he stubbornly proclaims his innocence. He's sentenced to a life term at the Shawshank State Prison in Maine, where another lifer, Ellis Red Redding (Morgan Freeman), picks him as the new recruit most likely to crack under the pressure. The ugly realities of prison life are quickly introduced to Andy: a corrupt warden (Bob Gunton), sadistic guards led by Capt. Byron Hadley (Clancy Brown), and inmates who are little better than animals, willing to use rape or beatings to insure their dominance. But Andy does not crack: he has the hope of the truly innocent, which (together with his smarts) allow him to prevail behind bars. He uses his banking skills to win favor with the warden and the guards, doing the books for Norton's illegal business schemes and keeping an eye on the investments of most of the prison staff. In exchange, he is able to improve the prison library and bring some dignity and respect back to many of the inmates, including Red. Based on a story by Stephen King,

In Shawshank Prison, we as the audience find lovable and characters we can relate and sympaphise with. Even though they are convicts, murderers, etc...

The acting is the strongest point in the film, as the characters played magnificently and uplifting by people Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman.

Overall, The Shawshank Redmption will always be considered one of the greatest movies ever made, and a personal favourite of mine

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a 1994 drama film directed by Frank Darabont, based on a novella by Stephen King. The film follows the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is wrongfully convicted of a crime and sent to the Shawshank prison. Inside the prison, Andy forms a friendship with a fellow inmate named Red and struggles to survive in the brutal environment.

The film explores themes of hope, friendship, perseverance, and the resilience of the human spirit. It is a powerful and emotional story that showcases the human capacity for redemption and the importance of never losing hope in the face of adversity.

The performances of the cast, the cinematography, and the music are all top-notch, making "The Shawshank Redemption" a timeless classic that has resonated with audiences for decades. Even if you're not a fan of the genre, the film's universal themes and powerful storytelling will leave a lasting impression on you.

I consider myself an avid movie-watcher with mostly mainstream choices for my favorite movies. One of my favorite genres is inspirational movies like Rudy, Contact, and October Sky. Tops on my list of any genre is The Shawshank Redemption. One of the driving factors that it tops my list is because, like everyone else, I watched the movie on video with absolutely no expectations. At the time I had not seen a review, trailer, commercial, or even the cover of the video box for the movie. My wife went to the video store for me to rent it only because I heard it got nominated for an Academy Award for Best Picture. We popped the movie in around 11:00 p.m., thinking we will fall asleep during the movie. Well, two hours later, the only way we could describe the movie would be inspirational. After the movie, I started to notice the commercials, the posters, and the box cover all gave references to the crucial twist at the end. I think if I saw any of these things before I watched the movie then I would have put 2 and 2 together and it would have made the movie less enjoyable. Word of mouth is the reason why it has been such a hit on video, and in the future will be the reason it will be considered on of the greatest movies of all time.
This is such an amazing movie I have ever seen. The director and all other crew knows how to integrate audience with story.

I try not to compare Papilon and Shawshank Redemption but most of you will agree with me that there are bits of story or narrative elemnts that runs simultaneously in this film. Both films have a succesful business man being acused of a crime and then being thrown into jail where they make new friends. Both story also shows how the main characters try to escape from prison. However The DShawshank stoodout from the normal narrative of the hollywood classicall system. The hollywood three act structre was recreated in a mster piece style. Papilon had a normal way of narrating the story but Shawshank Redemption treated this film differently even though the story lines had some similarities.

Awesome!i want to watch more story related to this movie.Tied for the best movie I have ever seen carflo26 November 2003 Why do I want to write the 234th comment on The Shawshank Redemption?
