The only other movie I have ever seen that effects me as strongly is To Kill a Mockingbird. Both movies leave me feeling cleaner for having watched them.

I didn't intend to see this movie at all: I do not like prison movies and I don't normally watch them. I work at a branch library and one day as I was checking The Shawshank Redemption out to one of our older patrons, she said to me, "Whenever I feel down or depressed, I check out this movie and watch it and it always makes me feel better." At the time, I thought that was very strange. One day there was nothing on TV except things I absolutely would not watch under any circumstance or things that I had seen too many times already. I remembered what she said, so I watched it. I have watched it many many times since then and it gets better with every showing.

No action, no special effects - just men in prison uniforms talking to each other.

The Shawshank Redemption and To Kill a Mockingbird are the best movies I have ever seen. I do not judge it by it's technical merits - I don't really care about that. I have read that Citizen Kane or The Godfather or this or that movie is the best movie ever made. In a world saturated with cinematic masterpieces, it takes something truly exceptional to stand out. "The Shawshank Redemption" (1994), directed by Frank Darabont and adapted from Stephen King's novella, is a shining beacon of such rarity. With its evocative storytelling and unforgettable characters, this epic drama transcends genres and cements itself in the annals of film history. It is not just a movie, but a symphony of emotions - one that will make you laugh, weep, and ultimately, revel in the indomitable human spirit.

The plot unwinds in the confines of Shawshank State Penitentiary, a place where hopes and dreams go to wither and die. But for Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), an enigmatic and falsely accused banker, this prison serves as a crucible of metamorphosis. His journey of self-discovery and friendship with fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman) is the heart and soul of the movie. Through their eyes, we are shown a world where friendship blooms in the harshest conditions, and hope becomes an act of defiance.

As the prison walls close in on the inmates, the film's cinematography takes our breath away. The sweeping shots of the imposing penitentiary and the iconic scene of Andy standing triumphant in the rain will forever be etched in our collective memory. The movie paints a vivid portrait of the inescapable human condition; our laughter is juxtaposed with heart-wrenching tears, and our fears are confronted by the resolute power of hope.

But what truly sets "The Shawshank Redemption" apart is its mastery of storytelling. The narrative is at once a riveting tale of camaraderie and an allegory of the human spirit's resilience. With every seemingly inconsequential detail weaved into the fabric of the story, Darabont brings King's novella to life with a finesse that leaves the audience spellbound. The movie's dramatic crescendo - the masterful escape of Andy - is a cinematic tour de force, an exhilarating testament to the power of hope and determination.

The ensemble cast is nothing short of extraordinary, led by Robbins and Freeman, who infuse their characters with quiet dignity and raw vulnerability. Their performances are imbued with grace and gravitas, making their friendship a beacon of light in the abyss of despair. The supporting cast, including Bob Gunton as the merciless Warden Norton and Clancy Brown as the brutal Captain Hadley, offers a compelling portrayal of the darker side of human nature.

As the end credits roll, one cannot help but be left awestruck by the film's hauntingly beautiful score, composed by Thomas Newman. His melodies linger long after the screen fades to black, serving as a poignant reminder of the emotional odyssey we have just witnessed.

In the pantheon of great cinema, "The Shawshank Redemption" stands proud as an enduring testament to the power of friendship and the unyielding resilience of the human spirit. It is a story that transcends time and space, a tale of redemption that reaches into the very depths of our souls. As you laugh and cry, remember that in the darkest of times, hope will always find a way. This film is not just a masterpiece; it is the quintessential human experience, immortalized on celluloid for eternity.

On Sept. 23, 1994, after a premiere at the Toronto film fest, The Shawshank Redemption hit theaters nationwide. The Morgan Freeman film eventually nabbed seven Oscar nominations. The Hollywood Reporter's original review is below:

Castle Rock has tapped into the wellspring of yet another Stephen King novella, from the same collection as Stand by Me. While it seems unlikely that this well-wrought film about hope and friendship in a maximum security prison will do Stand by Me-level business, The Shawshank Redemption should appeal to a mature audience. The marketing challenge will be to lure a mainstream audience to this dark drama starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman with, to boot, an enigmatic title.

Covering a span of time from 1946 to 1967, Shawshank focuses on the plight of a Maine banker, Andy Dufresne (Robbins), sentenced to two life terms for the murder of his wife and lover. Laconic and a bit chilly, Andy is somewhat of an outcast among the uneducated, macho thugs who make up the main brunt of the prison population.

Admittedly, he's not an easy guy to get to know and only comes to enjoy a prison friendship when he makes a deal with the prison black-market supplier, Red (Freeman), to get him a tiny hammer for his rock collection. Red is also an enigma to most of the inmates. He keeps his nose clean and his hopes up even though the parole board routinely denies him pardon, obviously a racial antagonism.

While the story roils with some rousing prison-type action and is coarsened by an overpowering sense of frustration, The Shawshank Redemption is really about the unlikely friendship between Andy and Red: Each nurtures the other and serves as a touchstone for keeping their sanity intact.

Frank Darabont's writing and direction are generally crisp, but Shawshank is a tough watch and audiences could use some time cut from its 142 minutes.

The Shawshank Redemption is a timeless classic that will send the viewer through multiple emotions with its multi-layered fascinating plot. I often get asked by those who haven't seen the film: "what's it about?", but I never know how to answer that question. The truth is that I don't feel that I can briefly summarise such a stunning beautiful film whilst doing it full justice. All I can say is that I can guarantee that if you don't love it, that you will at least very much like it. It's no fluke that this film stands at #1 in the IMDb top 250.

Despite deservedly winning a mere 14 awards, unfortunately this will always be one of the best films in history to have not won an Oscar, but don't let that affect your opinion.

I've read a number of the other user comments on this movie, and I was glad to see that every one of them regarded the movie as one of the best they've ever seen. The fact that 100% of the reviews I saw all rated this movie as somewhere beyond excellent says it all. I like all sorts of films, from serious to goofy comedies, but my list of the best films of the last 15 or so years includes the heavy hitters like Rain Man, Unforgiven, Jerry Maguire, Good Will Hunting, Murder In The First (because of Kevin Bacon's awe-inspiring performance) and Saving Private Ryan, which are all fabulous movies. But Shawshank tops them all by a good margin. It is, without a doubt, that good.

I'm also an avid reader, one of those who thinks that the book almost always far outshines the movie, no matter how good the movie. And Shawshank is one of my favorite stories by my favorite author, but this movie takes the story to a completely new level. I've never encountered another written or filmed work that better shows the 'triumph of the spirit' theme.

There are a number of deeply moving scenes in the movie, but for me, the climax of the movie, the point where everything comes together, is when Morgan Freeman's character is released from prison and contemplating killing himself. He finally comes to understand (or maybe just to accept) something that Tim Robbins' character told him earlier, and he says, "Get busy living... or get busy dying. That's goddamn right." This line starts a sequence that leads up to what, in my opinion, is the most perfect ending ever filmed.

Every aspect of this movie is of the highest caliber. The script is excellent, the acting of Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins is incredible, the musical score is flawless, and the direction is obviously superb. What's even more incredible is that this was Frank Darabont's first feature film - and he surely rose above to make this one. Forrest Gump won the Oscars it did because of its sentimentality and the nostalgic look at American history. It did NOT win because it was the best picture of that year. I had no problem with Tom Hanks winning the best actor award, but Shawshank should have won every other award it was nominated for. I though Forrest Gump was excellent, but Shawshank was so much better that its getting beat out for best picture is on a par with Shakespeare In Love beating Saving Private Ryan.

Well, I'll get off my soap box now. I would have no problem going on with how moving and beautifully-done this movie is, but I think you probably get the point by now.

The Shawshank Redemption is the 1994 movie about the banker named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins). Andy finds himself being accused of the murder of his cheating wife and her lover. After being convicted of both murders, Andy is sentenced to two life sentences at the dark Shawshank Penitentiary. He is mostly a quiet man and only talks to a few men in prison. Early on, Andy meets Ellis 'Red' Redding (Morgan Freeman). Red is the man in prison who can get things from the outside and knows how the prison runs. He may be a step above the inmates and a step below the guards, but deals with both to keep everyone satisfied. Throughout Andy's years in prison, he has many projects that he works on, starting on maybe the hardest--surviving. From the very beginning of his incarceration, Andy has to fight off the prison gang 'The Sisters' who try to isolate Andy so the can sexually have their way with him. After the leader is finally taken care of by the guards, Andy is left alone to work on other ventures. Andy decides to take up an old hobby and start carving rocks in chess pieces by using the rock hammer he received from Red. He is later given an office job of assistant librarian after doing taxes for the warden and all the prison guards. During these years, Andy writes to state legislators to get the prison money for a better library and helps many inmates receive a high school education. Andy soon finds out that the warden is corrupt and helps him launder money, but makes sure the warden doesn't find out about his plans that he is willing to carry out at the end of the movie. This is very dark movie and shows both the good and bad sides of living out a life sentence. The movie has a message about how some men become part of the prison and cannot live without it. It shows that people can get mentally attached to the worst the world has to offer.

Whenever I talk about this movie with my friends, I do not even refer to it by title, but rather as "The Movie". When I say "The Movie", my friends know exactly what I'm talking about. In fact the main reason that me and my friends don't refer to it by title is because this movie is so great, that we do not feel worthy enough to say it's name in vain! I still remember the first time I saw The Shawshank Redemption. Some friends of mine and I went to see it at one of those "Budget Theaters" over the summer of 1995. None of us really knew anything about the movie, but we had heard that it was pretty good. So, not having any real expectations, we saw it. When the final credits rolled and the lights came on in the theater, all of us just sat there with our jaws hanging down on the floor. I turned my head towards my friend Bob and said "That was the greatest movie I have ever seen in my entire life!" There's really no other way I can put it in words. Every moment of this movie captivated me and inspired me to believe in the one true thing in life...... "HOPE". This movie is sad, uplifting, inspiring, harsh, cold, funny (at the right times), jaw-dropping, and heart-warming all at the same time. I get chills every time I watch this film and this film contains the greatest ending (which takes place over the last 30 minutes or so)in movie history! How it all just "comes together" is so incredible and uplifting. I should also mention the music in this movie is nearly flawless as well, and the soundtrack is a "must buy" for any music fan. The only bad thing about this movie is the fact that I know I will never see a better movie, no matter how many I may see. I've seen many movies over the past few years, many excellent films. However, every time I walk out of the theater, I turn to my friend or family member that I saw it with and I say, "That was a great movie, but it wasn't nearly as good as 'you know what'!" There have been many movies over the past few years that thought would really move me or that I might one day call my "favorite of all time", but they've all fallen far short of "The Shawshank Redemption". So, if you have yet to see this movie, please run to the video store immediately. You're guaranteed to find it in the "employee picks" section. And if it isn't in that section, then you should tell the employees there that there is something seriously wrong with them.

The Shawshank Redemption, directed by Frank Darabont, is a cinematic masterpiece that has captured the hearts of audiences worldwide since its release in 1994. Based on Stephen King's novella, the film tells the gripping story of Andy Dufresne, a banker wrongfully convicted of murder and sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary. With its stellar performances, compelling narrative, and profound themes, The Shawshank Redemption has become a beloved classic that stands the test of time.

At the heart of The Shawshank Redemption lies its captivating narrative, which seamlessly weaves together elements of friendship, hope, resilience, and the quest for freedom. The film brilliantly portrays the harsh realities of prison life while also exploring the human capacity for redemption. Tim Robbins delivers a remarkable performance as Andy Dufresne, a man who maintains his innocence and refuses to let the prison system break his spirit. Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Ellis "Red" Redding, Andy's fellow inmate and narrator, adds depth and warmth to the story, as he becomes a pillar of friendship and guidance for Andy. The film expertly develops a rich ensemble of characters, each with their own struggles and complexities, making them relatable and deeply human.

One of the most remarkable aspects of The Shawshank Redemption is its ability to evoke a range of emotions within the audience. From moments of despair and injustice to instances of triumph and camaraderie, the film takes viewers on an emotional rollercoaster. It delves into profound themes such as the power of hope, the resilience of the human spirit, the corrupt nature of institutions, and the importance of personal redemption. The film's exploration of these themes leaves a lasting impact, forcing us to reflect on our own lives and the choices we make.

Frank Darabont's direction is nothing short of masterful. He skillfully navigates between intense prison scenes and quiet moments of contemplation, creating a perfect balance that keeps the audience engaged throughout. The cinematography by Roger Deakins beautifully captures the oppressive atmosphere of the prison, juxtaposing it with breathtaking shots that symbolize freedom and hope. The film's visual aesthetics, combined with a hauntingly beautiful score by Thomas Newman, further enhance the overall cinematic experience.

The Shawshank Redemption's universal message of hope and redemption resonates with audiences across generations and cultures. Its exploration of the human condition, the longing for freedom, and the search for meaning in life transcends time and societal boundaries. The film serves as a reminder that even in the darkest of circumstances, there is always a glimmer of hope and the possibility for redemption. Its enduring popularity and widespread acclaim are a testament to its cultural relevance and ability to touch the hearts of viewers worldwide.

In the realm of cinema, The Shawshank Redemption stands tall as an exceptional film that continues to captivate audiences with its powerful storytelling, memorable characters, and profound themes. It serves as a timeless reminder of the human capacity for resilience, friendship, and redemption. The film's ability to evoke a wide range of emotions, combined with its expert direction, beautiful cinematography, and thought-provoking narrative, solidifies its status as a true masterpiece. The Shawshank Redemption is a film that deserves to be celebrated and cherished for generations to come.

"Shawshank Redemption" came out on Sept. 23, 1994. Here are 10 things to know about the modern classic shot at Ohio State Reformatory:

1. The film was nominated for seven Academy Awards in 1994: best picture, best actor (Morgan Freeman), best adapted screenplay, best cinematography, best editing, best original score and best sound mixing. It won none.

2. "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption," a novella from Stephen King's story collection "Different Seasons," was the basis for "The Shawshank Redemption." King sold the story rights for $5,000. Two other stories from King's book also were turned into Hollywood films, "Stand By Me" and "Apt Pupil."

3. "Shawshank" director Frank Darabont went on to direct "The Green Mile" (1999), another prison film based on a Stephen King story. He also developed and executive produced the AMC zombie series "The Walking Dead."

4. Made for $25 million, "The Shawshank Redemption" only grossed $28 million during its theatrical release. The film has been successful on VHS, DVD, Blu-ray and cable television.

5. While the character of Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding was written by Stephen King as a middle-aged Irishman with graying red hair, director Darabont cast Freeman for his solid presence. Previously, Robert Redford, Paul Newman, Harrison Ford and Clint Eastwood had been considered for the role.

6. "The Shawshank Redemption" is No. 1 on IMDb's user-chosen list of Top 250 films, a ranking it has held since 2008, when it bumped "The Godfather" from the top spot. It is not the only 1994 movie in the top 10. "Pulp Fiction" starring Uma Thurman, John Travolta, Samuel L. Jackson and Bruce Willis is at No. 8. "Forrest Gump," which beat "Shawshank" for the Best Picture at the Academy Awards, is No. 12. Two other 1994 movies, "Leon: The Professional" and "The Lion King" are in the top 250 at No. 29 and No. 33, respectively.

7. Andy and Red's opening conversation in the prison yard took nine hours to shoot, with Morgan Freeman (Red) pitching a baseball throughout. The next day the actor appeared on set with his arm in a sling.

8. Tom Hanks and Kevin Costner both turned down the role of Andy due to their respective commitments to "Forrest Gump" and "Waterworld."

9. The Danish title for "The Shawshank Redemption" translates to "A World Outside." The Italian title means "The Wings of Freedom." The Israeli title means "Walls of Hope." In Taiwan, the film was released as "1995: Fantastic."

10. Freeman's voice-over narration for "Shawshank" was recorded before filming began, then played on the set to create the rhythm of each scene.

How ironic that an innocent man winds up being surrounded by the corruption of the legal system. Shawshank itself is similar to the character of Andy Dufresne. Prejudging this classic film, critics couldn't get past the title. The public followed suit, initially dismissing Shawshank, which failed in the box office just like "It's a Wonderful Life" and "Citizen Kane." It could have just whithered away on the store shelves, like Andy Dufresne could have in his own cell. But the characters prevailed, because Andy -- And Shawshank -- stayed true. Now, these movies are right up there as the most popular films of all time.

The Shawshank Redemption was likely going to be good. Nothing outstanding to timestamp on the history of film, but by 1995 it had suddenly grown a cult following and understandably so. It took a few years to become to cinematic phenomenon it is but in 1994 it was still recognised by the Academy with a best picture nomination, but it could not contend with big players such as the likes of Pulp Fiction and eventual winner Forrest Gump. Whether or not it should have won that year's Oscar award is still highly debated due to the quality of film from that year, but by no doubt it has aged the best, even better than Tarantino's acclaimed and admired Pulp Fiction.

Does the Shawshank Redemption have great cinematography? Yes. But is it monumental to film like Stanley Kubrick's Barry Lyndon or Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai? No. It's not specifically outstanding. Is it an artsy and classy film with technical detail to inadvertently sway the audience's emotions? To an extent yes, but not quite as artsy or technical as Francis Ford Coppola's Godfather trilogy or Martin Scorcese's Raging Bull. It is simply an excellent film with excellent technique made into a timeless film because it is so rewarding to the viewer. For starters, the plot is excellent. It is often a very underrated factor of a film but your plot is so important to a viewer. It is a tale of a man wrongfully convicted of murder who uses his wit, integrity, patience and most of all hope to persevere. It instills a reason to watch the film, to watch the protagonist struggle under such odds. Like said before, the camera work is excellent with them utilising the shot variation to convey the emotion of the scene. And next I would like to mention the sub plot. One often failed thing in films. They try too hard to build the sub charachter and in the end it does nothing in the long run. The main sub plot of an old man who owns a library in the prison is such a great contributor not only to the story but to the circumstances and environment. Not to forget the excellent acting and narration by Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins. It has absolutely fantastic antagonists as well.

As well as this, it acts quite like a David Fincher film in that it rewards you more whenever you watch it a second time around. There are little details and smart lines of dialogue which you can pick up on. It is just so fantastic how every minute of that film gets tied in a neat little bow. Everything comes full circle. Perhaps nothing so unexpected would turn out to be so excellent. I only take issue with the ending which with the beginning is the most important part of the film. I hear one of the Castle Rock producers insisted on a complete conclusion with the ending, but if that little knot had just stayed untied then that film would have been even better. In spite of this, it is with no doubt in the top 10 (and likely top 5 films ever made). Afterall, it hasn't been IMDB's top film for so long for nothing. Pure excellence.

If you can't watch a movie which doesn't contain any explosions, wild car chases or corrupt cops, then this movie probably isn't for you. However, if you enjoy a good story with great acting and execution, then you really should look into "The Shawshank Redemption".

So why is the movie so good? The movie as a whole is simply breath-taking. In addition to the exceptional story, everything is "just right". I've seen loads of movies with good stories, but most of them seem to fail in other aspects (poor acting, poor camera-work and such) making the movie as a whole not live up to its potential. "The Shawshank Redemption" is NOT one of them. It actually manages to pull it off, resulting in what I deem to be one of the best movies ever made.

I give it a 10/10, without any hesitation.

For those of you who rated this movie a 1/10: Shame on You! There is no way, even if you don't personally love the movie, that you can deny it's one of the best movies ever made. Just like there are some people who may not have personally loved the Godfather, Citizen Kane, Shindler's List, etc. and, therefore, gave those movies a 1/10. That's a bunch of crap. I personally didn't love the Godfather, but thats because it's not exactly my type of movie. That doesn't mean I bashed it and gave it a 1/10. I could see right away all the great qualities the movie had. So for those of you who voted 1/10 for shaw-shank, ask yourselves if it was really that bad, or was it just that you personally didn't enjoy it as much as everybody else...My guess is you would respond truthfully to the latter, so at least give it a 7, 8, or 9, not a 1. Thats all I have to say about that.

Now about the movie...The writing, the acting, the the music, the theme, etc. It's all as close to perfect as you will find in a movie. I don't want to write any spoilers, so let me just say that each and every scene of this movie is well crafted. It's the type of movie that keeps you on your toes from beginning to end. This is one of the only movies that I can remember that was so good, I forgot I was watching a movie. You can connect with the characters on such a personal level. Everything they do feels real. Nothing is under or overblown. TIm Robbins was the perfect cast for Andy Dufrane. Robbins' melodramatic personality lends itself perfectly to his character (Andy). As a viewer, you can never really tell what Andy is doing or thinking. Unlike most heroes, Andy doesn't make his objective clear to the audience. Morgan Freeman is the perfect actor for the character Red. Listening to him narrate the story is a real treat. I don't want to say anymore for those of you who haven't watched the movie yet. If you are one of those people, I wouldn't skip out on this movie. You will be doing yourself a disservice by missing this film. One of the best.

There are only a handful of films that have shaken me to my core and continued to resonate with me for very long after their first viewing. I can happily say that "The Shawshank Redemption" has stuck to me since I finished watching it for the first time, and instantly rocketed up my Top 10 Films list.

Most great films have one or two obvious flaws that can be easily picked out - not so in "Shawshank", at least not to me. The hefty run time doesn't put me off because the story and characters are just so well rounded and so easy to return to time and time again.

"Shawshank" is one of those films that I would love to experience for the first time all over again. The thrill of emotions and the highs and lows I felt that first time are incomparable to much else.

In my opinion, "Forrest Gump" was not as deserving of the Best Picture Oscar as this. The timeless feel of a story of friendship in a hopeless place will likely continue to capture generations of people for years to come.

Other than just the message of this movie the acting was phenomenal. Tim Robbins gave one of the greatest performances ever. He was inspiring, intelligent and most of all positive. His performance just made me smile. Robbins plays Andy Dufresne who was wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is gets to life sentences but yet never gives up hope. In he becomes friends with Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding played by Morgan Freeman. Freeman who gives the finest performance of his career has unlike Robbins lost hope. He is in deep regret of the crime that he committed. His way of deflecting the pain away is by trying to not feel anything at all. With his friendship with Andy he learns that without our hopes and dreams we have nothing. Andy also becomes friends with the rest of Red's group. James Whitmore also gave a great performance as Brooks Halten who gets out of prison parole but in the words of Red he has been "institutionalized".

The directing by Frank Darabont was just magnificent. He kept this movie at a great steady pace along with the writing and great cinematography. He portrayed prison life in such a horrifying way, but not in terms of the physical pain but the stress and pain that wares mentally on the inmates, some of which deserve a second chance.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic gem that transcends the boundaries of time and genre. Frank Darabont's 1994 adaptation of Stephen King's novella delivers an emotionally charged, thought-provoking narrative that has cemented its place as one of the greatest films in cinematic history.

The heart of the film lies in the friendship between Andy Dufresne, played brilliantly by Tim Robbins, and Ellis "Red" Redding, portrayed by the incomparable Morgan Freeman. Their on-screen chemistry is a true cinematic marvel, delivering performances that are nothing short of remarkable. Tim Robbins' portrayal of a man wrongfully convicted and his unwavering hope is a testament to the human spirit's resilience. Morgan Freeman's narration and portrayal of Red, the seasoned inmate, provide a soulful anchor to the story.

The plot is meticulously crafted, keeping the audience engaged throughout the film's 142-minute runtime. It weaves elements of hope, friendship, and the indomitable human spirit into a complex tale of redemption within the bleak confines of Shawshank State Penitentiary. The screenplay beautifully balances moments of despair and triumph, making the viewer's emotional journey a truly cathartic experience.

Cinematographer Roger Deakins captures the prison's stark, foreboding atmosphere and the transformative beauty of freedom with striking visuals. The film's timeless cinematography, along with Thomas Newman's evocative score, complements the storytelling in a way that deepens the emotional impact of every scene.

The supporting cast, featuring actors such as Bob Gunton, William Sadler, and Clancy Brown, contributes to the film's rich tapestry of characters, each with their own compelling stories and arcs.

What sets "The Shawshank Redemption" apart is its universal message of hope and redemption. It reminds us that even in the darkest of circumstances, the human spirit can endure and find its way back to the light. The film's profound themes resonate with audiences of all ages and backgrounds.

Ultimately, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of cinema. It's a timeless story of friendship, hope, and the resilience of the human spirit. A true classic, it will continue to inspire and touch the hearts of generations to come. If you haven't experienced this cinematic triumph, don't miss the opportunity to watch a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

The worst assumption one could make of The Shawshank Redemption is to think it's a depressing prison movie. Admittedly that's exactly what I thought when I first saw the preview scene of Morgan Freeman telling Tim Robbins that "hope is a dangerous thing.." I remember thinking OK my life really isn't like being in prison, but do I wanna watch something that's gonna bring the mood down a notch. Big mistake at the time, but just like the title, I had my own redemption of sorts when I caught it on video.

The performances of Robbins & Freeman should have won the best & supporting actor oscars and the work of the rest of the cast makes you wish they had an ensemble category. To late for "shoulds" I know, but in years to come if this title doesn't cement itself into the all time top 5 I'll be surprised.

This movie tells us a tale that takes place during the 1940's in a horror prison called Shawshank. The story is about a young banker named Andy Dufresne; a man was wrongly accused of murdering his wife though he was innocent. After Andy Dufresne was sentenced to Shawshank Prison, he must deal with those people despise and bully him, those brutal guards without any justice, and a corrupt warden who cannot do anything. Then he discovers the horror of prison. Prisoners in this prison seem to have been forgotten the hope and freedom which belonged to them. They forget how to live a free life and cannot think of some beautiful things outside the prison. Gradually, they get use to the prison life and give up the seeking of freedom. They become unconcerned and lose their faith, which is the most awful thing to one¡¯s life. In this prison he meets a man who has been sentenced to there for some time already, Red, who then strikes up the friendship with him. He is the narrator and is known as the guy who is able to get almost any type stuff from the prison. He helps Andy finding a rock hammer which helps Andy escape from the prison at last. What make me admire Andy most is his unremitting perseverance. He spends almost 20 years to dig a channel and escape outside from the prison just by a small rock hammer! One should not lose or give up his faith and dream, or just like a man without his soul. He cannot do nothing only knows he is surviving in the world like an animal. Courage is the motivations which stimulate you go ahead the success field in the dream. Andy writes a letter to Red after he gets outside. In the letter, such sentences like this:

Remember, Red. Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things,

and no good thing ever dies. I will be hoping that this letter finds

you, and finds you well. Your friend. Andy. I like the letter very much. It touches my heart deeply and makes me think much. I think about the life in the future, think about the meaning of my life. How should I do and which road I choose will make the life more meaningful? It is decided by yourself!

There's not much to be said about Shawshank that hasn't already been said. Morgan Freeman's acting here is some of his best, Frank Darabount's direction is near-perfect, and the story is a classic. But what really stands out is the classic feel of the movie, the sheer simplicity and perfect pacing that makes this film reminiscent of far older classics. It's not enriched in innovation but it's a worthy return to form, a perfectly-crafted masterpiece that deserves all the praise it has garnered.

Our lives are full of ups and downs. From the seemingly petty and minuscule problems of our youth, to the deep-seated frustrations and serious life-changing situations of our adulthood. Through most of those issues, we are left with mainly two choices: wallow in the despair and hopelessness of the situation, or embrace the hope that things can change AND work towards that change. That's the core philosophy that I always get from this film, my favorite of all-time.

Starting in the late 1940s, The Shawshank Redemption follows Andy (Tim Robbins), a banker that is wrongly imprisoned for the murder of his wife and her lover. After being sent to the brutal Shawshank Prison, he befriends long-time convict Red (Morgan Freeman), as the two develop a friendship that would alter the course of both of their lives.

To those that have known me, my love for this film is probably widely known. Ever since I first saw it back in the mid-1990s, while going through some "petty" romantic frustrations of my teens, the film instilled in me that philosophy I mentioned in the opening paragraph: I could wallow in my frustrations and get stuck where I was, or I could assure myself that things can change, and move towards that. "Get busy living or get busy dying".

As juvenile and inconsequential as my issues at that moment might've been, I've pretty much made that my philosophy of life against any life problems and situations I've faced since. From health issues to economical problems, from career frustrations to more adult relationship situations, I always try to embrace the hope that things can, and will change, and get busy working for that.

After rewatching the film for the gazillion time a couple of days ago on my birthday, 25+ years after the first time, I can say it remains as magical, profound, and meaningful to me. Not only is it masterfully directed and shot, but the honest and endearing performances from Robbins and Freeman are always moving, always affecting; a testimony of how, yes, a friendship, but also your own actions and attitude towards life can help keep you alive, hopeful, and free.

The Shawshank Redemption is a prison movie about Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a man being charged with the murder of his wife and her lover and is consequently sent to Shawshank prison on two life sentences. Year after year, Andy faces more and more adversity, victimized by ruthless prison guards and malicious inmates, but combining his mentality, courage, determination and spirit, as well as his close friendship with veteran inmate Red (Morgan Freeman), Andy's journey becomes an utterly unforgettable one.

The reason Shawshank is so good is because it's so incredibly moving and powerful. Up until the very last minute, you're drawn tightly towards the screen witnessing, step by step, Andy's growth in Shawshank prison. The acting is sublime, the dialogue is intelligent, the story is inspirational, the cinematography is breathtaking and every other little detail is done to maximum superiority.

Above all, is my comment about this movie, and I hope have a communicate with you on the movie.

A monumental celebration of resiliency, The Shawshank Redemption explores eternal themes of hope and friendship through the story of a banker convicted of murder adjusting to a brutal new life behind bars.

It's 1947 in New England, and young bank vice president Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is sent to the sprawling Shawshank State Penitentiary to serve two consecutive life sentences. The prison is run by warden Samuel Norton (Bob Gunton), who believes in discipline and the Bible, and ruthless chief guard Byron Hadley (Clancy Brown). Andy initially sticks to himself and has to fend off the unwanted advances of a group of pathologically violent rapists. He then befriends resourceful long-timer Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), a leader among the prisoners and legendary for being able to secure any item from outside the prison walls - for a standard 20 percent mark-up.

Andy finally establishes his reputation by helping Hadley save on his taxes. Norton then appoints Andy as his personal banker and chief tax-evader. Over the years, Andy uses his elevated position within the prison community to dramatically enhance the prison library, and helps several convicts to finish their high school education. But a shocking confession from a prisoner in another facility sets Andy on a collision course with Norton. 19 years into his sentence, Andy's determination to hang onto hope faces its ultimate challenge.

A generally faithful adaptation of a Stephen King novella, The Shawshank Redemption is a dazzling achievement. Director and screenwriter Frank Darabont constructs a deeply moving essay on the adaptability of the human spirit, and the conflict between hope and despair when the future appears uniformly grim.

i've seen the top 50 films in the IMDb top 250 category and a number of times I've felt that a movie wasn't worth its ranking. the shawshank redemption fits this bill in not being placed number one. and this coming from a die-hard god father fan must surely mean something. the storyline, the cinematography and the acting are all masterpieces in their own right. the story of a wronged person accepting his fate and then changing it is remarkable, for everyone relates to it, though maybe not to the extent portrayed here. kudos to stephen king and frank darabont and the actors for a great movie. its a real pity that it won no Oscars. this is one movie i would have hated to miss. truly exceptional.

Every man, woman, and child has the word "success" etched into their mind. Oftentimes, failure seems like a despicable and frowned upon idea; we tend to push ourselves past the breaking point simply to ensure that we succeed. Ball's idea of "knowing what you can not do" is a significant topic that pesters society today. Limits exist to provide control and a sense of stability in our lives. If people are not aware of what they "can" and "can not do," they will push their boundaries until chaos erupts. Although limits may hinder progress, Lucille Ball's belief regarding the importance of knowing "our limitations" is crucial to society's development because limits allow for overall prosperity and order.

There's really no other way I can put it in words. Every moment of this movie captivated me and inspired me to believe in the one true thing in life...... "HOPE". This movie is sad, uplifting, inspiring, harsh, cold, funny (at the right times), jaw-dropping, and heart-warming all at the same time. I get chills every time I watch this film and this film contains the greatest ending (which takes place over the last 30 minutes or so)in movie history! How it all just "comes together" is so incredible and uplifting. I should also mention the music in this movie is nearly flawless as well, and the soundtrack is a "must buy" for any music fan. I don't think there's anything new one can say about this movie that hasn't already been said over the years. 14 years ago a friend gave me the dvd to watch it, and he said it was his favourite movie. I started watching this movie with skepticism, because when people overhype the movies for me, i usually end up not liking them that much, because of the high expectations. But boy, oh boy, was this an exception to that rule. I finished this movie feeling completely inspired and amazed what i had just seen. I was trying to understand why i had loved it so much when the story is not a complicated one, actually it's a very simple one. Then i realized it was because it is a movie that can apply to most people in life, especially at those times we need a little more hope.

A lot of scenes stand out, from the horror Andy endures, like tha harassment from the "sisters", the times spent in "the hole" or the 20 years he spends in jail for a crime he didn't commit, to the beautiful and inspiring scenes, like the roof top part, the singin Italian lady, Andy's letter in the end. Or even the heartbreaking scene with Brooks. I don't want to say much more, because i don't want to spoil it to newcomers of this masterpiece.

Just be prepared to be moved, inspired, and watch a perfect example of what cinema should strive for: an amazing script, amazing acting, a beautiful story that will leave you thinking and if you are lucky enough, it will inspire you like it has inspired me and countless others. Absolutely one of the best movies of all time and my personal favourite.

The Shawshank Redemption is a metaphor, an analogy about holding onto a sense of personal worth, despite everything. The Redemption in the title holds true to its meaning from every aspect of the story. When Warden Norton realizes Andy has escaped with the documents he looks at the framed words from the Bible - "His judegement cometh and that Right Soon....". Soon after this is shown again when Red reads out Andy's letter under the white oak tree. Andy writes those beautiful words - "Remember Red, hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies." The film wonderfully depicts the lead roles Andy and Red's daily sustenance and minor triumphs. Its truly inspiring. Most splendid is Thomas Newman's somber score which at its best moments alights with radiant textures and sprightly grace notes. When Red says - "I hope the Pacific is as blue as it has been in my dreams. I hope." It gives an eternal peace to the audience to watch the end of their journey and the forthcoming reunion of the two buddies. The movie although being a prison story with a sense of frustration on the lives of the prisoners it is really about the unlikely friendship between Andy and Red. How each one of them nurtures the other and serves as a touchstone for keeping their sanity intact. This movie is timeless for me.

The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont, based on the 1982 Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. It tells the story of banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), who is sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary for the murders of his wife and her lover, despite his claims of innocence. Over the following two decades, he befriends a fellow prisoner, contraband smuggler Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), and becomes instrumental in a money-laundering operation led by the prison warden Samuel Norton (Bob Gunton). William Sadler, Clancy Brown, Gil Bellows, and James Whitmore appear in supporting roles. I see this movie 3 time and it is very good

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a 1994 American drama film directed by Frank Darabont and based on the novella by Stephen King. The film follows the story of Andy Dufresne, a successful banker who is wrongfully convicted of the murder of his wife and her lover and sentenced to life in Shawshank State Penitentiary.

The film stars Tim Robbins as Dufresne and Morgan Freeman as Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding, a longtime inmate and Dufresne's friend. The cast also includes Bob Gunton, William Sadler, and Clancy Brown in supporting roles.

The film is known for its powerful performances, moving storyline, and iconic scenes. Darabont's direction is masterful, creating a tense and emotional atmosphere that keeps audiences engaged from beginning to end. The film explores themes of hope, redemption, and the human spirit, as Dufresne and Redding navigate the harsh realities of prison life and find ways to survive and even thrive within the confines of their situation.

One of the film's most memorable scenes is the moment when Dufresne escapes from Shawshank using a tunnel he had been digging for years. The scene is shot with a sense of awe and wonder, as Dufresne emerges from the tunnel and into the pouring rain, symbolizing his newfound freedom.

Overall, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a classic film that has stood the test of time. Its powerful performances, compelling storyline, and emotional resonance continue to captivate audiences and make it a beloved favorite among moviegoers around the world.

Those in support aren't faring too bad either. Bob Gunton is coiled spring smarm as Warden Norton, James Whitmore is heart achingly great as the "Birdman Of Shawshank," Clancy Brown is menacing as antagonist Capt. Byron Hadley, William Sadler amusing as Heywood & Mark Rolston is impressively vile as Bogs Diamond. Then there's Roger Deakins' lush cinematography as the camera gracefully glides in and out of the prison offering almost ethereal hope to our characters (yes, they are ours). The music pings in conjunction with the emotional flow of the movie too. Thomas Newman's score is mostly piano based, dovetailing neatly with Andy's state of mind, while the excellently selected soundtrack ranges from the likes of Hank Williams to the gorgeous Le Nozze di Figaro

This is good example of how to not to make a movie. It begins quite dry. The main character doesn't seem like he quite knows how to act as he is thrown into a poorly lit scene in what seems to be the director's garage revamped. He then goes to prison. NO SENSE WHATSOEVER! Obviously there is a huge paradigm between what the director though the film to be and the original writers.

We then see all of what we normally find in prison, with a very fatal exception. NO MINING! I am a personal favorite of mining in prison. I love to see people smash rocks and burn coal for fire. We mainly find dry dialog from what appears to be actors who have never left their parent's basement (no wonder the director still films at his home). I had to leave the room a few times so that I could get some fresh air while the movie attempted be filmed.

My advice is to buy this film only if you need a DVD or VHS tape for a scrap booking project. The reflective qualities are very nice and the packaging insert can also be used to store a home video. Be sure not to allow the label to be visible, as that may cause your friends to disown you forever.

As the uptight banker, Robbins does some of his subtlest acting to date. As his hardened but resilient friend, Freeman is simply miraculous, giving the role so much depth, dignity, and good humor that you feel that you've known this man forever. "The Shawshank Redemption" is one of those rare films that ages better with time. People talk about this film more now than when it was released in 1994. The acting, writing, cinematography, direction, music, editing and everything else makes this as close to a perfect film as you can get.... Speaking of jail, "Shawshank"-the-movie seems to last about half a life sentence. The story, chiefly about the 20-year friendship between Freeman and Robbins, becomes incarcerated in its own labyrinthine sentimentality.

Director Frank Darabont has made a prison fable out of a Stephen King short story. It is well acted by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Freeman is especially important as he is the narrator and the POV of the story. It's his lyrical voice that makes this fable compelling. It could have easily been a simple prison movie that rang hollow. Freeman gave the readings depth.

If there is one complaint, it is Andy's claim of innocence. It needs to be shown early on during the trial. Instead, we derived mostly from Andy's demeanor. It needs to be a big declaration at the beginning. When Tommy (Gil Bellows) tells the story, he should include one detail from the trial like the 8 bullets. That way, the audience can get an aha moment. It's a minor point, and overall this is a good prison fable.

The Shawshank Redemption was released in a very good year for movies (1994) and although it could very well be argued that, at the time, it did not get the credit it deserved-- being overshadowed by movies like Pulp Fiction and Forrest Gump, it now may get more credit than it is due. Time and time again I have heard the phrase, "They don't make them like this anymore," when The Shawshank Redemption is spoke of. However, it should be noted that Shawshank was not the first movie of its kind and owes much credit to its predecessors (taking elements and ideas from movies like Dead Man Walking, It's a Wonderful Life, etc.) Well paced and often times very moving, The Shawshank Redemption provides us with what is initially a very realistic situation: middle aged man Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is put on trial wrongfully (as far as we know) for murder. Found guilty, he is put in jail for a life sentence. As the movie progresses , in part from beautiful cinematography, and in part from lightly tugging at the audiences heart strings, we are able to sympathize with the inmates, and almost pity them. The concept of having a home and not knowing what to do when not in your comfort zone is something that the Shawshank Redemption uses to make a simple idea into a very good full length movie. However, it is ranked #2 on IMDb's top 250 (with a rating of 9.2 it is actually higher than The Godfather, thus should be ranked #1) and this, I believe at least, is an undeserving spot for The Shawshank Redemption. While it is very good, it is certainly not among the ranks of Citizen Kane, The Godfather and others on that level. Providing us with little or no historical or cultural relevance, the movie likely earns its ranking because people can identify with it, so they end up enjoying it, and end up giving it a 10 out of 10 because they enjoy it so much. Though it pains me to say it, just because a movie is highly enjoyable, it does not make it great by any means. Andy Dufresne acts as a metaphor for the rest of the human race, and shows, how sometimes, we are all wrongfully accused of something or other. However, the movie pertains only to itself, not taking on anything bigger-- so it stays a very good movie rather than an excellent one.

This film is easily considered one of the greatest films of all time and I definitely agree with this fact.It was nominated for seven Academy Awards including (Best Picture, Best Actor - Morgan Freeman, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Original Score, and Best Sound) but didn't win any due to tough competition from the film Forrest Gump.

Imagine yourself in 1940's Maine, accused of a despicable crime of revenge on your wife and the man you recently found out was her lover, sent to a corrupted prison with a two-faced warden, where inmates are murdered for knowing information that would help an innocent man off the hook, or for crying on their first night of imprisonment. Where popularity with the guards gets you special privileges and crossing the warden while just trying to get the freedom you deserve gets you thrown into 'the hole' for a month. The only light of hope is the special friendship with a fellow inmate by the name of 'Red' and a rock-hammer hidden inside a Bible. "Salvation lies within." You can take my word for it, one thing that does lie within this movie is an incredible story of hope that will bring you to the point of tears at some points and enrage you at others. The acting is brilliant, the screenplay is superb. This drama places a new sense of hope in you that you would never have felt before. "The Shawshank Redemption" is absolutely the movie of choice for anyone who appreciates excellency in film-making.

There are two remarkable scenes in "Pieces of a Woman," though the first - an almost 30-minute, largely unbroken opening shot of a home birth - seems set to divert critical attention from the second.

That scene, arriving about halfway through the movie, feels at least as radical and courageous as its precedent. In it, we see the central couple, Martha and Sean (Vanessa Kirby and Shia LaBeouf), try to have sex. Both are grieving the death of their child; but while Martha has turned inward, Sean is reaching out with visible aggression.

You are introduced to Andy Deufresne, a banker who is sent to prison for life after being wrongly accused of murdering his wife and her lover. Before you know it, you witness the brutal things that happen in a 1940s prison. Beatings, murders, rape etc. But among all this brutality, he strikes up an extroardinary friendship with a fellow inmate called Red, a man who knows how to get things from the outside.

With his banking skills and his natural spirit, Andy gradually makes changes in that dark and miserable prison that touches all of his inmates in strange ways. To teach them all that nomatter how bad things get in life, there is always something inside you that others can't get to. Something that's personal and yours only. Hope.

Without question, I give this movie 11 out of 10 for great acting, clever and touching quotes, and for just being a beautiful story. Something that beats Titanic and Forrest Gump. This sense of freedom in the storytelling allows the film to consistently throw up genuine surprises, as the viewer isn't constantly on guard for clues and plot points

I keep coming back to this movie as one of my favorites of all time. To be able to watch this after 20+ years after its release and still feel such emotion is something that few films can accomplish, from characters you will quickly find yourself attached with, to an amazing look at the prison system, and a storyline that will have anyone unable to look away.

This movie really does deserve its spot as IDMB's #1 and if you have the time do give it a watch.

Those in support aren't faring too bad either. Bob Gunton is coiled spring smarm as Warden Norton, James Whitmore is heart achingly great as the "Birdman Of Shawshank," Clancy Brown is menacing as antagonist Capt. Byron Hadley, William Sadler amusing as Heywood & Mark Rolston is impressively vile as Bogs Diamond. Then there's Roger Deakins' lush cinematography as the camera gracefully glides in and out of the prison offering almost ethereal hope to our characters (yes, they are ours). The music pings in conjunction with the emotional flow of the movie too. Thomas Newman's score is mostly piano based, dovetailing neatly with Andy's state of mind, while the excellently selected soundtrack ranges from the likes of Hank Williams to the gorgeous Le Nozze di Figaro by Mozart.

Is Shawshank a good film? Yes. Is it the second greatest film of all time as this website suggests? Definitely not! I continually fail to see how people rank it so high. I don't even believe it was the best film of its given year. Pulp Fiction was a much more inventive film that changed the way films were made afterwards. Shawshank is a good film but I doubt it changed the cinematic landscape or it can be looked at as a work of an auteur. I am guessing the same people who regard it so high are the same people who have never seen a foreign film or consider black and white films hard to watch.

I hate to be so critical of a film that I enjoy. But at the same time, I feel I have to show my discontent with movie goers. I also don't consider the Lord of the Rings the 5th best film or Memento the 10th best film of all time. There were films made prior to 1990. People are free to have their opinions and I am allowed to have mine as well. My opinion is that the general public are the ones who encourage Hollywood to put out recycled formulas year after year.

A drama about the life of Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) after he is sent to Shawshank prison for the murder of his wife and her lover. There he befriends fellow prisoner 'Red' (Morgan Freeman) who narrates the film with several voice-overs. An ordinary man in such a situation would be crushed by despair but Red relates that Andy was no ordinary prisoner. Although prison is a kind of hell, even in a completely unforgiving and corrupt system with an evil warden and dangerous fellow inmates, he doesn't lose his spirit. Andy makes the best of the situation and can even claim small victories while serving time. Most important (for a Hollywood film) Andy doesn't lose hope. Red initially sees Andy's efforts as futility and leading to inevitable disappointment, but over time Red develops great admiration for Andy. The Shawshank Redemption is almost the perfect Hollywood film and told well enough to touch even the most jaded viewer, with an ending that brings the ultimate cinematic catharsis.

Love the characters and all of the different personalities that they represent not just in families but in society itself. It seems like the entire cast is part of every other movie that I love as well. The sounds, music, color and light in the film are just as much a part of the film as the people. This could be attributed to the method in which it was filmed. At many parts of the film I can still find myself feeling the emotions conveyed in the film.

The Shawshank Redemption is cinematic masterpiece directed by Frank Darabont, is the movie of all movies. It has touches of many themes from different types of genres such as drama, action, adventure, crime and mystery. Morgan Freeman narrates the movie perfectly with his soft southern tone of voice soothing to the listeners. The film, being an adaption of a Stephen King short story, has become one of his best stories along with another personal favorite of mine The Green Mile (1999).

The Shawshank Redemption is a powerful and moving film that explores themes of hope, friendship, and resilience in the face of adversity. It is also a scathing indictment of the American prison system, which is often portrayed as being corrupt, dehumanizing, and unjust.

What makes The Shawshank Redemption so special?

There are many things that make The Shawshank Redemption a special film. First and foremost, it is a beautifully told story with complex and well-developed characters. Andy Dufresne is a man of unwavering hope and determination, even in the darkest of circumstances. Red is a wise and compassionate man who has seen it all, but still maintains a sense of humanity. The supporting cast is also excellent, with memorable performances from Bob Gunton as the sadistic Warden Norton, William Sadler as the brutal Captain Hadley, and Clancy Brown as the menacing inmate Hadley.

Another thing that makes The Shawshank Redemption so special is its realistic portrayal of prison life. The film does not shy away from the harsh realities of incarceration, but it also shows that there can be moments of joy and even friendship behind bars. The film's message of hope is ultimately one of its greatest strengths.

The Shawshank Redemption as a social commentary

The Shawshank Redemption is also a powerful social commentary on the American prison system. The film shows how the system can be corrupt and dehumanizing, and how it can chew up and spit out innocent people. Andy Dufresne's wrongful conviction and subsequent incarceration is a prime example of the injustices that can occur within the prison system.

The film also explores the issue of rehabilitation. Andy Dufresne is a model prisoner who uses his skills and intelligence to help others. However, the prison system is not designed to rehabilitate inmates. Instead, it is focused on punishment and control. This is evident in the character of Warden Norton, who is more interested in using Andy's skills for his own personal gain than he is in helping him become a productive member of society.

Conclusion

The Shawshank Redemption is a classic film that deserves to be seen by everyone. It is a story of hope, friendship, and resilience in the face of adversity. It is also a powerful social commentary on the American prison system. The film is beautifully told, well-acted, and thought-provoking. It is a film that will stay with you long after you have seen it.

In addition to the above, here are some other thoughts on the film:

The Shawshank Redemption is a masterclass in storytelling. Darabont's screenplay is perfectly paced and structured, and he builds suspense and tension beautifully. The film is also visually stunning, with Roger Deakins' cinematography capturing the beauty and despair of Shawshank Prison.

The performances in The Shawshank Redemption are all top-notch. Tim Robbins is simply brilliant as Andy Dufresne, and Morgan Freeman gives one of the best performances of his career as Red. The supporting cast is also excellent, with Bob Gunton, William Sadler, and Clancy Brown all delivering standout performances.

The Shawshank Redemption is a film that stays with you long after you have seen it. It is a film that makes you think about the importance of hope, friendship, and resilience. It is also a film that challenges you to think about the American prison system and its flaws.

Overall, The Shawshank Redemption is a masterpiece of cinema. It is a film that everyone should see at least once in their lifetime.

The Shawshank Redemption has been voted the best film of all time after thousands of LADbible readers responded to a poll on Twitter featuring the top four ranked movies on IMDb. Of course, it's not an exact science, but enough people voted to make it a significant cross-section of people.

"Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies".

''Get busy living or get busy dying" The Shawshank Redemption is a film about hope. It is a film about perseverance, patience, and friendship. It is a lasting modern-day classic. The film is centered on two men, each serving a different Prison life sentence, and thus becoming close friends in the prison. The film was written and directed by Frank Darabont. And it is an adaptation of Stephen King's novella -"Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption".

In the film, Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding(Morgan Freeman) gives a narration of the lives of the Prisoners inside the Prison wall of a prison called "Shawshank". A place where, a prisoner can rediscover himself - 'Redemption". The movie begins with the scene, where a man parks his car in front of his house, obviously sober and drunk. This man is known as Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) then reaches for his gun which he kept in the glove compartment of his car and loads the gun with rounds of .38 caliber bullets. Apparently, that night Andy's wife and her lover, Mr. Glenn Quentin, were both inside the house in front of where Andy parked his car.

The next scene was inside a Courtroom where Mr. Andy Dufresne, a banker was convicted and found guilty of murdering his wife, and her lover. And sentenced two two life sentences, back to back.

"Red" (Morgan Freeman) is also an inmate of the Shawshank Prison and he was also serving a life sentence in prison. Fred's narration spoke about his friends in the prison, other fellow prisoners, the corrupt Warden Norton (Bob Gunton), the Captain of the prison guards (Captain Hardly).

Ellis "Red" Redding narrated about how he first saw Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) the day the Prison Bus drove into Shawshank with New inmates-"Fresh Fish". Red and his fellow friends made bets on who will be the first amongst the "fresh fish" to break down in tears and cry, during the first night in the prison. And of course "Red" placed a bet on Andy Dufresne, who definitely looks like some who will definitely break down and cry like a baby. But Andy proved Red wrong.

Andy though a smart, well-educated, and intelligent former banker surprised everyone inside the Shawshank prison. Many respected his quietness, calmness, determination, and also a sense of hope of one day getting out of the prison wall. Red, Andy's close pal, and fellow prison inmate through the years began to like and respect the man called Andy Dufresne through the years. Andy Dufresne fended off some sadistic fellow male prisoners - 'the Sisters' who continually harassed, beat, and wanted to physically harm and have sex with him (homosexuals).

Years later Andy found out that he was innocent of the crime that the Judge said he committed. As a fresh young prison inmate, Tommy later told both Andy and Red that one day he heard a former cellmate of his in another prison boasting of how he killed a banker's wife and her lover, but no one knew. But instead, the wife's husband was convicted of the crime and sentenced to life imprisonment. This made Andy go ahead and tell Warden Norton, which a big mistake Andy was made. This is because Warden Norton did not want the innocent Andy Dufresne to go to court and prove his innocence. Warden Norton (Bob Gunton) saw Andy as a very resourceful Prisoner due to his skill and knowledge Tax preparation, Tax filing, and bookkeeping abilities. Also, Andy did a good job of restoring the Prison's library and got State Grants to equip the Prison library with books.

In the Prison unknowingly to Red, Andy has been so hopeful and planning his escape from Shawshank prison. And for about twenty years, with the help of a 'Rock Hammer" (Red- the man who can get you whatever you need), Andy dug a tunnel through the wall in his prison cell, he escaped the prison yard. He escaped to a town very close to the Pacific Ocean (in Mexico).

Years later Ellis Boyd 'Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman) was granted parole. Red not enjoying this his new life, and of course not wanting to end up like his very old friend - Brooks the Old Librarian, who was granted parole and ended up committing suicide. Red later skipped parole, and with the help of his friend Andy Dufresne, he was able to escape also to the Pacific Ocean near the Town of "Zihuatanejo".

Shawshank Redemption received Seven Oscar nominations and a host of other nominations and a few awards. The secret to the film's structure, in my opinion, is that it is about our relationship with the hero - our curiosity, pity, and admiration. The picture would have been more conventional and less mysterious if Andy had been the heroic core, bravely enduring.

The Shawshank Redemption is written and directed by Frank Darabont. It is an adaptation of the Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. Starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, the film portrays the story of Andy Dufresne (Robbins), a banker who is sentenced to two life sentences at Shawshank State Prison for apparently murdering his wife and her lover. Andy finds it tough going but finds solace in the friendship he forms with fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding (Freeman). While things start to pick up when the warden finds Andy a prison job more befitting his talents as a banker. However, the arrival of another inmate is going to vastly change things for all of them.

There was no fanfare or bunting put out for the release of the film back in 94, with a title that didn't give much inkling to anyone about what it was about, and with Columbia Pictures unsure how to market it, Shawshank Redemption barely registered at the box office. However, come Academy Award time the film received several nominations, and although it won none, it stirred up interest in the film for its home entertainment release. The rest, as they say, is history. For the film finally found an audience that saw the film propelled to almost mythical proportions as an endearing modern day classic. Something that has delighted its fans, whilst simultaneously baffling its detractors. One thing is for sure, though, is that which ever side of the Shawshank fence you sit on, the film continues to gather new fans and simply will never go away or loose that mythical status.

It uses the narrator's calm, observant voice to include us in the story of men who have formed a community behind bars. It is deeper than most films; about continuity in a lifetime, based on friendship and hope.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is an outstanding film that truly stands the test of time. The film boasts an incredibly talented cast, with standout performances from Tim Robbins as Andy and Morgan Freeman as Red. One of the film's greatest strengths is its ability to balance drama, humor, and hope in a way that never feels forced or contrived. It's a movie that deals with heavy themes like injustice, corruption, and the prison system, but it never loses sight of the humanity of its characters. In conclusion, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a must-see film that has earned its place as a classic of the genre. It's a powerful, moving, and inspiring story that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Whether you're a fan of drama, comedy, or just great filmmaking in general, this movie is not to be missed.

This is the best story driven movie ever, and yet until the end it doesn't have any forceful direction in plot, it doesn't need it. All the lead up is a natural story, which is allowed to evolve and expand in a way that is so humanly aware and so subtle that it's remarkable. I remember showing this movie to some friends after I'd seen it and a parent walked in about halfway through and asked "was it good?" they all said it was enthralling and amazing, then the parent added "what's it about?". There was a pause, because everyone realised that to summarise this movie would undermine what it is about in every way possible: every nuance and intricacy is important, and they deserve every minute of screen time that they are generously awarded. We grow into the characters so well that we aren't surprised by how they behave, because we can understand it. Even the apparently crazy antics of Brooks is wholly comprehensible. Then there's the music, amazingly visual and emotionally abundant in content. The movies so good that it doesn't need music to drive it, but when the music is of such astounding quality you begin to get a real resonance of mood, and an extra dimension of depth in the already amazing aesthetics of the cinematography. Whether everyone else is blown away by this movie doesn't bother me, because I will know how lucky I am. Lucky that I came across this movie, and lucky that I get it... that I really get it, in a way obviously not everyone in the world can. Anyone reading this should just hope they will fall into this category, and anyone who hasn't yet should just watch it again, and again, and again... (Please note, the ending is just as perfect as the rest of the package, but in-case someone hasn't seen it yet, I don't want to give it away).

Mr Simms: The Shawshank Redemption is a timeless classic directed by Frank Darabont and released in 1994. It tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is wrongly convicted and sentenced to life in Shawshank State Prison for the murder of his wife and her lover. Despite facing a bleak future, Andy uses his wits and creativity to battle the harshness of prison life, befriending fellow inmates and eventually finding freedom in an unexpected way.

The movie is filled with strong performances, notably by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Robbins delivers an emotionally rich performance that captures all of the despair, sadness, and determination experienced by his character. Morgan Freeman's calm and collected narration adds a quiet dignity to the story as we gain insight into the lives of all the inmates of Shawshank.

The story is and always has been compelling and captivating, but what truly sets The Shawshank Redemption apart is its underlying message of hope. Throughout the film, Andy stays strong in his faith that he will survive the horrors of Shawshank and eventually earn his freedom. It serves as a reminder that, despite all of the adversities we may face in life, hope and perseverance will ultimately prevail.

The Shawshank Redemption is an enduring drama that offers insight into the human condition and demonstrates the power of resilience and hope. A must-see for movie fans of all ages, The Shawshank Redemption will leave you feeling inspired and deeply moved.

Hollywood is awesome in movie making in each and everything for their work, editing, acting, vfx and etc. Can Hollywood, usually creating things for entertainment purposes only, create art? To create something of this nature, a director must approach it in a most meticulous manner, due to the delicacy of the process. Such a daunting task requires an extremely capable artist with an undeniable managerial capacity and an acutely developed awareness of each element of art in their films, the most prominent; music, visuals, script, and acting. These elements, each equally important, must succeed independently, yet still form a harmonious union, because this mixture determines the fate of the artist's opus. Though already well known amongst his colleagues for his notable skills at writing and directing, Frank Darabont emerges with his feature film directorial debut, The Shawshank Redemption. Proving himself already a master of the craft, Darabont managed to create one of the most recognizable independent releases in the history of Hollywood. The Shawshank Redemption defines a genre, defies the odds, compels the emotions, and brings an era of artistically influential films back to Hollywood.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is my favorite movie. It's based on a story by Stephen King and directed by Frank Darabont. This film has left a deep impact on me.

The story takes place in a prison in New England and revolves around two prisoners, Andy Dufresne (played by Tim Robbins) and Ellis "Red" Redding (played by Morgan Freeman). The story unfolds and you will never expect how this is going to end.

The movie also touches on themes that I find relatable as someone from India. It emphasizes hope and friendship. Despite the challenges the characters face, they find a way to hold onto hope and support each other. The movie is based on the key emotional element "Hope" as I quote Andy "Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies."

The performances by the actors are exceptional. Tim Robbins portrays Andy, who's wrongly imprisoned, with a lot of depth. His transformation from vulnerability to strength is inspiring. Morgan Freeman as Red brings wisdom and warmth to the character, and his narration adds an extra layer of connection.

The visuals and cinematography effectively capture the emotions of the characters.

The movie's music, composed by Thomas Newman, complements the story beautifully. I love the opera scene, It made the prisoners feel an inch of freedom, symbol of hope and it gives them something from the outside world to connect to. This shows that the prisoners can connect with things that belong in the outside world.

In conclusion, "The Shawshank Redemption" is a timeless masterpiece that has a universal appeal. Its themes, performances, storytelling, and artistic presentation create a memorable movie that continues to stay with me.

The best movie ever is a subjective term.

Deciding on the best movie of all time requires a balance between objectivity and subjective preference, which can be different for industry professionals and general audiences. We took the top 250 movies on IMDb and Metacritic and assigned each movie a score based on the range of scores in the dataset. These equally weighted scores are summed and then normalized to our own Screen Rant score. The result is a rating system that gives equal and fair credit to audiences and critics, resulting in a list that spans the entire history of cinema .

If I had one criterion for choosing the best picture, it would be the emotional criterion. Somehow these movies hit me hard. Movies are the greatest art form of all time, designed to evoke emotion in the audience. It does it best. (If instead you pleaded for dance or music, theater or painting, I would answer that cinema contains all these arts).

There are only two ways to discuss the greatest movies of all time. You either pick your favorite and put it on the mat, or you create a list so extensive you're sure you've covered every nook and cranny of the cinema. That's what we're trying to do here - find the best of the entire movie. The starting point is covered. Romance, natural disaster epic, and thriller are all here too. Bang your fists on the table while yelling "You can't handle the truth!" while declaring Citizen Kane the best! Fun (even if you're streaming a movie here), but not as fun as having the whole list at your fingertips.
